beginner.question: When Jesus was arrested in the Garden of Gethsemane, one of His disciples pulled out a sword and cut off a servant's ear. Which disciple did this?
options: James
John
Peter
Thomas
beginner.explanation: Simon Peter drew his sword and struck the high priest's servant, cutting off his right ear. Jesus told Peter to put away his sword and healed the servant's ear.

beginner.question: After Jesus rose from the dead, one of His disciples refused to believe it until he could see and touch Jesus' wounds for himself. Which disciple demanded this proof?
options: Peter
Andrew
Thomas
Philip
beginner.explanation: Thomas said he would not believe unless he could put his fingers in the nail marks and his hand in Jesus' side. When Jesus appeared and invited him to do so, Thomas declared 'My Lord and my God!'

beginner.question: Before becoming an apostle, Paul (originally called Saul) was actually an enemy of the early Christians and persecuted them. What dramatic event on the road to Damascus changed his life?
options: An earthquake struck him down
A bright light from heaven blinded him and Jesus spoke to him
An angel appeared with a scroll
He had a vision in his sleep
beginner.explanation: As Saul travelled to Damascus to arrest Christians, a light from heaven flashed around him. He fell to the ground and heard Jesus say 'Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me?' He was blinded for three days until God sent Ananias to restore his sight.

beginner.question: Jesus once told a famous parable about a traveller who was robbed, beaten, and left on the road. Two religious leaders walked past without helping, but a man from Samaria stopped to care for him. What is this parable commonly called?
options: The Parable of the Lost Sheep
The Parable of the Good Samaritan
The Parable of the Prodigal Son
The Parable of the Sower
beginner.explanation: Jesus told this parable to answer the question 'Who is my neighbour?' The Samaritan bandaged the man's wounds, took him to an inn, and paid for his care — showing that loving your neighbour means helping anyone in need, regardless of background.

beginner.question: At the very first Christian Pentecost, the Holy Spirit came upon the disciples in Jerusalem. When this happened, what miraculous sign appeared above each of them?
options: Bright halos of golden light
Tongues of fire resting on their heads
Doves descending from heaven
Beams of sunlight through the clouds
beginner.explanation: When the day of Pentecost came, they heard a sound like a rushing wind and saw what looked like tongues of fire that separated and rested on each of them. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began speaking in other languages.

beginner.question: In the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus went up on a mountainside and delivered one of the most famous sermons ever recorded, teaching about blessings, loving your enemies, and prayer. What is this sermon commonly known as?
options: The Olivet Discourse
The Sermon on the Mount
The Farewell Address
The Galilean Teaching
beginner.explanation: The Sermon on the Mount, found in Matthew chapters 5-7, contains some of Jesus' most well-known teachings including the Beatitudes, the Lord's Prayer, and the Golden Rule.

beginner.question: When Jesus was just 12 years old, His parents Mary and Joseph took Him to Jerusalem for the Passover festival. On the way home, they realised He was missing and searched for three days. Where did they eventually find Him?
options: In the marketplace buying supplies
At the Temple, sitting among the teachers and discussing Scripture
At a relative's house in the city
By the River Jordan with John the Baptist
beginner.explanation: Mary and Joseph found the boy Jesus in the Temple courts, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking questions. Everyone who heard Him was amazed at His understanding. When His parents questioned Him, Jesus said 'Didn't you know I had to be in my Father's house?'

beginner.question: Jesus chose 12 men to be His closest followers. Two of these apostles were brothers who worked as fishermen, and Jesus gave them the nickname 'Sons of Thunder' because of their bold and fiery personalities. Who were these two brothers?
options: Peter and Andrew
James and John
Philip and Bartholomew
Matthew and Thomas
beginner.explanation: James and John, the sons of Zebedee, were given the Aramaic nickname 'Boanerges' meaning 'Sons of Thunder' by Jesus. They once even asked if they could call down fire from heaven on a Samaritan village that rejected Jesus.

beginner.question: During the Last Supper — the final meal Jesus shared with His disciples before His crucifixion — Jesus surprised everyone by performing an act of humble service that was normally done by the lowest servant in a household. What did Jesus do?
options: He cooked and served the entire meal Himself
He washed His disciples' feet
He gave away His outer cloak to each disciple
He swept and cleaned the upper room
beginner.explanation: Jesus wrapped a towel around His waist, poured water into a basin, and began washing His disciples' feet. He told them: 'I have set you an example that you should do as I have done for you.' It was a powerful lesson in servant leadership.

beginner.question: When Jesus was crucified, He was placed between two criminals who were also being executed. One criminal mocked Jesus, but the other defended Him and asked for mercy. What did this repentant criminal say to Jesus?
options: Please save us from this cross
Remember me when you come into your kingdom
I believe you are the Son of God
Forgive me, for I have sinned greatly
beginner.explanation: The repentant criminal rebuked the other, saying they deserved their punishment but Jesus had done nothing wrong. He then said 'Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.' Jesus replied, 'Truly I tell you, today you will be with me in paradise.'

beginner.question: In the town of Jericho, there was a chief tax collector who was very wealthy but also very short. He desperately wanted to see Jesus passing through, so he climbed a tree to get a view above the crowd. What was this man's name?
options: Matthew
Levi
Zacchaeus
Nicodemus
beginner.explanation: Zacchaeus climbed a sycamore-fig tree to see Jesus. When Jesus looked up and told him to come down because He wanted to visit his house, the crowd grumbled because Zacchaeus was a hated tax collector. But Zacchaeus repented and promised to give half his possessions to the poor.

beginner.question: One of Jesus' 12 apostles was a tax collector before Jesus called him to follow. Tax collectors in that time were despised by the Jewish people because they worked for the Roman Empire and often cheated people. Which apostle had this job?
options: Simon
Matthew
Judas
Bartholomew
beginner.explanation: Matthew (also called Levi) was sitting at his tax collector's booth when Jesus simply said 'Follow me.' Matthew got up, left everything, and followed Jesus. He later wrote the Gospel of Matthew.

beginner.question: One of the 12 apostles is known for betraying Jesus by handing Him over to the religious authorities who wanted to arrest Him. This apostle identified Jesus to the soldiers by greeting Him with a kiss. Who was this betrayer?
options: Peter
Thomas
Judas Iscariot
Simon the Zealot
beginner.explanation: Judas Iscariot agreed to betray Jesus for 30 pieces of silver. He led a crowd of soldiers and officials to the Garden of Gethsemane and identified Jesus with a kiss. Judas later regretted his actions and returned the money before taking his own life.

beginner.question: On the night Jesus was arrested, one of His closest disciples denied even knowing Him — not once, but three times, just as Jesus had predicted. After the third denial, a rooster crowed and this disciple wept bitterly. Who was it?
options: John
Andrew
Peter
James
beginner.explanation: Peter had boldly promised he would never deny Jesus, even if it meant dying with Him. But when questioned by servants and bystanders in the courtyard, Peter denied knowing Jesus three times. When the rooster crowed, Peter remembered Jesus' prediction and broke down weeping.

beginner.question: Before Jesus began His public ministry, He went to the Jordan River to be baptized. The prophet who baptized Him had been living in the wilderness, wearing clothes made of camel's hair and eating locusts and wild honey. Who was this prophet?
options: Elijah
Isaiah
John the Baptist
Zechariah
beginner.explanation: John the Baptist was the one chosen to prepare the way for Jesus' ministry. When Jesus came to be baptized, John initially protested, saying Jesus should be baptizing him instead. After the baptism, the heavens opened, the Spirit descended like a dove, and God's voice said 'This is my Son, whom I love.'

beginner.question: Right after Jesus was baptized, the Spirit led Him into the wilderness where He fasted and was tempted by the devil. How many days did Jesus spend in the wilderness being tested?
options: 7 days
21 days
40 days
70 days
beginner.explanation: Jesus fasted for 40 days and 40 nights in the wilderness. The devil tempted Him three times: to turn stones into bread, to throw Himself from the Temple, and to worship the devil in exchange for all the kingdoms of the world. Jesus resisted each temptation by quoting Scripture.

beginner.question: In one of Jesus' most famous miracles, a massive crowd of over 5,000 people had gathered to hear Him teach, and they had nothing to eat. A young boy offered his small lunch, and Jesus used it to feed the entire crowd. What did the boy's lunch consist of?
options: Three loaves of bread and two fish
Five loaves of bread and two fish
Seven loaves of bread and three fish
Two loaves of bread and five fish
beginner.explanation: The boy had five small barley loaves and two small fish. Jesus took them, gave thanks, and distributed them to the crowd. Everyone ate and was satisfied, and the disciples collected 12 baskets of leftovers.

beginner.question: The Roman governor of Judea held a trial for Jesus and offered the crowd a choice: he would release either Jesus or a convicted criminal. The crowd chose to release the criminal instead. Who was the Roman governor that sentenced Jesus to crucifixion?
options: Herod Antipas
Caesar Augustus
Pontius Pilate
Felix
beginner.explanation: Pontius Pilate was the Roman governor who presided over Jesus' trial. Despite finding no fault in Jesus and even having his wife warn him through a dream, Pilate gave in to the crowd's demands. He symbolically washed his hands before the crowd, saying he was innocent of Jesus' blood.

beginner.question: According to the Gospels, the very first miracle that Jesus ever performed took place at a wedding celebration in the town of Cana. The hosts had run out of a key drink, and Jesus' mother Mary asked Him to help. What did Jesus do?
options: He multiplied the food for the guests
He turned water into wine
He healed a sick guest at the wedding
He calmed a storm that threatened the celebration
beginner.explanation: When the wine ran out, Mary told the servants to do whatever Jesus said. Jesus told them to fill six stone water jars to the brim, then draw some out and take it to the master of the banquet. The water had been turned into wine — and the master said it was the best wine of the evening.

beginner.question: After Jesus ascended to heaven, His apostles needed to replace Judas Iscariot (who had betrayed Jesus and died) so that there would once again be 12 apostles. They prayed and cast lots to choose between two candidates. Who was chosen as the replacement?
options: Paul
Barnabas
Matthias
Stephen
beginner.explanation: The apostles nominated two men — Joseph called Barsabbas and Matthias. After prayer, they cast lots and the lot fell to Matthias, who was added to the eleven apostles. This happened before the day of Pentecost.

beginner.question: According to the Gospel of Luke, when the angel Gabriel appeared to a young virgin named Mary in the town of Nazareth and announced that she would give birth to the Son of God, what was Mary's response?
options: She ran away in fear
She immediately told Joseph
She said 'I am the Lord's servant; may it be as you have said'
She asked for time to think about it
beginner.explanation: Although Mary was initially troubled and wondered how this could happen since she was a virgin, she ultimately responded in faith, saying 'I am the Lord's servant. May your word to me be fulfilled.' She then visited her relative Elizabeth, who was also miraculously pregnant with John the Baptist.

beginner.question: In the Christmas story, after Jesus was born in Bethlehem, a group of visitors from the East followed a special star that led them to the child. These visitors brought expensive gifts to honour the newborn King. What three gifts did they bring?
options: Silver, silk, and spices
Gold, frankincense, and myrrh
Jewels, perfume, and fine linen
Gold, silver, and precious stones
beginner.explanation: The Magi (wise men) from the East brought three symbolic gifts: gold (representing royalty), frankincense (representing deity and worship), and myrrh (a burial spice, foreshadowing Jesus' death). They were warned in a dream not to return to King Herod, so they went home by a different route.

beginner.question: On the day Jesus entered Jerusalem for the last time before His crucifixion, crowds of people lined the streets, laid down palm branches and cloaks, and shouted praises. This event is now celebrated as Palm Sunday. What animal did Jesus ride into the city on?
options: A white horse
A camel
A donkey
A chariot pulled by oxen
beginner.explanation: Jesus rode into Jerusalem on a young donkey, fulfilling the prophecy in Zechariah 9:9 which said 'See, your king comes to you, righteous and victorious, lowly and riding on a donkey.' The crowds shouted 'Hosanna! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord!'

beginner.question: At the moment Jesus died on the cross, something dramatic happened inside the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem. A massive curtain that separated the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place (where only the high priest could enter once a year) was affected. What happened to it?
options: It caught fire
It was torn in two from top to bottom
It turned white
It collapsed to the ground
beginner.explanation: The Temple curtain was torn in two from top to bottom at the moment of Jesus' death. This symbolised that through Jesus' sacrifice, the barrier between God and people was removed — everyone could now have direct access to God, not just the high priest once a year.

beginner.question: On Easter Sunday morning, when some of Jesus' female followers went to His tomb to anoint His body with spices, they found that the large stone covering the entrance had been rolled away and the tomb was empty. According to the Gospel of John, who was the first person to see the risen Jesus?
options: Peter
John
Mary Magdalene
Jesus' mother Mary
beginner.explanation: Mary Magdalene was the first person to encounter the risen Jesus. She was weeping at the empty tomb when Jesus appeared to her. At first she thought He was the gardener, but when Jesus said her name 'Mary', she recognised Him immediately.

beginner.question: After rising from the dead, Jesus appeared to His disciples and others over a period of time before ascending to heaven. According to the book of Acts, how many days after His resurrection did Jesus ascend into heaven?
options: 3 days
7 days
40 days
50 days
beginner.explanation: Jesus appeared to His disciples and many others over a period of 40 days after His resurrection, teaching them about the kingdom of God. He then led them to the Mount of Olives near Bethany, blessed them, and was taken up into heaven before their eyes.

beginner.question: After Jesus' resurrection, He appeared to His disciples by the Sea of Galilee and had breakfast with them on the shore. During this meal, Jesus asked Peter the same question three times, giving Peter a chance to undo his earlier three denials. What did Jesus ask him?
options: 'Will you follow me to the end?'
'Do you love me?'
'Do you believe I am the Son of God?'
'Will you forgive yourself?'
beginner.explanation: Jesus asked Peter 'Do you love me?' three times — once for each time Peter had denied knowing Him. Each time Peter affirmed his love, Jesus gave him a commission: 'Feed my lambs,' 'Take care of my sheep,' and 'Feed my sheep.' This restored Peter and gave him the mission to lead the early church.

beginner.question: When Jesus taught His disciples how to pray, He gave them a model prayer that Christians have been reciting for thousands of years. This prayer begins with 'Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name.' What is this prayer commonly known as?
options: The Apostles' Prayer
The Lord's Prayer
The Disciples' Prayer
The Prayer of Faith
beginner.explanation: The Lord's Prayer, found in Matthew 6:9-13, is the prayer Jesus taught when His disciples asked Him to show them how to pray. It covers worship, God's will, daily provision, forgiveness, and protection from evil. It is the most widely recited prayer in Christianity.

beginner.question: In the book of Acts, a young deacon named Stephen became the first person to be killed for preaching about Jesus. He was put on trial before the Jewish council and was executed by an angry mob. How was Stephen killed?
options: He was beheaded
He was crucified
He was stoned to death
He was thrown from a cliff
beginner.explanation: Stephen was stoned to death after giving a powerful speech to the Sanhedrin (Jewish council). As he was being stoned, he looked up to heaven and said he could see Jesus standing at the right hand of God. His last words were 'Lord, do not hold this sin against them.' A young man named Saul (later Paul) watched and approved of his killing.

beginner.question: In one of Jesus' most beloved parables, a father had two sons. The younger son demanded his inheritance early, left home, wasted all his money on wild living, and ended up so poor he was feeding pigs. When he finally returned home, how did the father react?
options: He refused to speak to him
He ran to him, embraced him, and threw a feast to celebrate his return
He allowed him back but only as a hired servant
He told him to earn back his inheritance first
beginner.explanation: In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, the father saw his son coming from a long way off and was filled with compassion. He ran to his son, threw his arms around him, kissed him, and ordered the best robe, a ring, sandals, and a grand feast. This parable illustrates God's unconditional love and forgiveness.

beginner.question: One night, a respected Jewish religious leader secretly visited Jesus because he wanted to learn from Him but was afraid of what other leaders would think. Jesus told this man that no one can see the kingdom of God unless they are 'born again.' Who was this leader?
options: Joseph of Arimathea
Gamaliel
Nicodemus
Caiaphas
beginner.explanation: Nicodemus was a Pharisee and a member of the Jewish ruling council. He came to Jesus at night and Jesus told him 'No one can see the kingdom of God unless they are born again.' This conversation also contains the famous verse John 3:16. Nicodemus later helped bury Jesus after the crucifixion.

beginner.question: In the Gospel of John, Jesus met a Samaritan woman at a well outside the town of Sychar. This was shocking because Jewish men did not normally speak to Samaritan women. During their conversation, what did Jesus offer her?
options: A meal from His disciples' supplies
Living water that would quench her thirst forever
A healing miracle for her family
An invitation to join His followers
beginner.explanation: Jesus told the woman that whoever drinks the water from the well would be thirsty again, but whoever drinks the living water He gives would never thirst — it would become a spring of water welling up to eternal life. The woman was so amazed by Jesus that she went back to her town and told everyone about Him.

beginner.question: Jesus once encountered a man who had been unable to walk for 38 years. This man was lying by a pool in Jerusalem, hoping for healing. Jesus simply told him to stand up. What was the name of this pool?
options: The Pool of Siloam
The Pool of Bethesda
The Pool of Gethsemane
The Pool of Solomon
beginner.explanation: The Pool of Bethesda had five covered colonnades where many disabled people lay waiting. They believed an angel would stir the waters and the first person in would be healed. Jesus asked the man 'Do you want to get well?' and then told him 'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.' The man was instantly healed.

beginner.question: Before Jesus was born, an angel appeared to His earthly father Joseph in a dream and told him not to be afraid to take Mary as his wife, because her child was from the Holy Spirit. The angel also told Joseph what to name the baby. What name did the angel give?
options: Emmanuel
Jesus
Joshua
Messiah
beginner.explanation: The angel told Joseph: 'You are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.' The name Jesus (Yeshua in Hebrew) means 'the Lord saves.' Matthew also notes this fulfilled the prophecy about 'Emmanuel' meaning 'God with us.'

beginner.question: Just before Jesus ascended into heaven, He gave His disciples a final command that Christians call 'The Great Commission.' He told them to go into all the world and do something. What did Jesus command them to do?
options: Build churches in every city
Make disciples of all nations, baptizing and teaching them
Write down everything He had taught them
Wait in Jerusalem until the end times
beginner.explanation: Jesus said 'Go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age.'

intermediate.question: The apostle Paul wrote a letter to the church in Rome that became one of the most important books in the New Testament. In this letter, he makes a famous statement about the consequence of sin compared to God's gift. According to Romans 6:23, what are 'the wages of sin'?
options: Suffering
Separation from God
Death
Judgment
intermediate.explanation: Paul wrote 'For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.' This verse contrasts what sin earns (death) with what God freely gives (eternal life).

intermediate.question: On his first missionary journey described in the book of Acts, Paul did not travel alone. He was accompanied by a fellow believer from Cyprus who was known as an encourager and had previously introduced Paul to the suspicious apostles in Jerusalem. Who was this travelling companion?
options: Timothy
Silas
Barnabas
Luke
intermediate.explanation: Barnabas (whose name means 'Son of Encouragement') accompanied Paul on his first missionary journey. They travelled through Cyprus and parts of modern-day Turkey, preaching in synagogues and establishing churches. Barnabas had earlier vouched for Paul when the apostles in Jerusalem were afraid of him.

intermediate.question: Paul was a highly educated Jewish man who studied under one of the most respected rabbis of his time. Before Paul became a Christian, he was trained as a Pharisee in Jerusalem. Which famous rabbi was Paul's teacher?
options: Hillel
Shammai
Gamaliel
Nicodemus
intermediate.explanation: Paul studied under Gamaliel, one of the most honoured teachers of Jewish law. Gamaliel was so respected that he is the only rabbi referred to as 'Rabban' (our master). Interestingly, Gamaliel later advised the Jewish council to leave the Christians alone, saying 'if their purpose is from God, you will not be able to stop them.'

intermediate.question: In Paul's famous chapter on love in 1 Corinthians 13, he lists three things that will last forever and says one of them is the greatest. He writes that 'these three remain: faith, hope, and love.' According to Paul, which of the three is the greatest?
options: Faith
Hope
Love
They are all equal
intermediate.explanation: Paul wrote 'And now these three remain: faith, hope and love. But the greatest of these is love.' This chapter, often read at weddings, describes love as patient, kind, not envious, not boastful, and never failing.

intermediate.question: In the early church described in Acts chapter 5, a married couple sold a piece of property and secretly kept some of the money for themselves while pretending to give the full amount to the apostles. When confronted by Peter, both of them fell down dead. What were their names?
options: Aquila and Priscilla
Ananias and Sapphira
Andronicus and Junia
Philemon and Apphia
intermediate.explanation: Ananias brought the money and lied about it being the full amount. Peter said 'You have not lied just to human beings but to God,' and Ananias fell down dead. Three hours later, his wife Sapphira came in and told the same lie, and she also died. Great fear seized the whole church.

intermediate.question: The apostle Peter had a vision that radically changed how the early church understood God's plan for non-Jewish people (Gentiles). In this vision, a large sheet was lowered from heaven containing animals that Jewish law considered unclean. What did a voice tell Peter to do?
options: Release the animals into the wild
Count the animals and record them
Kill and eat the animals
Separate the clean from the unclean
intermediate.explanation: The voice told Peter 'Get up, kill and eat.' When Peter refused because the animals were 'unclean' under Jewish law, the voice said 'Do not call anything impure that God has made clean.' This vision prepared Peter to visit and baptize Cornelius, a Roman centurion — the first Gentile convert.

intermediate.question: In addition to being an apostle and writing much of the New Testament, Paul also had a regular trade that he used to support himself financially so he would not be a burden to the churches. What was Paul's profession?
options: Carpenter
Fisherman
Tentmaker
Scribe
intermediate.explanation: Paul was a tentmaker by trade. When he arrived in Corinth, he stayed and worked with Aquila and Priscilla, who were also tentmakers. Paul took pride in working with his hands and not being financially dependent on the churches he served.

intermediate.question: During one of Paul's missionary journeys, he and his companion Silas were beaten and thrown into prison in the city of Philippi. At midnight, while they were praying and singing hymns, something dramatic happened that freed them. What occurred?
options: An angel unlocked their chains
A violent earthquake shook the prison and all the doors flew open
The guards fell asleep and they escaped
The city magistrates sent orders for their release
intermediate.explanation: A violent earthquake shook the prison foundations, all the doors flew open, and everyone's chains came loose. The jailer was about to kill himself (thinking the prisoners had escaped), but Paul shouted that they were all still there. The jailer asked 'What must I do to be saved?' and Paul told him to believe in Jesus. The jailer and his whole household were baptized that night.

intermediate.question: In the book of Revelation, the risen Jesus dictated messages to seven specific churches in Asia Minor (modern-day Turkey). Each message contained praise, correction, or warning tailored to that church's situation. How many churches received these messages?
intermediate.explanation: Jesus addressed seven churches: Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea. Each letter followed a pattern of identifying Jesus, acknowledging the church's situation, offering praise or rebuke, and giving a promise to 'the one who overcomes.'

intermediate.question: Paul wrote a deeply personal letter to a Christian slave owner, asking him to forgive and welcome back a runaway slave who had become a Christian under Paul's teaching in prison. This is the shortest of Paul's letters. Who was the slave owner Paul wrote to?
options: Titus
Philemon
Timothy
Onesimus
intermediate.explanation: Paul wrote to Philemon, asking him to receive back his slave Onesimus — no longer as a slave, but as a 'dear brother in Christ.' Paul even offered to pay any debt Onesimus owed. This letter is a beautiful example of reconciliation and equality in Christ.

intermediate.question: In Paul's letter to the Galatians, he lists nine qualities that the Holy Spirit produces in the lives of believers. These are collectively known as the 'Fruit of the Spirit.' Which of the following is NOT one of the nine fruits Paul lists?
options: Patience
Courage
Gentleness
Self-control
intermediate.explanation: The nine fruits of the Spirit listed in Galatians 5:22-23 are: love, joy, peace, patience (forbearance), kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. Courage is not on the list, though it is certainly a Christian virtue mentioned elsewhere in Scripture.

intermediate.question: In the Sermon on the Mount, Jesus taught a series of blessings that begin with the word 'Blessed.' These statements, such as 'Blessed are the poor in spirit' and 'Blessed are the peacemakers,' are known by a special name. What are they called?
options: The Commandments
The Beatitudes
The Benedictions
The Proverbs of Jesus
intermediate.explanation: The Beatitudes (from the Latin 'beatus' meaning 'blessed' or 'happy') are eight (or nine) blessings that Jesus pronounced at the beginning of the Sermon on the Mount. They describe the character and values of those who belong to God's kingdom.

intermediate.question: In Acts chapter 15, the early church leaders met in Jerusalem to settle a major dispute about whether non-Jewish (Gentile) Christians needed to follow all the Jewish laws, including circumcision, to be saved. What is this important meeting commonly called?
options: The Last Supper
The Council of Jerusalem
The Synod of Antioch
The Great Debate
intermediate.explanation: The Council of Jerusalem was a pivotal moment in early Christianity. After much debate, the apostles and elders — led by James, Peter, and Paul — concluded that Gentile believers did not need to be circumcised or follow the full Mosaic law. They only asked them to avoid food sacrificed to idols, blood, strangled animals, and sexual immorality.

intermediate.question: During Paul's second missionary journey, he arrived in the intellectual city of Athens and found it full of idols. He was invited to speak at a famous hilltop gathering place where Athenian philosophers debated new ideas. What was this location called?
options: The Acropolis
The Areopagus (Mars Hill)
The Agora
The Parthenon
intermediate.explanation: Paul spoke at the Areopagus (also known as Mars Hill), where he gave a brilliant speech connecting with Greek culture. He referenced their altar 'To an Unknown God' and declared that this unknown God was the true Creator who 'is not far from any one of us.' Some believed, including Dionysius the Areopagite.

intermediate.question: Near the end of Paul's missionary travels, he was on a ship sailing to Rome to stand trial before Caesar. The ship encountered a terrible storm that lasted 14 days. After the shipwreck, Paul and all 276 people on board swam safely to an island. Which island did they land on?
options: Cyprus
Crete
Malta
Sicily
intermediate.explanation: After being battered by the storm for two weeks, the ship ran aground near the island of Malta. All 276 passengers survived, just as Paul had promised them after receiving a message from an angel. The islanders showed unusual kindness and welcomed the survivors.

intermediate.question: After arriving safely on the island of Malta following his shipwreck, Paul was gathering wood for a fire when a venomous snake came out of the bundle and fastened itself on his hand. The islanders expected him to swell up and die. What actually happened to Paul?
options: He became very ill for several days
He suffered no harm at all
Luke the physician treated the bite
He prayed and the venom was neutralised
intermediate.explanation: Paul simply shook the snake off into the fire and suffered no ill effects. The islanders watched him for a long time, expecting him to swell up or suddenly fall dead. When nothing happened, they changed their minds and said he must be a god.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, a woman named Lydia became one of the first converts to Christianity in Europe. Paul met her by a river outside the city of Philippi, where she had gone to pray. What was Lydia's occupation?
options: A potter
A dealer in purple cloth
A seamstress
A merchant of spices
intermediate.explanation: Lydia was a dealer in purple cloth from the city of Thyatira. Purple dye was extremely expensive, so she was likely a wealthy businesswoman. After hearing Paul speak, 'the Lord opened her heart' and she and her entire household were baptized. She then insisted Paul and his companions stay at her home.

intermediate.question: Jesus told a parable about a master who gave three servants different amounts of money (called 'talents') before going on a journey. Two servants invested and doubled their money, but the third servant buried his in the ground. What happened when the master returned?
options: He forgave all three servants equally
He praised the two who invested and punished the one who buried his talent
He took all the money back from everyone
He gave the third servant another chance
intermediate.explanation: The master praised the two faithful servants, saying 'Well done, good and faithful servant! You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things.' But he called the third servant 'wicked and lazy' and took his talent away. This parable teaches about using the gifts God gives us.

intermediate.question: When a teacher of the law asked Jesus which commandment was the greatest, Jesus did not pick just one — He gave two commandments and said all of Scripture hangs on them. The first was to love God with all your heart, soul, and mind. What was the second?
options: Keep the Sabbath holy
Honour your father and mother
Love your neighbour as yourself
Do not worship any other gods
intermediate.explanation: Jesus said the second greatest commandment is 'Love your neighbour as yourself,' quoting Leviticus 19:18. He told the teacher that all the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments — loving God completely and loving your neighbour as yourself.

intermediate.question: In Paul's letter to the Ephesians, he describes the spiritual protection God provides to believers using the metaphor of a Roman soldier's equipment. This passage is known as the 'Armour of God.' Which of the following is NOT one of the pieces Paul mentions?
options: The belt of truth
The helmet of salvation
The shield of faith
The spear of righteousness
intermediate.explanation: Paul lists the belt of truth, breastplate of righteousness, shoes of the gospel of peace, shield of faith, helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit (the Word of God). There is no 'spear of righteousness' — the only offensive weapon mentioned is the sword of the Spirit.

intermediate.question: Three of Jesus' disciples — Peter, James, and John — witnessed a miraculous event where Jesus' appearance was transformed on top of a mountain. His face shone like the sun and His clothes became dazzlingly white, and two Old Testament figures appeared beside Him. What is this event called?
options: The Ascension
The Transfiguration
The Glorification
The Revelation
intermediate.explanation: During the Transfiguration, Moses and Elijah appeared and talked with Jesus. Peter offered to build three shelters for them. Then a bright cloud covered them and God's voice said 'This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him!' The disciples fell facedown in terror.

intermediate.question: Paul wrote two letters to the church in the city of Corinth, a wealthy Greek port city known for its immorality. In his first letter, he scolded them for divisions within the church — different groups were claiming to follow different leaders. What was the main problem Paul addressed?
options: They were worshipping Greek gods alongside Jesus
They were dividing into factions saying 'I follow Paul' or 'I follow Apollos'
They refused to meet together for worship
They were rejecting Paul's authority completely
intermediate.explanation: Some Corinthians were saying 'I follow Paul,' others 'I follow Apollos,' others 'I follow Cephas (Peter),' and others 'I follow Christ.' Paul rebuked this, asking 'Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you?' He reminded them they were all one body in Christ.

intermediate.question: The book of James is a practical letter about living out your faith through actions, not just words. James uses a vivid metaphor to describe the tongue, saying it is a small part of the body but has enormous power. What does James compare the tongue to?
options: A sharp sword that cuts both ways
A small spark that can set a great forest on fire
A poisonous snake hiding in the grass
A rudder that steers a great ship
intermediate.explanation: James actually uses multiple metaphors — he compares the tongue to a bit in a horse's mouth, a rudder on a ship, AND a small spark that sets a forest ablaze. But his main point is that the tongue, though small, can cause enormous destruction through careless or harmful words.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, a couple named Aquila and Priscilla (or Prisca) were close friends and co-workers with Paul. When they met an eloquent preacher named Apollos who only knew part of the Christian message, what did they do?
options: They reported him to the apostles for teaching errors
They took him aside privately and explained the full truth more accurately
They asked him to stop preaching until he was properly trained
They wrote him a letter of correction
intermediate.explanation: Apollos was a learned man who spoke with great fervour and taught accurately about Jesus, but he only knew about John's baptism. Rather than embarrassing him publicly, Aquila and Priscilla invited him to their home and explained 'the way of God more adequately.' Apollos then became an even more powerful preacher.

intermediate.question: Paul mentions a personal physical struggle in his second letter to the Corinthians, calling it a 'thorn in my flesh.' He says he prayed three times for God to remove it, but God responded with a famous statement. What did God say to Paul?
options: 'Be patient, and I will heal you in time'
'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness'
'This suffering will strengthen your faith'
'Remove it yourself through prayer and fasting'
intermediate.explanation: God told Paul 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.' Paul then said he would boast gladly about his weaknesses, so that Christ's power could rest on him. Scholars have debated for centuries what the 'thorn' was — possibilities include a physical ailment, persecution, or a spiritual struggle.

intermediate.question: The book of Hebrews describes an Old Testament figure named Melchizedek, who was both a king and a priest, and who blessed Abraham after a battle. Hebrews argues that Jesus is a priest forever 'in the order of Melchizedek.' What was Melchizedek the king of?
options: Babylon
Egypt
Salem (later Jerusalem)
Ur
intermediate.explanation: Melchizedek was 'king of Salem' (an ancient name for Jerusalem) and 'priest of God Most High.' The book of Hebrews uses him to argue that Jesus' priesthood is superior to the Levitical priesthood, since Melchizedek's priesthood predated and outranked it. His name means 'king of righteousness.'

intermediate.question: In Jesus' parable of the sower, a farmer scatters seed on four different types of ground. The seed represents the Word of God, and the soils represent different responses people have to hearing it. According to Jesus, what happened to the seed that fell on the path?
options: It grew quickly but withered in the sun
Birds came and ate it up
Thorns choked it out
It produced a huge harvest
intermediate.explanation: Jesus explained that the seed on the path represents people who hear the message but don't understand it, and the evil one comes and snatches away what was sown. The rocky ground represents shallow faith, the thorns represent worldly worries, and the good soil represents those who hear, understand, and produce fruit.

intermediate.question: In the early church, there was a generous believer from Cyprus whose real name was Joseph, but the apostles gave him a nickname that means 'Son of Encouragement.' He later became Paul's travelling partner on the first missionary journey. What was his nickname?
options: Barnabas
Apollos
Silas
Titus
intermediate.explanation: Barnabas (meaning 'Son of Encouragement') sold a field he owned and brought the money to the apostles. He was the one who believed in Paul's conversion when others were still suspicious, and he travelled with Paul on the first missionary journey through Cyprus and Asia Minor.

intermediate.question: Paul had a young protege whom he called 'my true son in the faith.' This young man's mother was Jewish and his grandmother Lois was known for her sincere faith. Paul wrote two letters to him that are now books of the Bible. Who was this young man?
options: Titus
Timothy
Philemon
Mark
intermediate.explanation: Timothy was Paul's closest and most trusted co-worker. His mother Eunice and grandmother Lois had taught him the Scriptures from infancy. Paul recruited Timothy during his second missionary journey and later wrote two pastoral letters to him with instructions for leading the church in Ephesus.

intermediate.question: In the Gospel of Luke, Jesus told a parable about a man who was owed money by two people — one owed a large amount and the other a small amount. The moneylender cancelled both debts. Jesus then asked His host Simon which debtor would love the moneylender more. Why did Jesus tell this parable?
options: To teach about financial responsibility
To explain why a sinful woman who washed His feet with tears showed greater love than Simon
To warn about lending money to strangers
To teach about the dangers of debt
intermediate.explanation: A woman known in the city as a sinner came to Simon the Pharisee's house, wept at Jesus' feet, wiped them with her hair, and anointed them with perfume. Simon judged her silently. Jesus told the parable to show that the woman loved greatly because she had been forgiven much, while Simon showed little love because he thought he needed little forgiveness.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, a devout woman named Tabitha (also called Dorcas) was known for her kindness and charity, especially making clothes for widows. When she died, the believers sent for Peter. What did Peter do when he arrived?
options: He comforted the mourners and led a funeral prayer
He sent everyone out of the room, prayed, and raised her from the dead
He collected her clothing and distributed it to the poor
He preached a sermon about the hope of resurrection
intermediate.explanation: Peter sent everyone out of the room, knelt down and prayed, then turned to the dead woman and said 'Tabitha, get up.' She opened her eyes, saw Peter, and sat up. This miracle became known throughout Joppa, and many people believed in the Lord because of it.

intermediate.question: The author of the Gospel of Luke and the book of Acts was a physician who travelled with Paul on several of his missionary journeys. He is the only non-Jewish (Gentile) author in the New Testament. What was his name?
options: Mark
Luke
Matthew
Theophilus
intermediate.explanation: Luke was a physician and close companion of Paul, who called him 'our dear friend Luke, the doctor' in Colossians 4:14. Luke wrote both his Gospel and the book of Acts to a man named Theophilus. He is known for his detailed, orderly accounts and his emphasis on Jesus' compassion for the marginalised.

intermediate.question: In the parable of the ten virgins (bridesmaids), Jesus described ten young women waiting for a bridegroom to arrive for a wedding feast. Five were wise and five were foolish. What was the difference between the wise and foolish virgins?
options: The wise brought food and the foolish did not
The wise brought extra oil for their lamps and the foolish did not
The wise arrived early and the foolish came late
The wise wore proper wedding garments and the foolish did not
intermediate.explanation: The five wise virgins brought extra oil for their lamps, while the five foolish ones did not. When the bridegroom was delayed and arrived at midnight, the foolish virgins' lamps were going out and they had to go buy more oil. While they were gone, the bridegroom arrived and the door was shut. Jesus used this to teach about being ready for His return.

intermediate.question: Paul was originally from a city in Cilicia (modern-day Turkey) that was known as a major centre of learning and commerce in the Roman Empire. Paul sometimes referenced his citizenship of this city. What city was Paul from?
options: Antioch
Ephesus
Tarsus
Corinth
intermediate.explanation: Paul was born in Tarsus, the capital city of the Roman province of Cilicia. It was a prosperous university city. Paul held both Tarsian citizenship and Roman citizenship — the latter being a rare privilege that he used on several occasions to assert his legal rights when facing persecution.

intermediate.question: In the Gospel of John, Jesus performed a miracle by raising a man from the dead who had been in the tomb for four days. This miracle took place in the village of Bethany, and Jesus wept when He saw the man's sisters grieving. Who was the man Jesus raised?
options: Jairus' daughter
The widow's son at Nain
Lazarus
Eutychus
intermediate.explanation: Lazarus was the brother of Mary and Martha, close friends of Jesus. When Jesus arrived in Bethany, Lazarus had been dead for four days. Jesus wept at the tomb, then commanded 'Lazarus, come out!' and the dead man walked out, still wrapped in burial cloth. This miracle led many to believe in Jesus but also accelerated the plot to kill Him.

advanced.question: In the book of Revelation, four mysterious horsemen ride out when the first four of seven seals are opened. Each rider represents a different force of destruction. What colour is the horse ridden by the first horseman, who is often interpreted as representing conquest?
options: Red
Black
White
Pale green
advanced.explanation: The first horseman rides a white horse, carrying a bow and wearing a crown, riding out 'bent on conquest.' The second rides a red horse (war), the third a black horse (famine), and the fourth a pale horse (death). These Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are among the most well-known images in Revelation.

advanced.question: In Philippians chapter 2, Paul quotes what many scholars believe is an early Christian hymn about Jesus emptying Himself and taking on human form. This theological concept of Christ 'emptying Himself' is known by a specific Greek term. What is it called?
options: Theosis
Kenosis
Koinonia
Metanoia
advanced.explanation: The 'Kenosis' passage (Philippians 2:5-11) comes from the Greek word 'kenoo' meaning 'to empty.' Paul writes that Christ Jesus, 'being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be used to his own advantage; rather, he made himself nothing (emptied himself) by taking the very nature of a servant.'

advanced.question: The Gospel of John begins with a profound theological prologue: 'In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.' The Greek term translated 'Word' carries deep philosophical meaning in both Jewish and Greek thought. What is this Greek word?
options: Pneuma
Logos
Theos
Christos
advanced.explanation: The Greek word 'Logos' means 'word,' 'reason,' or 'principle.' In Greek philosophy, the Logos was the rational principle governing the universe. In Jewish thought, God's Word was His creative power. John brilliantly uses this concept to declare that Jesus IS the Logos — the divine creative Word made flesh.

advanced.question: Paul's letter to the Romans contains a detailed argument about salvation. In Romans chapter 9, Paul discusses God's sovereignty using the example of two brothers — one whom God chose and one He rejected — even before they were born or had done anything good or bad. Which two brothers does Paul reference?
options: Cain and Abel
Isaac and Ishmael
Jacob and Esau
Moses and Aaron
advanced.explanation: Paul quotes God's statement about Rebekah's twin sons: 'Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated' (from Malachi 1:2-3). Paul uses this to argue that God's purposes in election stand firm, not based on works but on the One who calls. This passage has been central to theological debates about predestination.

advanced.question: In his letter to the Colossians, Paul warns against a false teaching that combined elements of Jewish legalism, Greek philosophy, and angel worship. He writes that believers have 'died with Christ to the elemental spiritual forces of this world.' What Greek term does Paul use for these 'elemental forces'?
options: Stoicheia
Dynamis
Archon
Exousia
advanced.explanation: Paul uses the word 'stoicheia' (elemental principles/forces) to describe the basic spiritual forces or principles that once held the Colossians in bondage. Scholars debate whether Paul meant cosmic spiritual powers, basic religious principles, or elementary teachings. Either way, Paul declares Christ's supremacy over all such forces.

advanced.question: In the Gospel of John, Jesus makes seven distinct 'I am' statements that each reveal something about His divine nature and mission. Which of the following is NOT one of Jesus' seven 'I am' statements in John's Gospel?
options: I am the bread of life
I am the vine
I am the cornerstone
I am the resurrection and the life
advanced.explanation: The seven 'I am' statements in John are: I am the bread of life (6:35), the light of the world (8:12), the gate/door (10:9), the good shepherd (10:11), the resurrection and the life (11:25), the way, truth, and life (14:6), and the true vine (15:1). While Jesus is called a cornerstone elsewhere (Ephesians 2:20), He never uses that as an 'I am' statement in John.

advanced.question: The book of Hebrews contains a famous 'Hall of Faith' chapter that lists Old Testament heroes who lived by faith. The chapter begins with a definition of faith that has become one of the most quoted verses about what faith actually is. How does Hebrews 11:1 define faith?
options: Faith is trusting God even when life is difficult
Faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see
Faith is believing what the Scriptures teach about God
Faith is the decision to follow God regardless of the cost
advanced.explanation: Hebrews 11:1 states: 'Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see.' This definition sets the stage for the examples that follow — Abel, Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Sarah, Moses, Rahab, and many others who trusted God's promises without seeing their fulfilment.

advanced.question: In Revelation, John describes a vision of a 'new heaven and new earth' at the end of time. In this vision, a voice from the throne declares that God will dwell with His people and wipe away every tear. What specific thing does John say will NOT be found in the new creation?
options: Angels
The sun and moon
A temple
Mountains and seas
advanced.explanation: John writes 'I did not see a temple in the city, because the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple.' There is also no need for sun or moon because God's glory provides light. This represents the ultimate fulfilment of God dwelling directly with His people — no barrier, no mediating structure needed.

advanced.question: Paul wrote to the Thessalonians about the 'Day of the Lord,' describing events surrounding Christ's return. He mentions a figure he calls 'the man of lawlessness' who will oppose God and even seat himself in God's temple, proclaiming himself to be God. What must happen before this figure is revealed?
options: A great earthquake must strike Jerusalem
A great falling away (apostasy) must occur first
The gospel must be preached to every nation
The Temple in Jerusalem must be rebuilt
advanced.explanation: Paul told the Thessalonians 'that day will not come until the rebellion (apostasia) occurs and the man of lawlessness is revealed.' He also mentions a 'restrainer' who is currently holding back this lawlessness until the appointed time. This passage has generated extensive debate about end-times theology.

advanced.question: In the Gospel of Mark, Jesus tells His disciples about a sin that will never be forgiven — what He calls an 'eternal sin.' This statement came after the Pharisees accused Jesus of casting out demons by the power of Satan. What is this unforgivable sin commonly called?
options: Denying the resurrection
Blasphemy against the Holy Spirit
Taking the Lord's name in vain
Worshipping false gods
advanced.explanation: Jesus said 'Whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven; they are guilty of an eternal sin.' He said this because the Pharisees were attributing the work of the Holy Spirit (casting out demons) to Satan. Theologians generally interpret this as a deliberate, persistent rejection of the Holy Spirit's testimony about Christ.

advanced.question: The letter to the Hebrews makes a complex argument comparing Jesus to the Old Testament priesthood. It argues that Jesus is a superior high priest because His priesthood belongs to a different order than the Levitical priests. In what way is Jesus' priestly ministry superior?
options: He offered many sacrifices instead of just one
He offered Himself as a perfect, once-for-all sacrifice
He served in a more beautiful temple
He was appointed by the people rather than by birth
advanced.explanation: Unlike the Levitical priests who had to repeatedly offer animal sacrifices, Jesus offered Himself as the perfect, sinless sacrifice once for all. Hebrews argues that Jesus' single sacrifice accomplished what countless animal sacrifices never could — permanently removing the barrier of sin between God and humanity.

advanced.question: In Paul's letter to the Romans, he introduces the concept of justification by faith using the example of Abraham, arguing that Abraham was declared righteous by God because of his faith, not because of his works. Paul quotes Genesis to make this point. What did Abraham believe that was 'credited to him as righteousness'?
options: That God would deliver him from his enemies
That God's promise about his descendants would come true, even though he was old
That he would inherit the land of Canaan
That God would make him wealthy and powerful
advanced.explanation: Paul quotes Genesis 15:6: 'Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.' Abraham believed God's promise that his descendants would be as numerous as the stars, even though he and Sarah were far too old to have children. Paul uses this to argue that people are made right with God through faith, not by following the law.

advanced.question: In the book of Revelation, John sees a vision of 144,000 people who are 'sealed' by God. These individuals are described as coming from the tribes of Israel. However, one of the original twelve tribes is missing from the list and is replaced by another. Which tribe is notably absent?
options: Benjamin
Dan
Judah
Levi
advanced.explanation: The tribe of Dan is missing from the list in Revelation 7:4-8. The tribe of Manasseh (one of Joseph's sons) is listed separately instead. Scholars have debated why Dan is excluded — some early church writers suggested it was because the Antichrist would come from Dan (based on Genesis 49:17), though this is speculative.

advanced.question: In John chapter 21, after the risen Jesus helped the disciples catch a miraculous haul of fish, the Gospel records the exact number of fish caught. This specific number has puzzled scholars for centuries, with many proposing symbolic interpretations. How many fish were caught?
advanced.explanation: The disciples caught exactly 153 large fish. Various interpretations have been suggested: Jerome said ancient zoologists catalogued 153 species of fish (symbolising all nations), Augustine noted that 153 is the sum of all numbers from 1 to 17, and others see gematria (number values of letters). The net held together despite the enormous catch.

advanced.question: Paul describes a profound mystery in his letter to the Ephesians — something that had been hidden for ages but was now revealed through Christ. This 'mystery' was central to Paul's understanding of the gospel and his mission. What was this mystery?
options: That Jesus would return a second time
That Gentiles are fellow heirs with Jews, united in one body through Christ
That the Temple would be destroyed
That the law of Moses would be replaced by a new law
advanced.explanation: Paul writes that 'this mystery is that through the gospel the Gentiles are heirs together with Israel, members together of one body, and sharers together in the promise in Christ Jesus.' This was revolutionary — that God's salvation plan included all peoples, not just the Jewish nation, united as equals in Christ.

advanced.question: The word 'Maranatha' appears at the end of Paul's first letter to the Corinthians and is one of the few Aramaic words preserved in the Greek New Testament. It reveals what the earliest Christians were eagerly praying for. What does 'Maranatha' mean?
options: Grace be with you
Our Lord, come!
Peace be upon you
God is great
advanced.explanation: 'Maranatha' is Aramaic and can be translated as 'Our Lord, come!' (Marana tha) or 'Our Lord has come' (Maran atha). Most scholars prefer 'Come, Lord!' — expressing the early church's longing for Christ's return. The fact that it was preserved in Aramaic even in Greek-speaking churches shows how ancient and important this prayer was.

advanced.question: Both the Gospel of Luke and the book of Acts are addressed to the same person. Luke tells this man that he investigated everything carefully so he could write an orderly account. Who was this recipient, whose name means 'friend of God' or 'loved by God'?
options: Theophilus
Timothy
Titus
Tertullus
advanced.explanation: Both Luke's Gospel (Luke 1:3) and Acts (Acts 1:1) are addressed to 'most excellent Theophilus.' Whether Theophilus was a real person (possibly a Roman official or patron) or a symbolic name meaning 'friend of God' (addressed to all God-loving readers) has been debated by scholars for centuries.

advanced.question: In the letter of Jude (one of the shortest books in the New Testament), the author references a dispute between the archangel Michael and the devil over the body of Moses. This story is not found in the Old Testament. From which ancient Jewish text does Jude appear to draw this account?
options: The Book of Enoch
The Assumption of Moses
The Testament of the Twelve Patriarchs
The Wisdom of Solomon
advanced.explanation: Jude appears to reference the 'Assumption of Moses' (also called the 'Testament of Moses'), an ancient Jewish text. In this account, Michael and Satan argued over Moses' body after his death. Michael did not dare pronounce a slanderous judgment against the devil but said 'The Lord rebuke you!' Jude also quotes from 1 Enoch in the same letter.

advanced.question: In 1 Corinthians 15, Paul presents the earliest known creed of Christian faith, listing the people Jesus appeared to after His resurrection. Paul says this tradition was 'passed on' to him. According to this creed, after appearing to the apostles, Jesus appeared to a large group all at once. How many people saw Him at one time?
options: More than 500
advanced.explanation: Paul writes that Jesus 'appeared to more than five hundred of the brothers and sisters at the same time, most of whom are still living' — meaning people could still verify the claim when Paul wrote. This creed (1 Corinthians 15:3-8) is considered by scholars to date to within just a few years of Jesus' crucifixion.

advanced.question: In the book of Acts, a young man named Eutychus was sitting in a window listening to Paul preach late into the night. Something happened to him that required a miraculous intervention from Paul. What happened?
options: He was struck blind by a vision
He fell asleep, fell from a third-story window, and died
He was seized by an evil spirit
He collapsed from fasting too long
advanced.explanation: Paul was preaching in Troas and kept talking until midnight. A young man named Eutychus, sitting in a window, sank into a deep sleep and fell from the third floor, and was picked up dead. Paul went down, threw himself on the young man, and embraced him, saying 'Don't be alarmed. He's alive!' Paul then went back upstairs and kept preaching until dawn.

advanced.question: In the letter to the Galatians, Paul publicly confronted the apostle Peter (Cephas) in the city of Antioch. Paul accused Peter of hypocrisy for a specific behaviour. What had Peter done that prompted Paul's confrontation?
options: Peter had denied knowing Christ again
Peter was eating with Gentiles but withdrew when Jewish Christians arrived, fearing their disapproval
Peter had rejected Paul's authority as an apostle
Peter had returned to collecting taxes
advanced.explanation: Peter had been eating freely with Gentile believers in Antioch, but when certain men from James arrived in Jerusalem, Peter pulled away and separated himself, 'because he was afraid of those who belonged to the circumcision group.' Paul opposed him to his face because Peter's hypocrisy was leading others astray, including even Barnabas.

advanced.question: The letter of James and Paul's letter to the Romans appear to contradict each other on the relationship between faith and works. Paul writes 'a person is justified by faith apart from works of the law,' while James writes that 'a person is considered righteous by what they do and not by faith alone.' How do theologians typically reconcile these two statements?
options: James was correcting Paul's errors
Paul is talking about how a person is initially saved, while James is talking about how genuine faith shows itself through actions
They are genuinely contradictory and cannot be reconciled
Paul was writing to Jews and James to Gentiles, so different rules apply
advanced.explanation: Most theologians see Paul and James addressing different questions. Paul argues against the idea that keeping the Jewish law can earn salvation — faith in Christ alone saves. James argues against a dead, inactive faith that claims to believe but produces no change in behaviour. Both agree that genuine saving faith will naturally produce good works.

advanced.question: In the book of Revelation, John receives a vision of seven golden lampstands and is told what they represent. He also sees seven stars in the right hand of a figure 'like a son of man.' According to Revelation chapter 1, what do the seven lampstands and seven stars represent?
options: The seven days of creation and the seven archangels
The seven churches and their angels (or messengers)
The seven seals and the seven trumpets
The seven continents and the seven spirits of God
advanced.explanation: Jesus explains the symbolism directly: 'The seven stars are the angels of the seven churches, and the seven lampstands are the seven churches' — Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea. The word 'angel' (angelos) can also mean 'messenger,' possibly referring to the pastor or leader of each church.

advanced.question: In the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus curses a fig tree on His way to Jerusalem, and it withers immediately. This event, which seems unusual for Jesus, occurred the day after He cleansed the Temple. What do most scholars believe the fig tree symbolised?
options: The Roman Empire and its coming destruction
Israel's spiritual fruitlessness despite its outward religious appearance
The futility of relying on earthly sustenance
The end of the agricultural age
advanced.explanation: Most scholars interpret the cursing of the fig tree as an enacted parable about Israel. The tree had leaves (outward appearance of religion) but no fruit (genuine spiritual life). Coming alongside the Temple cleansing, it represented Jesus' judgment on Israel's religious establishment, which had the appearance of devotion but lacked true faithfulness.

advanced.question: In John chapters 14-16, Jesus teaches extensively about the Holy Spirit during His farewell discourse with the disciples. Jesus uses a specific Greek title for the Spirit that is variously translated as 'Counsellor,' 'Advocate,' 'Helper,' or 'Comforter.' What is this Greek word?
options: Pneuma
Parakletos
Sophia
Dunamis
advanced.explanation: 'Parakletos' literally means 'one called alongside' — someone who advocates, comforts, and helps. Jesus promised the Father would send 'another Parakletos' to be with the disciples forever, teach them all things, remind them of Jesus' words, convict the world of sin, and guide them into all truth.

advanced.question: Paul's letter to Philemon is often cited in discussions about slavery in the ancient world. Paul sends back the runaway slave Onesimus with a remarkable request — he asks Philemon to receive Onesimus back not as a slave, but in a new way. How does Paul ask Philemon to treat Onesimus?
options: As a hired servant with wages
As a dear brother in Christ
As a freed man with no obligations
As a business partner in Paul's ministry
advanced.explanation: Paul writes: 'Perhaps the reason he was separated from you for a little while was that you might have him back forever — no longer as a slave, but better than a slave, as a dear brother.' Paul subtly undermines the institution of slavery by declaring master and slave to be brothers in Christ — equal before God.

advanced.question: In 2 Peter chapter 3, Peter addresses those who mock the idea that Jesus will return, asking 'Where is this coming he promised?' Peter gives a specific reason for the apparent delay of Christ's return. According to Peter, why has the Lord not yet returned?
options: Because certain prophecies must still be fulfilled
Because the Lord is patient, not wanting anyone to perish, but everyone to come to repentance
Because the angels are not yet ready for the final battle
Because the church has not yet reached every nation
advanced.explanation: Peter writes: 'The Lord is not slow in keeping his promise, as some understand slowness. Instead he is patient with you, not wanting anyone to perish, but everyone to come to repentance.' Peter also reminds readers that 'with the Lord a day is like a thousand years, and a thousand years are like a day.'

advanced.question: In the Gospel of John, when Pilate asked Jesus 'What is truth?' during His trial, Jesus did not answer. But earlier in John's Gospel, Jesus had already answered this very question in a famous statement to His disciples. What had Jesus said?
options: 'The truth will set you free'
'I am the way, the truth, and the life'
'You will know the truth by its fruits'
'The Spirit of truth will guide you'
advanced.explanation: In John 14:6, Jesus declared 'I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.' This is one of the most definitive claims Jesus made about His identity — He did not merely teach truth, He claimed to BE the truth. Pilate's question in John 18:38 echoes ironically because Truth was standing right in front of him.

advanced.question: The book of Revelation describes a final battle where the forces of evil gather against God. The armies of the world are assembled at a specific location for this ultimate confrontation. By what name is this famous battle site known?
options: Gehenna
Armageddon
Megiddo
The Valley of Jehoshaphat
advanced.explanation: Revelation 16:16 says the spirits of demons gathered the kings of the world 'to the place that in Hebrew is called Armageddon.' The name likely derives from 'Har Megiddo' (Mount Megiddo), an ancient battlefield site in northern Israel where many historic battles took place. The term has become synonymous with apocalyptic final conflict.

advanced.question: In Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, he addresses the issue of spiritual gifts and uses the metaphor of a human body to explain how the church should function. According to Paul, what is the key lesson of this body metaphor?
options: The head (pastor) is more important than the other parts
Every part of the body is needed, and the weaker parts are actually indispensable
The body should strive to become one uniform part
Some gifts are clearly superior to others
advanced.explanation: Paul argues that every member of the church is essential, just as every part of a body is needed. He writes 'those parts of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable' and 'God has put the body together, giving greater honour to the parts that lacked it.' No one can say 'I don't need you' to another believer.

beginner.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus was born in the city of Nazareth, which is why He was called 'Jesus of Nazareth.'
beginner.explanation: Jesus was born in Bethlehem, not Nazareth. He grew up in Nazareth, which is why He was called 'Jesus of Nazareth,' but His birth took place in Bethlehem, the city of David, fulfilling the prophecy in Micah 5:2.

beginner.question: In the New Testament, Jesus chose exactly 12 men to be His closest followers, and these men are known as the apostles.
beginner.explanation: Jesus appointed twelve apostles to be His closest companions and to carry on His mission. Their names are listed in Matthew 10:2-4: Simon Peter, Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot.

beginner.question: The New Testament contains a total of four Gospels — Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John — each telling the story of Jesus' life, death, and resurrection from a different perspective.
beginner.explanation: The four Gospels are Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. The first three (Matthew, Mark, Luke) are called the 'Synoptic Gospels' because they share a similar perspective, while John's Gospel takes a more theological approach and includes many events and teachings not found in the other three.

beginner.question: According to the Gospel of Matthew, when Jesus was born, a group of shepherds followed a star from the East to find Him and bring Him gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh.
beginner.explanation: It was the Magi (wise men), not shepherds, who followed the star and brought gifts. The shepherds were visited by angels in the fields near Bethlehem and went to see the baby Jesus in the manger. The Magi came from the East, possibly arriving much later when Jesus was in a house.

beginner.question: The apostle Paul wrote more books of the New Testament than any other single author. He is credited with writing 13 of the 27 books.
beginner.explanation: Paul is traditionally credited with writing 13 New Testament letters: Romans, 1 & 2 Corinthians, Galatians, Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, 1 & 2 Thessalonians, 1 & 2 Timothy, Titus, and Philemon. Some scholars debate the authorship of a few, but tradition attributes all 13 to Paul.

beginner.question: In the Gospel of John, Jesus raised His friend Lazarus from the dead after Lazarus had been in the tomb for four days. The Bible says that Jesus wept when He saw the mourners grieving.
beginner.explanation: 'Jesus wept' (John 11:35) is the shortest verse in the Bible. Despite knowing He was about to raise Lazarus, Jesus was deeply moved by the grief of Mary, Martha, and the other mourners. He then commanded 'Lazarus, come out!' and the dead man walked out of the tomb.

beginner.question: According to the book of Acts, the apostle Peter was the one who preached the sermon on the Day of Pentecost when about 3,000 people believed and were baptized.
beginner.explanation: After the Holy Spirit came upon the disciples at Pentecost, Peter stood up and preached a powerful sermon explaining that Jesus was the Messiah, crucified and risen from the dead. About 3,000 people accepted his message and were baptized that day, forming the foundation of the early church.

beginner.question: The shortest verse in the English Bible is 'Jesus wept,' which appears in the Gospel of John when Jesus arrived at the tomb of His friend Lazarus.
beginner.explanation: John 11:35, 'Jesus wept,' is the shortest verse in most English translations of the Bible. It shows the humanity of Jesus — even though He knew He was about to raise Lazarus from the dead, He was deeply moved by the sorrow and grief of those around Him.

beginner.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus was crucified on a Friday and rose from the dead on the following Monday, which is why Christians celebrate Easter on Monday.
beginner.explanation: Jesus was crucified on a Friday (Good Friday) and rose from the dead on the third day, which was Sunday — not Monday. Christians celebrate Easter on Sunday because that is the day the women found the empty tomb and the risen Jesus appeared to His followers.

beginner.question: The book of Revelation, the last book of the New Testament, was written by the apostle John while he was exiled on a small island called Patmos.
beginner.explanation: John was exiled to the island of Patmos 'because of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus.' While there, he received the visions that make up the book of Revelation. Patmos is a small Greek island in the Aegean Sea, and tradition dates John's exile to around 95 AD during the reign of Emperor Domitian.

beginner.question: In the parable of the Prodigal Son, when the younger son returned home after wasting all his money, his father refused to welcome him back and made him work as a servant.
beginner.explanation: The father did the opposite — he ran to his son, embraced him, kissed him, and threw a lavish celebration. He put the best robe on him, a ring on his finger, and sandals on his feet. He ordered the fattened calf to be killed for a feast, saying 'this son of mine was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.'

beginner.question: The Gospel of Mark is generally considered by scholars to be the shortest of the four Gospels and was likely the first one to be written.
beginner.explanation: Mark's Gospel is the shortest of the four, with only 16 chapters compared to Matthew's 28, Luke's 24, and John's 21. Most scholars believe Mark was written first (around 65-70 AD) and that Matthew and Luke used Mark as a source when writing their own Gospels.

beginner.question: According to the New Testament, Jesus performed His first miracle by healing a blind man at the Pool of Siloam in Jerusalem.
beginner.explanation: Jesus' first miracle was turning water into wine at a wedding in Cana of Galilee, not healing a blind man. John 2:11 specifically states 'What Jesus did here in Cana of Galilee was the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory.' The healing of a blind man at the Pool of Siloam happened much later in His ministry.

beginner.question: After Jesus ascended to heaven, the disciples waited in Jerusalem as He had instructed them. They were all gathered together when the Holy Spirit came upon them on the day of Pentecost.
beginner.explanation: Before ascending, Jesus told His disciples to stay in Jerusalem and wait for the gift of the Holy Spirit. They gathered in an upper room, praying together. On the day of Pentecost (50 days after Passover), the Holy Spirit came with the sound of a rushing wind and tongues of fire, empowering them to preach the gospel.

beginner.question: In the Christmas story told in Luke's Gospel, an angel appeared to shepherds watching their flocks at night near Bethlehem and announced the birth of Jesus, calling Him 'a Saviour, who is Christ the Lord.'
beginner.explanation: An angel of the Lord appeared to shepherds in the fields near Bethlehem, and the glory of the Lord shone around them. The angel said 'Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord.' Then a great company of angels appeared, praising God.

beginner.question: The New Testament was originally written in Latin, the official language of the Roman Empire, and was later translated into Greek.
beginner.explanation: The New Testament was originally written in Greek — specifically Koine (common) Greek, which was the widely spoken language of the eastern Roman Empire. Although Latin was the official language of Rome, Greek was the common language of trade, culture, and communication throughout the Mediterranean world in the first century.

beginner.question: According to the Gospel accounts, Jesus walked on water during a storm on the Sea of Galilee, and Peter also briefly walked on water before becoming afraid and beginning to sink.
beginner.explanation: Jesus came to the disciples walking on the Sea of Galilee during a storm. Peter asked to come to Jesus on the water, and Jesus said 'Come.' Peter stepped out of the boat and walked on the water toward Jesus, but when he saw the wind and waves, he became afraid and began to sink. Jesus caught him and said 'You of little faith, why did you doubt?'

beginner.question: The well-known verse John 3:16, which begins 'For God so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son,' was spoken by Jesus during a private nighttime conversation with a Pharisee named Nicodemus.
beginner.explanation: Nicodemus, a member of the Jewish ruling council, came to Jesus at night. During their conversation about being 'born again,' Jesus spoke the famous words: 'For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.'

beginner.question: According to the book of Acts, the apostle Paul was born and raised in Jerusalem and never travelled outside of Israel during his ministry.
beginner.explanation: Paul was born in Tarsus (in modern-day Turkey), not Jerusalem. He was one of the most widely travelled figures in the New Testament, making at least three major missionary journeys across the Roman Empire — through modern-day Turkey, Greece, and eventually to Rome. He established churches throughout the Mediterranean world.

beginner.question: In the Lord's Prayer that Jesus taught His disciples, one of the requests is 'Give us today our daily bread,' asking God to provide for our everyday needs.
beginner.explanation: The Lord's Prayer (Matthew 6:9-13) includes the request 'Give us today our daily bread.' This is a prayer for God's daily provision — not just physical food, but all the necessities of life. It teaches dependence on God for everyday needs, one day at a time.

beginner.question: According to the Gospel of Luke, when Jesus was presented at the Temple as an infant, an elderly man named Simeon held the baby and declared that he could now die in peace because he had seen God's salvation.
beginner.explanation: Simeon was a righteous and devout man who had been promised by the Holy Spirit that he would not die before seeing the Messiah. When Mary and Joseph brought the baby Jesus to the Temple, Simeon took the child in his arms and praised God, saying 'my eyes have seen your salvation, which you have prepared in the sight of all nations.'
