He reduced 613 laws to two principles: vertical love (toward God) and horizontal love (toward people).

intermediate.question: Jesus healed a woman who had been suffering from bleeding for 12 years. She had spent all her money on doctors but only got worse. She believed that if she could just touch Jesus' clothing she would be healed. What happened when she touched the edge of his cloak?
options: Nothing happened at first
She was immediately healed, and Jesus felt power go out from him and asked 'Who touched me?'
Jesus turned and laid hands on her
She fainted and Jesus carried her to safety
intermediate.explanation: The moment she touched his cloak, her bleeding stopped. Jesus immediately sensed that power had gone out from him and asked 'Who touched me?' in a crowd pressing against him. The disciples thought the question was absurd, but the woman fell at his feet and told the truth. Jesus said 'Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace and be freed from your suffering.'

intermediate.question: On the day of Pentecost, 50 days after Jesus' resurrection and 10 days after his ascension, the Holy Spirit descended on the disciples in Jerusalem. How did the Holy Spirit manifest his arrival?
options: A gentle breeze filled the room
The sound of a violent rushing wind filled the house, and tongues of fire appeared and rested on each of them, and they spoke in other languages
A bright light filled the Temple
Thunder and lightning struck the building
intermediate.explanation: Suddenly a sound like a violent rushing wind came from heaven and filled the whole house. They saw tongues of fire that separated and came to rest on each of them. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages, understood by the diverse crowd of Jews from many nations gathered in Jerusalem. Peter preached and about 3,000 people were baptised that day — the birth of the church.

advanced.question: The Gospel of John opens with a theological prologue that begins 'In the beginning was the Word (Logos), and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.' The Greek term 'Logos' carried deep meaning in both Jewish and Greek thought. What did 'Logos' primarily mean in Greek philosophy before John adopted it?
options: A simple spoken word or command
The rational principle governing the universe — divine reason, logic, and cosmic order
A religious prayer or liturgical formula
A reference to written scripture
advanced.explanation: In Greek philosophy (particularly Stoicism and Heraclitus), 'Logos' referred to the rational, ordering principle behind all reality — the divine reason that gave coherence to the cosmos. In Jewish thought, the 'Word of God' was the creative and revelatory power of God (Genesis 1 — God spoke creation into being). John brilliantly bridges both worlds by declaring that this cosmic Logos 'became flesh and made his dwelling among us' in Jesus.

advanced.question: The phrase 'the kingdom of God' (or 'kingdom of heaven' in Matthew) was central to Jesus' teaching — he mentioned it over 100 times. Scholars debate its exact nature. Which of the following best captures the tension in Jesus' teaching about the kingdom?
options: The kingdom is purely a future heavenly reality with no present dimension
The kingdom is both 'already here' (inaugurated through Jesus' ministry) and 'not yet' (awaiting full consummation at his return)
The kingdom is a political nation that Jesus intended to establish on earth immediately
The kingdom is an entirely internal, spiritual state with no outward social expression
advanced.explanation: New Testament scholars widely recognise the 'already/not yet' tension in Jesus' kingdom teaching. Jesus said 'The kingdom of God has come upon you' (present — Matthew 12:28) and taught people to pray 'Your kingdom come' (future — Matthew 6:10). The kingdom was inaugurated in Jesus' life, death, and resurrection, but awaits full consummation at his second coming. This framework, popularised by George Eldon Ladd, shapes much of modern evangelical theology.

advanced.question: Jesus' title 'Son of Man' is his most frequently used self-designation in the Gospels (over 80 times), yet it is almost never used by anyone else to refer to him. The title draws primarily from a vision in the book of Daniel. What does Daniel's vision reveal about the 'Son of Man'?
options: He is a humble teacher who lives among the poor
He is a divine figure who comes on the clouds of heaven, approaches the Ancient of Days, and is given authority, glory, and an everlasting kingdom
He is a military leader who conquers Israel's enemies
He is an angel who delivers messages from God
advanced.explanation: In Daniel 7:13-14, 'one like a son of man' approaches the Ancient of Days (God) riding on the clouds of heaven and is given 'authority, glory and sovereign power; all nations and peoples of every language worshipped him. His dominion is an everlasting dominion that will not pass away.' By using this title, Jesus was making an extraordinary claim to divine authority while initially veiling it in a title that also means simply 'human being.'

advanced.question: The Synoptic Problem is a major area of New Testament scholarship dealing with the literary relationship between Matthew, Mark, and Luke. The dominant theory holds that one Gospel was written first and the other two used it as a source. According to the most widely accepted scholarly view, which Gospel was written first?
options: Matthew
Mark
Luke
John
advanced.explanation: Markan Priority — the view that Mark was the first Gospel written (around AD 65-70) — is the most widely held position in modern scholarship. Nearly all of Mark's content appears in Matthew and/or Luke, often with the same wording and order. The Two-Source Hypothesis posits that Matthew and Luke independently used Mark plus a hypothetical sayings source called 'Q' (from the German 'Quelle' meaning 'source').

advanced.question: When Jesus was crucified, the Gospels record that he cried out 'Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?' ('My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?'). While this is often interpreted as a cry of despair, many scholars point out that Jesus was quoting the opening line of a specific psalm. Why is the full context of this psalm significant?
options: The psalm describes God's permanent rejection of the righteous
Psalm 22 begins with abandonment but ends in triumph, praise, and the proclamation 'He has done it' — suggesting Jesus was pointing to the whole psalm, not just the opening despair
The psalm is a battle cry for military victory
The psalm calls for vengeance against enemies
advanced.explanation: Psalm 22 begins with 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' but progresses through suffering (pierced hands and feet, lots cast for garments) to triumphant vindication: 'All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the LORD' and concludes 'He has done it!' By quoting the opening line, Jesus may have been directing attention to the entire psalm — from the reality of his suffering to the certainty of God's ultimate victory.

advanced.question: The concept of kenosis (from the Greek 'kenoo,' meaning 'to empty') is derived from Philippians 2:5-11, which describes Christ 'emptying himself' to take the form of a servant. What does the kenosis passage teach about Jesus' incarnation?
options: Jesus temporarily ceased to be God when he became human
Jesus voluntarily set aside the independent exercise of certain divine attributes (not his divine nature) to take on full humanity
Jesus was merely a human being whom God later elevated to divine status
Jesus pretended to be human while remaining fully divine without any real limitation
advanced.explanation: The Philippians 2 hymn states that Jesus, 'being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be used to his own advantage; rather, he made himself nothing (emptied himself) by taking the very nature of a servant.' Orthodox theology teaches that Jesus didn't cease being God but voluntarily chose not to exercise certain divine prerogatives independently, fully experiencing human limitations while retaining his divine nature.

advanced.question: The Gospel of John contains seven 'sign miracles' carefully selected by the author to reveal Jesus' identity. Unlike the Synoptic Gospels (which record dozens of miracles), John chose exactly seven and often followed each with extended theological discourse. Why did John limit himself to seven signs?
options: He simply didn't know about more miracles
Seven is the biblical number of completeness/perfection, and John chose these signs to present a theologically complete portrait of Jesus' divine identity
John was writing for a small community that wouldn't have believed more miracles
Roman censorship prevented him from including more supernatural content
advanced.explanation: John 20:30-31 explicitly states 'Jesus performed many other signs in the presence of his disciples, which are not recorded in this book. But these are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God.' Seven was the number of divine completeness in Jewish thought. Each sign reveals a facet of Jesus' identity: from water to wine (Creator), healing the official's son (Life-giver), to raising Lazarus (Lord of Death).

advanced.question: The 'Messianic Secret' is a term coined by William Wrede in 1901 to describe a puzzling pattern in Mark's Gospel where Jesus repeatedly tells people he heals and even demons who recognise him not to tell anyone who he is. What is the most widely accepted theological explanation for this pattern?
options: Jesus didn't want to become famous

Jesus needed to control the narrative of his identity because popular messianic expectations were political/military, and premature revelation could trigger the wrong kind of following before his mission was complete
Jesus was unsure of his own identity and wanted time to figure it out
Jesus was testing people's obedience
advanced.explanation: First-century Jewish messianic expectations centred on a military deliverer who would overthrow Rome. Jesus' mission was to be a suffering servant, not a political king. Premature disclosure of his messiahship would have sparked political uprising and prevented him from fulfilling his true mission — the cross. After Peter's confession, Jesus 'began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer' (Mark 8:31) — redefining messiahship through suffering.

advanced.question: Jesus' parables often subverted the expectations of his audience. In the Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard (Matthew 20), workers hired at different times of the day all received the same full day's wage. This parable was a direct challenge to what common religious assumption?
options: That prayer is unnecessary for salvation
That God's grace operates on a merit-based system where greater effort earns greater reward, rather than being a gift of equal generosity to all
That only Jewish people could enter the kingdom
That wealth is a sign of God's blessing
advanced.explanation: The parable scandalized its hearers because the workers who laboured all day expected more than those who worked only one hour. The landowner's response — 'Don't I have the right to do what I want with my own money? Are you envious because I am generous?' — illustrates that God's grace is not earned by effort. The 'first shall be last, and last shall be first.' This challenged both Pharisaic merit-theology and human notions of fairness.

advanced.question: The crucifixion narrative contains several details that scholars believe were intended to present Jesus as the ultimate Passover lamb. Which of the following details most directly connects Jesus' death to the Passover sacrifice?
options: Jesus was crucified outside the city walls

In John's chronology, Jesus dies at the exact time the Passover lambs were being slaughtered in the Temple, and not one of his bones was broken (fulfilling the Passover requirement that no bone of the lamb be broken)
Jesus wore a purple robe
Darkness covered the land for three hours
advanced.explanation: John's Gospel places Jesus' death on the Day of Preparation for Passover — at the very hour when priests were slaughtering Passover lambs in the Temple. When soldiers came to break the legs of those crucified, Jesus was already dead, so they did not break his bones (John 19:33-36) — fulfilling Exodus 12:46: 'Do not break any of the bones.' Paul explicitly declares 'Christ, our Passover lamb, has been sacrificed' (1 Corinthians 5:7).

advanced.question: The historical Jesus debate has produced various scholarly positions. The 'Third Quest for the Historical Jesus' (from the 1980s onward) emphasises understanding Jesus within his first-century Jewish context. Which approach distinguishes the Third Quest from earlier scholarship?
options: Rejecting all supernatural elements and treating Jesus as purely a moral teacher
Placing Jesus firmly within Second Temple Judaism and using Jewish sources to illuminate his words and deeds, rather than abstracting him from his Jewish context
Treating the Gospels as entirely unreliable historical documents
Focusing exclusively on archaeological evidence while ignoring literary sources
advanced.explanation: The Third Quest (led by scholars like E.P. Sanders, N.T. Wright, and James D.G. Dunn) emphasised that Jesus must be understood as a first-century Jew within Second Temple Judaism. Unlike earlier quests that imposed modern Western categories, the Third Quest uses Jewish literature (Dead Sea Scrolls, Mishnah, Josephus) to illuminate Jesus' teachings about the kingdom, his conflicts with religious leaders, and his self-understanding.

advanced.question: The term 'hypostatic union' is the technical theological term describing the relationship between Jesus' divine and human natures, formally defined at the Council of Chalcedon in AD 451. What does the Chalcedonian definition affirm about Jesus?
options: Jesus had a divine nature that gradually replaced his human nature
Jesus is one person with two complete natures — fully God and fully human — united without confusion, change, division, or separation
Jesus alternated between being divine and being human at different times
Jesus had a mixed nature that was partly divine and partly human
advanced.explanation: Chalcedon affirmed that Jesus Christ is 'truly God and truly man... in two natures, without confusion, without change, without division, without separation; the distinction of natures being by no means taken away by the union, but rather the property of each nature being preserved, and concurring in one person.' This definition navigated between errors: Jesus is not half-God/half-human, nor two persons, nor divine only pretending to be human.

advanced.question: Jesus' practice of eating with 'sinners and tax collectors' was not merely casual socialising — it was a deliberately provocative prophetic action. In the culture of first-century Palestine, what did sharing a meal symbolise?
options: Simply satisfying hunger with available company
Table fellowship represented acceptance, covenant relationship, and the anticipated messianic banquet — eating with outcasts declared God's welcome to those the religious establishment excluded
It was merely a teaching opportunity with no deeper meaning
It showed Jesus' lack of concern for dietary laws
advanced.explanation: In ancient Mediterranean culture, table fellowship was laden with social and religious meaning. Who you ate with defined your social boundaries. The messianic age was pictured as a great banquet (Isaiah 25:6-8). By eating with tax collectors and sinners, Jesus was performing a prophetic sign-act — declaring that God's kingdom was open to those the religious establishment had excluded. The Pharisees understood exactly what he was claiming, which is why they objected so strongly.

advanced.question: The Gospel of Mark has a famously abrupt ending in the earliest manuscripts — it ends at Mark 16:8 with the women fleeing the empty tomb 'trembling and bewildered' and telling 'no one anything, because they were afraid.' Later manuscripts add a longer ending (verses 9-20). Why do most scholars believe the original ending was at verse 8?
options: Mark died before finishing his Gospel
The earliest and most reliable manuscripts (Sinaiticus and Vaticanus) end at 16:8, and the vocabulary and style of the longer ending differ significantly from the rest of Mark
Ancient editors deliberately removed the ending to create mystery
The original ending was lost in a fire
advanced.explanation: The two oldest and most important Greek manuscripts — Codex Sinaiticus and Codex Vaticanus (both 4th century) — end at Mark 16:8. Early church fathers Clement and Origen show no knowledge of the longer ending. The vocabulary, style, and theology of verses 9-20 differ noticeably from the rest of Mark. Some scholars believe Mark intentionally ended with the women's fear and silence, inviting readers to complete the story with their own response to the resurrection.

advanced.question: The concept of 'atonement' — how Jesus' death deals with human sin — has been understood through multiple theological models throughout church history. Which model focuses specifically on Jesus' death as a victory over the powers of evil, sin, and death?
options: Moral Influence Theory (Abelard)
Penal Substitutionary Atonement (Calvin/Reformation)
Christus Victor (Irenaeus/Aulén)
Satisfaction Theory (Anselm)
advanced.explanation: Christus Victor ('Christ the Victor'), the earliest atonement model prominent in the early church fathers, presents Jesus' death and resurrection as a cosmic victory over the powers of sin, death, and the devil. Swedish theologian Gustaf Aulén reintroduced this model in his 1931 book 'Christus Victor.' In this view, the cross is primarily a battlefield where Christ defeats the enslaving powers. It complements rather than replaces other atonement models.

advanced.question: The feeding of the 5,000 is the only miracle (besides the resurrection) recorded in all four Gospels, and John's Gospel follows it with Jesus' 'Bread of Life' discourse. Scholars note that the miracle contains deliberate echoes of an Old Testament event. Which event does it most closely parallel?
options: The manna God provided to the Israelites in the wilderness
Elijah being fed by ravens
The meal Abraham prepared for the three angelic visitors
The wedding feast at Cana
advanced.explanation: The feeding of the 5,000 deliberately echoes the manna miracle. Jesus feeds a multitude in a deserted place (wilderness), bread comes from an unexpected source, there is more than enough for everyone, and John 6 explicitly connects the events when the crowd says 'Our ancestors ate manna in the wilderness.' Jesus responds 'I am the bread of life. Your ancestors ate manna and died, but whoever eats this bread will live forever.' He is the true manna.

advanced.question: Jesus' cry from the cross 'It is finished' (John 19:30) uses the Greek word 'tetelestai.' This word carried specific significance in the commercial world of first-century Greco-Roman society. What did 'tetelestai' mean in everyday usage?
options: 'It is destroyed'
'Paid in full' — it was stamped on receipts and debt certificates when a debt had been completely satisfied
'The end has come'
'I give up'
advanced.explanation: 'Tetelestai' was a commercial and legal term meaning 'paid in full' — it was written across receipts when a debt was completely settled. Archaeological discoveries of papyrus tax receipts in Egypt have confirmed this usage. When Jesus cried 'Tetelestai,' he was declaring that the debt of human sin had been completely paid — nothing more was owed, nothing more could be added. It was a shout of triumph, not defeat.

advanced.question: The 'criteria of authenticity' are tools scholars use to evaluate which sayings and deeds attributed to Jesus in the Gospels are historically reliable. One important criterion is the 'criterion of embarrassment.' What does this criterion suggest?
options: Sayings that embarrass the reader are likely fictional

Material that would have been embarrassing or difficult for the early church to invent (like Jesus' baptism by John, his ignorance of the day of his return, or Peter's denials) is likely historically authentic because no one would fabricate material that created theological problems
Embarrassing stories were added later to make Jesus seem more human
Only flattering accounts of Jesus can be considered reliable
advanced.explanation: The criterion of embarrassment argues that the early church would not have invented stories that created theological difficulties for themselves. Jesus being baptised by John (suggesting Jesus needed repentance), Jesus saying he didn't know the day of his return (suggesting limited knowledge), and Jesus crying out 'Why have you forsaken me?' are examples — the church would have no reason to create these traditions, so they are likely historically authentic.

advanced.question: In Matthew's Gospel, Jesus delivers five major discourses (chapters 5-7, 10, 13, 18, 23-25), each ending with a similar formula ('When Jesus had finished saying these things...'). Many scholars believe Matthew structured his Gospel this way to intentionally parallel a specific section of the Old Testament. Which section?
options: The five books of Moses (Pentateuch/Torah)
The five wisdom books
The five scrolls (Megilloth)
The five major prophets
advanced.explanation: Matthew's five-discourse structure appears to deliberately parallel the five books of Moses, presenting Jesus as the 'new Moses' — the definitive lawgiver and teacher. Just as Moses delivered God's law from Mount Sinai, Jesus delivers his teaching from a mountain (Sermon on the Mount). Matthew's Gospel consistently emphasises Jesus' fulfilment of Old Testament patterns, and this structural parallel underscores Jesus as the one greater than Moses.

advanced.question: The term 'Son of God' as applied to Jesus carried layered meaning. In the Old Testament, 'son of God' could refer to angels, the king of Israel, or the nation of Israel itself. When the Roman centurion at the cross said 'Truly this man was the Son of God!' (Mark 15:39), what would this title have meant in a Roman context?
options: A Jewish religious leader
A divine being in the Jewish sense
'Son of God' (divi filius) was a title used for the Roman Emperor — the centurion was acknowledging Jesus' authority as rivalling Caesar's
A prophet sent from heaven
advanced.explanation: In the Roman world, 'Son of God' (divi filius) was an official title of the Emperor — Augustus was called 'son of the divine Julius.' When a Roman centurion declares the crucified Jesus 'Son of God,' Mark presents a profound irony: the representative of Roman power, standing at the foot of Rome's instrument of execution, confesses that the true 'Son of God' is not Caesar but this crucified Jewish man. It's a political and theological bombshell.

advanced.question: Paul's earliest letter (1 Thessalonians, written around AD 50-51) and the early creed embedded in 1 Corinthians 15:3-7 (which scholars date to within 3-5 years of the crucifixion) are significant for historical Jesus studies. Why are these texts so important?
options: They contain the most detailed accounts of Jesus' miracles

They demonstrate that core Christian beliefs — Jesus' death for sins, burial, resurrection, and appearances to eyewitnesses — were established within a few years of the events, far too early for legendary development
They are the only reliable texts about Jesus
They were written by eyewitnesses to the crucifixion
advanced.explanation: The creedal formula in 1 Corinthians 15:3-7 ('Christ died for our sins... was buried... was raised on the third day... appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve') is dated by most scholars to within 3-5 years of the crucifixion (approximately AD 33-38). Paul received it as already-established tradition. This extremely early dating makes legendary invention essentially impossible — the core resurrection claim existed while eyewitnesses were still alive and could be consulted.

advanced.question: The Gospel of John uses the concept of 'signs' (semeion) differently from the Synoptic Gospels' use of 'miracles' (dunamis/power). In John's theological framework, what is the essential purpose of a 'sign'?
options: To prove Jesus' power to unbelievers
A sign points beyond itself to a deeper spiritual reality about Jesus' identity — it is not just an act of power but a revelation of who Jesus is
To fulfill Old Testament prophecy
To establish Jesus' authority over nature
advanced.explanation: In John's Gospel, 'signs' are not just displays of power — they are symbolic revelations of Jesus' identity. Turning water to wine reveals Jesus as the source of messianic joy. Healing the blind man reveals Jesus as 'the light of the world.' Raising Lazarus reveals Jesus as 'the resurrection and the life.' Each sign functions as a theological window into Jesus' nature. John also notes that seeing signs without grasping their meaning is insufficient — true faith goes beyond signs to the person they reveal.

advanced.question: The 'Johannine Comma' (1 John 5:7-8) is a famous textual variant that explicitly states 'there are three that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one.' Why do most modern scholars and Bible translations exclude or bracket this passage?
options: It contradicts other New Testament teachings
It is absent from virtually all Greek manuscripts before the 16th century, absent from all early church father citations, and appears to have originated as a marginal gloss in later Latin manuscripts
It was deliberately removed by heretical scribes
It duplicates content found elsewhere in John's writings
advanced.explanation: The Comma Johanneum is found in NO Greek manuscript before the 16th century. It is absent from all early church father discussions of the Trinity (who would certainly have cited it if it existed). It appears to have originated as a marginal gloss in Old Latin manuscripts that was later incorporated into the text. Erasmus famously excluded it from his Greek New Testament but was pressured to include it in his 1522 edition. Modern critical editions and translations either omit it or relegate it to a footnote.

advanced.question: Jesus' cleansing of the Temple is placed at different points in the Gospel narratives — John places it at the beginning of Jesus' ministry (chapter 2), while the Synoptic Gospels place it during the final week in Jerusalem. How do most scholars resolve this discrepancy?
options: One account is historically accurate and the other is wrong
Most scholars believe there was one cleansing that John relocated to the beginning of his Gospel for theological purposes — to frame Jesus' entire ministry as a replacement of the Temple system
Jesus cleansed the Temple twice — once at the beginning and once at the end of his ministry
The accounts describe two different parts of the Temple
advanced.explanation: While some scholars argue for two separate cleansings, the majority view is that John relocated the event to the beginning of his Gospel for theological reasons. By placing the Temple cleansing at the start, John frames Jesus' entire ministry as the replacement of the old Temple system. John's Gospel is structured more thematically than chronologically, and the placement serves his theological purpose of presenting Jesus as the true Temple (John 2:21 — 'the temple he had spoken of was his body').

advanced.question: The concept of 'inaugurated eschatology' (associated with scholars like C.H. Dodd and George Ladd) fundamentally shapes how Christians understand Jesus' mission. Which statement best captures this concept?
options: All prophecy was fulfilled in Jesus' first coming

Jesus' first coming inaugurated the last days and the kingdom of God, but the full consummation awaits his second coming — creating an 'overlap of the ages' where the present evil age and the age to come coexist
The end times have not yet begun and await a future trigger
Eschatology is purely symbolic and has no temporal dimension
advanced.explanation: Inaugurated eschatology holds that Jesus' life, death, and resurrection launched the 'age to come' within the present age — creating an overlap. Believers already experience kingdom realities (forgiveness, the Spirit, new creation) but still await the full consummation (bodily resurrection, new heavens and earth, elimination of evil). This framework explains why Christians experience both the 'already' (salvation, Spirit) and the 'not yet' (suffering, death, sin's persistence).

advanced.question: The resurrection narratives across the four Gospels contain notable differences in details (number of angels, which women visited, what they were told). Sceptics argue these differences undermine the accounts' reliability, while many historians argue the opposite. Why might these differences actually strengthen the historicity of the resurrection?
options: The differences show the authors were creative fiction writers

Independent, unharmonised eyewitness accounts naturally contain variant details about peripheral circumstances while agreeing on the core event — this pattern is characteristic of authentic testimony, not fabrication (which would show artificial agreement)
The differences don't matter because the accounts are purely symbolic
Later editors deliberately introduced differences to make the accounts seem authentic
advanced.explanation: Legal and historical scholars note that when multiple witnesses describe the same event, verbatim agreement suggests collusion or copying, while agreement on core facts with variation in peripheral details (how many angels, exact time, who arrived first) is the hallmark of genuine independent testimony. All accounts agree on the essentials: Jesus died, was buried, the tomb was empty on Sunday morning, and women were the first witnesses — this last detail is particularly significant since women's testimony was not considered reliable in first-century Jewish courts, making it an unlikely invention.

advanced.question: The 'New Perspective on Paul' (associated with E.P. Sanders, James Dunn, and N.T. Wright) has significantly reframed how scholars understand Jesus' conflicts with the Pharisees. According to this perspective, what was the primary issue between Jesus and the Pharisees?
options: The Pharisees were trying to earn salvation through good works while Jesus taught grace alone

The conflict centred on 'boundary markers' (Sabbath, food laws, circumcision, purity) that defined who was 'in' or 'out' of God's people — Jesus was redefining the boundaries of God's covenant community around himself rather than Torah observance
Jesus rejected the Old Testament while the Pharisees upheld it
The Pharisees were corrupt politicians, not genuinely religious men
advanced.explanation: The New Perspective argues that first-century Judaism was not about 'earning salvation by works' (a caricature largely shaped by Reformation polemic). The Pharisees were genuinely devoted to Torah. The real conflict was about 'who belongs to God's people?' — the Pharisees defined belonging by Torah observance (especially Sabbath, food laws, circumcision), while Jesus was radically redefining God's covenant community around faith in himself, welcoming sinners, tax collectors, and Gentiles.

advanced.question: The non-biblical historian Josephus (AD 37-100) mentions Jesus in a passage known as the 'Testimonium Flavianum' (Antiquities 18.3.3). Why is this passage both celebrated and controversial among scholars?
options: Because Josephus was a Christian who naturally praised Jesus

While the core reference to Jesus is considered authentic by most scholars, the passage contains phrases ('he was the Messiah,' 'he appeared to them alive on the third day') that appear to be later Christian interpolations inserted into Josephus' original text
Because the passage is a medieval forgery with no ancient manuscript support
Because Josephus contradicts everything the Gospels say about Jesus
advanced.explanation: The majority scholarly view is that Josephus did write about Jesus (he was a Jewish historian recording significant events), but that Christian scribes later embellished the passage with faith claims Josephus, as a non-Christian Jew, would not have written. Reconstructed, the original likely said something like: 'About this time there lived Jesus, a wise man... He won over many Jews and many of the Greeks. When Pilate condemned him to the cross, those who had loved him did not give up their affection for him. And the tribe of Christians, so called after him, has still to this day not disappeared.'

advanced.question: The 'ransom saying' of Jesus — 'The Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many' (Mark 10:45) — is considered by most scholars to be one of the most important christological statements in the Synoptic Gospels. The Greek word 'lytron' (ransom) carries a specific connotation. What does it mean?
options: A gift freely given with no strings attached
The price paid to release a slave, prisoner, or hostage from bondage — liberation through substitutionary payment
A fine paid to avoid punishment
A voluntary donation to charity
advanced.explanation: 'Lytron' (ransom) was the price paid to free slaves, prisoners of war, or those under sentence of death. The preposition 'anti' (for/instead of) indicates substitution — Jesus gives his life 'instead of' the many. Combined with 'the many' (echoing Isaiah 53's Suffering Servant), this saying presents Jesus' death as a voluntary, substitutionary act of liberation — paying the price to set captive humanity free. It is one of the clearest self-interpretations of Jesus' death in the Gospels.

advanced.question: Luke's Gospel has been called the 'Gospel of the outcasts' because of its distinctive emphasis on groups that were marginalised in first-century Jewish society. Which of the following is NOT a distinctive Lukan emphasis?
options: Women (Mary's Magnificat, Anna, the widow of Nain, the sinful woman, Mary and Martha, the bent-over woman)
The poor and the oppressed (Blessed are the poor, the Rich Man and Lazarus, Zacchaeus)
Detailed genealogies tracing Jesus' lineage through the royal line of Solomon
Samaritans, Gentiles, and other social outsiders (the Good Samaritan, the grateful Samaritan leper, Simeon's 'light for revelation to the Gentiles')
advanced.explanation: Luke does include a genealogy, but it traces Jesus' line through Nathan (not Solomon) back to Adam (emphasising Jesus' connection to all humanity), whereas Matthew traces the royal Solomonic line. Luke's distinctive emphasis is on the marginalised: women appear in nearly every chapter, the poor receive special blessings, Samaritans are heroes, and the gospel is explicitly 'for all people.' Luke also uniquely records Jesus' first sermon in Nazareth about 'good news to the poor... freedom for the oppressed.'

beginner.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus was born to a virgin named Mary in the town of Bethlehem, as the angel Gabriel had announced to her beforehand.
beginner.explanation: The angel Gabriel appeared to Mary and told her she would conceive by the Holy Spirit and bear a son named Jesus. 'How will this be,' Mary asked, 'since I am a virgin?' Gabriel replied 'The Holy Spirit will come on you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you.' Mary responded with faith: 'I am the Lord's servant. May your word to me be fulfilled.'

beginner.question: Jesus grew up in the city of Jerusalem, where Joseph worked as a carpenter near the Temple.
beginner.explanation: Jesus grew up in Nazareth, a small village in the region of Galilee — not in Jerusalem. Nazareth was such an insignificant place that Nathanael famously asked 'Can anything good come from Nazareth?' (John 1:46). Jesus later moved his base of ministry to Capernaum, a town on the Sea of Galilee.

beginner.question: John the Baptist baptised Jesus in the Jordan River, and when Jesus came up out of the water, the Holy Spirit descended on him like a dove and God's voice said 'This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.'
beginner.explanation: John the Baptist initially hesitated, saying 'I need to be baptised by you, and do you come to me?' But Jesus insisted 'Let it be so now; it is proper for us to do this to fulfil all righteousness.' After the baptism, the heavens opened, the Spirit descended like a dove, and the Father's voice affirmed Jesus' identity and mission.

beginner.question: Jesus began his public ministry at approximately 30 years of age, meaning he spent roughly 30 years in relative obscurity before his three years of public ministry.
beginner.explanation: Luke 3:23 states 'Now Jesus himself was about thirty years old when he began his ministry.' This means Jesus spent about 30 years living as a carpenter in Nazareth before beginning his public work, which lasted approximately three years. The Gospels record almost nothing about these 'hidden years' except the Temple visit at age 12.

beginner.question: Jesus chose 10 apostles to be his closest followers, who would carry on his work after his death and resurrection.
beginner.explanation: Jesus chose 12 apostles, not 10. The number twelve was deliberate — it corresponded to the twelve tribes of Israel, symbolising that Jesus was reconstituting God's people. The twelve were: Peter, Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot.

beginner.question: Jesus' first miracle, according to John's Gospel, was turning water into wine at a wedding in Cana of Galilee, after his mother Mary told him the hosts had run out of wine.
beginner.explanation: Mary told Jesus 'They have no more wine.' Though Jesus initially said 'My hour has not yet come,' he instructed the servants to fill six stone water jars with water. When they drew some out, it had become wine. The master of the banquet was amazed at its quality, not knowing where it came from. John calls this 'the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory.'

beginner.question: Jesus taught that to enter the kingdom of God, people needed to be wealthy, powerful, and follow all 613 Jewish laws perfectly.
beginner.explanation: Jesus taught the opposite. He said 'Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven' and 'It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for someone who is rich to enter the kingdom of God.' He welcomed children, sinners, and outcasts. He taught that entering the kingdom requires faith and humility, not wealth, power, or perfect law-keeping.

beginner.question: The shortest verse in the Bible — 'Jesus wept' — appears in the story of Lazarus' death, showing that Jesus experienced genuine human grief and emotion.
beginner.explanation: John 11:35 ('Jesus wept') is the shortest verse in the English Bible. Even though Jesus knew he was about to raise Lazarus from the dead, he was deeply moved by the grief of Mary and Martha and by the reality of death itself. The original Greek uses a word for silent, deep tears (edakrysen) — different from the loud wailing of the mourners. It reveals Jesus' fully human compassion.

beginner.question: During the Last Supper, Jesus washed his disciples' feet as an act of humble service, including the feet of Judas Iscariot, who was about to betray him.
beginner.explanation: John 13:1 says 'Having loved his own who were in the world, he loved them to the end.' Jesus washed all the disciples' feet — including Judas'. He knew Judas would betray him (John 13:11) yet still served him with the same love and humility. Jesus told them 'I have set you an example that you should do as I have done for you.'

beginner.question: Pontius Pilate, the Roman governor, found Jesus guilty of a serious crime and eagerly sentenced him to death by crucifixion.
beginner.explanation: Pilate actually said three times 'I find no basis for a charge against him' (John 18:38, 19:4, 19:6). He tried to release Jesus by offering the crowd a choice between Jesus and Barabbas, and he even washed his hands symbolically saying 'I am innocent of this man's blood.' But under pressure from the Jewish leaders and the crowd, he handed Jesus over to be crucified despite believing him innocent.

beginner.question: Jesus was crucified at a place called Golgotha, which means 'the place of the skull,' and he died on a Friday, which Christians now commemorate as Good Friday.
beginner.explanation: Golgotha (Aramaic) or Calvary (Latin) means 'Place of the Skull,' likely named for the skull-shaped rock formation there. Jesus was crucified on a Friday (the day before the Sabbath) and Christians worldwide commemorate this day as Good Friday — 'good' because of the salvation accomplished through Jesus' sacrificial death, despite the horrific suffering involved.

beginner.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus rose from the dead on the third day after his crucifixion — that is, on a Sunday morning — and the first people to discover the empty tomb were women.
beginner.explanation: Jesus was crucified on Friday, rested in the tomb on Saturday (the Sabbath), and rose on Sunday morning — the third day by Jewish reckoning. Women (including Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and others) were the first to discover the empty tomb and the first to see the risen Jesus. This detail is considered historically significant because women's testimony was not considered reliable in first-century Jewish courts.

beginner.question: After his resurrection, Jesus appeared to his disciples over a period of 40 days, teaching them about the kingdom of God, before ascending to heaven from the Mount of Olives.
beginner.explanation: Acts 1:3 states 'After his suffering, he presented himself to them and gave many convincing proofs that he was alive. He appeared to them over a period of forty days and spoke about the kingdom of God.' He ate with them, taught them, and commissioned them. Then, on the Mount of Olives, he was taken up before their eyes and a cloud hid him from their sight.

beginner.question: Jesus only performed healing miracles for Jewish people and refused to help Gentiles (non-Jews) or Samaritans during his ministry.
beginner.explanation: While Jesus' primary mission was to 'the lost sheep of Israel,' he also healed non-Jews. He healed the Roman centurion's servant (Matthew 8:5-13), praising the centurion's faith as greater than any he had found in Israel. He healed the Syrophoenician woman's daughter (Mark 7:24-30) and the Samaritan leper (Luke 17:11-19). These healings foreshadowed the gospel going to all nations.

beginner.question: The disciple who betrayed Jesus — Judas Iscariot — was paid 30 pieces of silver by the chief priests for identifying Jesus to the soldiers who arrested him.
beginner.explanation: Matthew 26:14-16 records that Judas went to the chief priests and asked 'What are you willing to give me if I deliver him over to you?' They counted out 30 pieces of silver. This amount fulfilled the prophecy of Zechariah 11:12 — the price of a slave. After the betrayal, Judas was filled with remorse, tried to return the money, and then took his own life.

beginner.question: During his crucifixion, Jesus forgave the criminals who were crucified beside him, and one of them asked Jesus to remember him when he came into his kingdom.
beginner.explanation: Two criminals were crucified alongside Jesus. One mocked him, but the other rebuked the first criminal and said 'Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.' Jesus replied 'Truly I tell you, today you will be with me in paradise.' Earlier, Jesus had also prayed 'Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing' — forgiving even his executioners.

beginner.question: Jesus said 'I am the good shepherd' and compared himself to a shepherd who lays down his life for his sheep, in contrast to a hired hand who abandons the sheep when danger comes.
beginner.explanation: In John 10:11-15, Jesus said 'I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs away.' He added 'I know my sheep and my sheep know me... and I lay down my life for the sheep.' This imagery connected to Psalm 23 and Ezekiel 34.

beginner.question: After healing a paralysed man who was lowered through a roof by his friends, Jesus first said 'Your sins are forgiven' before telling him to 'Get up, take your mat, and go home' — which angered the religious leaders who believed only God could forgive sins.
beginner.explanation: Four friends couldn't get through the crowd, so they made a hole in the roof and lowered the paralysed man to Jesus on a mat. Jesus said 'Son, your sins are forgiven.' The religious leaders thought this was blasphemy — only God can forgive sins. Jesus asked 'Which is easier: to say "Your sins are forgiven" or "Get up and walk"?' Then he healed the man to prove he had authority to forgive sins.

beginner.question: Jesus taught his followers to pray in public as loudly as possible so that everyone could hear and be impressed by their devotion to God.
beginner.explanation: Jesus taught exactly the opposite: 'When you pray, do not be like the hypocrites, for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and on the street corners to be seen by others... But when you pray, go into your room, close the door and pray to your Father, who is unseen. Then your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you.' He condemned prayer that was performed for human applause rather than genuine conversation with God.

beginner.question: The Gospels record that at the moment of Jesus' death on the cross, darkness covered the whole land for three hours, and the curtain of the Temple was torn in two from top to bottom.
beginner.explanation: From noon until 3 PM, darkness covered the land. At the moment Jesus died, the curtain of the Temple was torn in two from top to bottom. There was also an earthquake and rocks split. The centurion guarding Jesus was so terrified by these events that he exclaimed 'Surely he was the Son of God!' The tearing of the curtain symbolised direct access to God being opened through Jesus' sacrifice.

beginner.question: Jesus refused to associate with tax collectors and sinners, considering them unworthy of his time and attention.
beginner.explanation: Jesus was famously criticised for doing the exact opposite. The Pharisees complained 'This man welcomes sinners and eats with them!' (Luke 15:2). Jesus called the tax collector Matthew to be one of his twelve apostles. He dined at the home of Zacchaeus. He said 'It is not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick. I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners' (Mark 2:17).

beginner.question: When Jesus calmed a storm on the Sea of Galilee by simply speaking to the wind and waves, the disciples were amazed and asked 'Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!'
beginner.explanation: A furious squall came up while Jesus was asleep in the stern of the boat. The disciples woke him, terrified, saying 'Don't you care if we drown?' Jesus got up, rebuked the wind and said to the waves 'Quiet! Be still!' The wind died down completely and the sea became calm. The disciples' question 'Who is this?' shows they were beginning to understand that Jesus had divine authority over nature itself.

beginner.question: According to Luke's Gospel, Mary (Jesus' mother) was visited by the angel Gabriel, who told her she would conceive by the Holy Spirit and bear a son named Jesus, who would be called 'the Son of the Most High.'
beginner.explanation: Gabriel told Mary 'Do not be afraid, Mary; you have found favour with God. You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you are to call him Jesus. He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David, and he will reign over Jacob's descendants forever; his kingdom will never end.'

beginner.question: Jesus said 'Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God' as part of the Beatitudes in the Sermon on the Mount — a series of blessings that described the character of those who belong to God's kingdom.
beginner.explanation: The Beatitudes (Matthew 5:3-12) begin 'Blessed are the poor in spirit' and include blessings for those who mourn, the meek, those who hunger for righteousness, the merciful, the pure in heart, peacemakers, and those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake. These blessings describe not merely passive traits but active virtues — peacemakers don't just avoid conflict but actively work to create peace.

beginner.question: The Gospel of Matthew records that after Jesus was born, King Herod ordered the massacre of all baby boys in Bethlehem aged two and under, in an attempt to kill the newborn 'King of the Jews.' Joseph was warned in a dream and fled with Mary and Jesus to Egypt.
beginner.explanation: When the Magi didn't return to tell Herod where the child was, Herod was furious and ordered the killing of all boys in Bethlehem aged two and under. An angel had warned Joseph in a dream to flee to Egypt with Mary and Jesus, where they stayed until Herod died. Matthew sees this as fulfilling Hosea 11:1: 'Out of Egypt I called my son.'

beginner.question: When a woman caught in adultery was brought before Jesus and the crowd wanted to stone her, Jesus wrote something in the dust and said 'Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.' One by one, the accusers left.
beginner.explanation: The scribes and Pharisees brought the woman, citing Moses' law about stoning adulterers. Jesus bent down and wrote on the ground with his finger. When they kept questioning him, he stood up and said 'Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.' One by one they left, starting with the oldest. Jesus then told the woman 'Neither do I condemn you. Go now and leave your life of sin.'

beginner.question: Mary Magdalene was one of Jesus' most devoted followers and was the first person to see the risen Jesus on Easter Sunday morning, making her the first witness of the resurrection.
beginner.explanation: According to John 20:11-18, Mary Magdalene was weeping outside the empty tomb when Jesus appeared to her. She initially mistook him for the gardener until he called her name — 'Mary.' She recognised his voice and exclaimed 'Rabboni!' (Teacher). Jesus told her 'Go and tell my brothers.' She became the first person to announce 'I have seen the Lord!' — earning her the title 'Apostle to the Apostles' in early church tradition.

beginner.question: The parable of the sower (or the parable of the soils) describes a farmer scattering seed on four types of ground — the path, rocky ground, thorns, and good soil — representing four different responses people have to God's message.
beginner.explanation: Jesus explained: seed on the path represents those who hear but the devil snatches the message away. Rocky ground represents those who receive with joy but have no root and fall away in trouble. Thorns represent those choked by life's worries, riches, and pleasures. Good soil represents those who hear, retain, and produce a crop — 30, 60, or 100 times what was sown. The parable teaches that the same message gets different responses based on the condition of the heart.

beginner.question: According to the Gospel of John, the last words Jesus spoke before dying on the cross were 'It is finished' — a declaration that his mission to save humanity was complete.
beginner.explanation: John 19:30 records 'When he had received the drink, Jesus said, "It is finished." With that, he bowed his head and gave up his spirit.' The Greek word 'tetelestai' means 'completed,' 'accomplished,' or 'paid in full.' It was not a cry of defeat but of victory — Jesus had accomplished everything the Father sent him to do. The work of salvation was complete.

beginner.question: During Jesus' ministry, he primarily taught in synagogues and the Temple, and he never taught outdoors or in people's homes.
beginner.explanation: Jesus taught everywhere — in synagogues, the Temple, homes, fields, hillsides, lakeshores, boats, and roads. The Sermon on the Mount was delivered outdoors on a hillside. He taught from a boat on the Sea of Galilee. He taught at dinner parties in people's homes. He taught while walking between villages. His ministry was characterised by accessibility — he met people wherever they were.

beginner.question: Jesus raised three people from the dead during his earthly ministry: Jairus' daughter, the widow of Nain's son, and his friend Lazarus.
beginner.explanation: Jesus raised Jairus' 12-year-old daughter, saying 'Talitha koum!' ('Little girl, get up!') — Mark 5:41. He raised the widow of Nain's only son by touching the funeral bier and saying 'Young man, I say to you, get up!' — Luke 7:14. He raised Lazarus, who had been dead four days, by calling 'Lazarus, come out!' — John 11:43. Each resurrection demonstrated increasing power over death.

beginner.question: Jesus' earthly ministry lasted approximately three years, from his baptism by John at about age 30 until his crucifixion at about age 33.
beginner.explanation: While the exact length is debated, most scholars estimate Jesus' public ministry lasted approximately three years, based on the number of Passover feasts mentioned in John's Gospel (John 2:13, 6:4, 11:55, and possibly 5:1). Luke 3:23 says Jesus was 'about thirty' when he began his ministry, placing his crucifixion at approximately age 33.

beginner.question: When Jesus ascended to heaven, two angels appeared and told the watching disciples that Jesus would return in the same way they had seen him go — coming back on the clouds.
beginner.explanation: As the disciples were staring up at the sky after Jesus was taken up, two men dressed in white (angels) stood beside them and said 'Men of Galilee, why do you stand here looking into the sky? This same Jesus, who has been taken from you into heaven, will come back in the same way you have seen him go into heaven.' This promise of Jesus' visible, physical return has been a cornerstone of Christian hope ever since.

beginner.question: The apostle Matthew, one of Jesus' twelve disciples, had previously worked as a tax collector — a profession despised by the Jewish people because tax collectors worked for the occupying Roman government and were considered traitors.
beginner.explanation: Matthew (also called Levi) was sitting at his tax collector's booth when Jesus walked by and simply said 'Follow me.' Matthew got up, left everything, and followed Jesus. He then threw a large banquet at his house for Jesus, inviting many tax collectors and sinners. The Pharisees complained, but Jesus said 'I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners.'

beginner.question: When Jesus fed the 5,000 people with five loaves and two fish, the disciples collected twelve baskets of leftover food after everyone had eaten their fill.
beginner.explanation: After Jesus blessed and broke the five barley loaves and two small fish, all 5,000 men (plus women and children, so the total was likely 15,000-20,000) ate until they were satisfied. The disciples then collected twelve full baskets of broken pieces left over — one for each disciple. The abundance of leftovers demonstrated that God's provision through Jesus was more than sufficient for everyone's needs.

intermediate.question: The Transfiguration of Jesus — when his face shone like the sun and his clothes became dazzling white — was witnessed by all twelve apostles on a high mountain.
intermediate.explanation: Only three apostles witnessed the Transfiguration: Peter, James, and John — the same inner circle who were present at the raising of Jairus' daughter and who accompanied Jesus deeper into Gethsemane. Jesus commanded them 'Don't tell anyone what you have seen, until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead.' These three were repeatedly given privileged access to Jesus' most significant moments.

intermediate.question: When Jesus entered the Temple and found merchants selling animals and money-changers taking unfair advantage of worshippers, he made a whip of cords and drove them out, overturning their tables and chairs.
intermediate.explanation: According to John 2:15, Jesus 'made a whip out of cords, and drove all from the temple courts, both sheep and cattle; he scattered the coins of the money changers and overturned their tables.' He said 'Get these out of here! Stop turning my Father's house into a market!' This dramatic action was a prophetic sign-act declaring judgment on the corrupt Temple system.

intermediate.question: Jesus never criticized the Pharisees publicly — he always addressed them privately and politely, treating them with great deference as the religious leaders of his people.
intermediate.explanation: Jesus' most scathing public criticisms were directed at the Pharisees and religious leaders. In Matthew 23, he delivered seven 'woes' against them: 'Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites!' He called them 'blind guides,' 'whitewashed tombs,' 'snakes,' and 'brood of vipers.' While Jesus showed compassion to sinners, he was fiercely confrontational with religious leaders who burdened people with rules while missing God's heart.

intermediate.question: The Garden of Gethsemane, where Jesus prayed before his arrest, was located on the Mount of Olives, just outside Jerusalem. The name 'Gethsemane' means 'olive press,' referring to the olive oil production that took place there.
intermediate.explanation: 'Gethsemane' comes from the Aramaic 'gat shmanim' meaning 'oil press.' It was an olive grove on the western slope of the Mount of Olives, across the Kidron Valley from Jerusalem. The name is deeply symbolic — just as olives were crushed to produce oil, Jesus was 'pressed' under the weight of the world's sin in this garden, sweating drops like blood.

intermediate.question: According to the Gospel of John, Jesus described the Holy Spirit as the 'Paraclete' (Helper/Advocate/Comforter) who would come after Jesus departed and would guide the disciples into all truth.
intermediate.explanation: In the Farewell Discourse (John 14-16), Jesus promised 'I will ask the Father, and he will give you another advocate (parakletos) to help you and be with you forever — the Spirit of truth.' The word 'parakletos' means 'one called alongside' — a helper, advocate, counsellor, or comforter. Jesus called the Spirit 'another' advocate, implying that Jesus himself had been their first advocate.

intermediate.question: During his trial before the Sanhedrin (Jewish council), Jesus refused to answer any questions and remained completely silent from arrest to crucifixion.
intermediate.explanation: While Jesus was largely silent during parts of his trial (fulfilling Isaiah 53:7 — 'like a sheep before its shearers is silent'), he did make several crucial statements. When the high priest asked 'Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?', Jesus replied 'I am... and you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One and coming on the clouds of heaven.' He also spoke to Pilate, Herod, and from the cross.

intermediate.question: The Gospel of Luke records that Jesus sent out 72 disciples (in addition to the twelve apostles) in pairs to go ahead of him to every town and place he was about to visit.
intermediate.explanation: In Luke 10:1, Jesus appointed 72 others and sent them two by two ahead of him to every town he was about to visit. He told them 'The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few.' They were to heal the sick and proclaim 'The kingdom of God has come near to you.' When they returned, they reported joyfully that even demons submitted to them in Jesus' name.

intermediate.question: When the resurrected Jesus appeared to his disciples, he proved he was not a ghost by eating a piece of broiled fish in front of them.
intermediate.explanation: Luke 24:36-43 records that when the risen Jesus appeared to the disciples, they were 'startled and frightened, thinking they saw a ghost.' Jesus said 'Touch me and see; a ghost does not have flesh and bones.' He showed them his hands and feet, but they still couldn't believe it 'because of joy and amazement.' So he asked 'Do you have anything here to eat?' and they gave him a piece of broiled fish, and he ate it in their presence.

intermediate.question: The parable of the talents (Matthew 25) teaches that God gives every person the same amount of resources and expects the same results from everyone.
intermediate.explanation: In the parable, the master gave different amounts to different servants — five talents to one, two to another, and one to the last — 'each according to his ability.' The master praised both the five-talent and two-talent servants equally ('Well done, good and faithful servant') because both doubled what they were given. The one-talent servant was condemned not for having less but for doing nothing. The parable teaches faithful stewardship of whatever you are given, not equal outcomes.

intermediate.question: Jesus used the phrase 'Truly, truly, I say to you' (or 'Verily, verily' in older translations) — the doubled 'Amen' — exclusively in the Gospel of John, and it appears 25 times, always introducing a statement of profound theological significance.
intermediate.explanation: The double 'Amen' (amen, amen) is unique to John's Gospel — the Synoptic Gospels use only a single 'Amen.' In Jewish usage, 'Amen' was spoken after someone else's statement to confirm it. Jesus' unprecedented use of 'Amen' before his own statements was a claim to supreme authority — he was, in effect, confirming the truth of his own words before speaking them, asserting divine authority.

intermediate.question: When Jesus healed ten lepers, all ten returned to thank him and worship at his feet, demonstrating the natural human response to miraculous healing.
intermediate.explanation: Only one of the ten returned to thank Jesus — and he was a Samaritan (a social and religious outsider). Jesus asked pointedly 'Were not all ten cleansed? Where are the other nine? Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner?' The story shows that gratitude is not a natural human response and that outsiders sometimes show more faith and gratitude than religious insiders.

intermediate.question: Jesus predicted the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem, saying 'Not one stone here will be left on another; every one will be thrown down.' This prophecy was fulfilled in AD 70 when the Romans destroyed Jerusalem.
intermediate.explanation: Jesus' prediction (Matthew 24:2) was fulfilled in AD 70 when the Roman general Titus besieged Jerusalem and destroyed the Temple. According to Josephus, the Romans set fire to the Temple and then literally pried apart the stones to recover the gold that had melted between them — fulfilling Jesus' words that not one stone would be left on another. The Temple has never been rebuilt.

intermediate.question: The raising of Lazarus from the dead (John 11) was such a powerful sign that it became one of the primary reasons the Jewish authorities decided Jesus had to be killed — a miracle so undeniable that it was drawing too many people to believe in him.
intermediate.explanation: John 11:45-53 records that after Lazarus' resurrection, many Jews put their faith in Jesus. The chief priests and Pharisees called an emergency council meeting. Caiaphas the high priest said 'It is better for you that one man die for the people than that the whole nation perish.' From that day on, they plotted to kill Jesus — and Lazarus too (John 12:10), because his living testimony was causing many to believe.

intermediate.question: When Jesus appeared to the disciples after his resurrection and Thomas was present, Thomas immediately believed without needing any physical proof, saying 'My Lord and my God!'
intermediate.explanation: Thomas was NOT present during Jesus' first appearance to the disciples and said 'Unless I see the nail marks in his hands and put my finger where the nails were, and put my hand into his side, I will not believe.' A week later, Jesus appeared again when Thomas was present and invited him to touch his wounds. Then Thomas exclaimed 'My Lord and my God!' Jesus responded 'Because you have seen me, you have believed; blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.'

intermediate.question: The Gospel accounts of Jesus' birth in Matthew and Luke provide complementary but distinct perspectives — Matthew tells the story primarily from Joseph's viewpoint (including the Magi, flight to Egypt, and return to Nazareth), while Luke tells it primarily from Mary's perspective (including the annunciation, the manger, and the shepherds).
intermediate.explanation: Matthew's account focuses on Joseph (who receives angelic dreams), the visit of the Magi, Herod's massacre, and the family's flight to Egypt. Luke's account focuses on Mary (Gabriel's annunciation, the Magnificat, Elizabeth's visit), the census, the manger, and the shepherds. Together they provide a fuller picture than either alone, with each evangelist selecting material that serves his theological purposes.

intermediate.question: Jesus cursed a fig tree for not bearing fruit, and it withered overnight. This was a purely botanical frustration — Jesus was simply hungry and annoyed — with no deeper symbolic meaning.
intermediate.explanation: The cursing of the fig tree (Mark 11:12-25) was a prophetic sign-act, not an outburst of frustration. In the Old Testament, the fig tree frequently symbolised Israel (Jeremiah 8:13, Hosea 9:10). Mark sandwiches the fig tree incident around the Temple cleansing (fig tree cursed → Temple cleansed → fig tree withered), creating an 'intercalation' that connects them: Israel (the fig tree) had produced impressive leaves (religious activity) but no fruit (genuine faithfulness), and judgment was coming.

intermediate.question: When Jesus walked on water, the disciple Peter also walked on water toward Jesus but began to sink when he looked at the wind and waves instead of keeping his eyes on Jesus.
intermediate.explanation: Peter said 'Lord, if it's you, tell me to come to you on the water.' Jesus said 'Come.' Peter got out of the boat and actually walked on the water toward Jesus. But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and began to sink, crying out 'Lord, save me!' Jesus immediately reached out his hand, caught him, and said 'You of little faith, why did you doubt?' It's a powerful picture of faith — and what happens when fear displaces it.

intermediate.question: Jesus spoke about money and possessions more than he spoke about heaven and hell combined, making finances one of the most frequent topics in his teaching.
intermediate.explanation: By most counts, Jesus spoke about money, wealth, and possessions in roughly 11 of his 39 parables and in numerous other teachings. About 1 in every 7 verses in the Synoptic Gospels relates to money. He spoke about money more than prayer, faith, or heaven and hell. Topics included the rich young ruler, the widow's mite, the talents, the rich fool, paying taxes, treasure in heaven, and the love of money as a rival to God.

intermediate.question: The high priest Caiaphas unknowingly prophesied when he said 'It is better for you that one man die for the people than that the whole nation perish.' John's Gospel notes that Caiaphas said this not on his own but as high priest that year, speaking a deeper truth than he realised.
intermediate.explanation: John 11:49-52 records Caiaphas' statement and adds: 'He did not say this on his own, but as high priest that year he prophesied that Jesus would die for the Jewish nation, and not only for that nation but also for the scattered children of God, to bring them together and make them one.' Caiaphas intended a cynical political calculation, but John reveals that God used even the words of Jesus' enemy to express the meaning of the cross.

intermediate.question: Paul's conversion on the road to Damascus, where the risen Jesus appeared to him in a blinding light, is considered by scholars to be one of the best-attested events in early Christianity because Paul describes it himself and it is recorded three times in Acts.
intermediate.explanation: Paul describes his encounter with the risen Jesus in his own letters (Galatians 1:12-16, 1 Corinthians 9:1, 15:8), and Luke records it three times in Acts (chapters 9, 22, 26). The transformation of Paul from Christianity's most violent persecutor to its most effective missionary is one of the strongest historical arguments for the reality of the resurrection. No adequate naturalistic explanation has been widely accepted for Paul's radical conversion.

intermediate.question: When Jesus washed his disciples' feet at the Last Supper, Peter initially refused, saying 'You shall never wash my feet!' Jesus responded that if he didn't wash Peter, Peter would have no part with him. Peter then asked Jesus to wash his hands and head too.
intermediate.explanation: Peter's refusal was based on his understanding of social hierarchy — a master should never wash a servant's feet. But when Jesus said 'Unless I wash you, you have no part with me,' Peter swung to the opposite extreme: 'Then, Lord, not just my feet but my hands and my head as well!' Jesus replied that someone who has bathed needs only to wash their feet. Peter's impulsive responses reveal his passionate but often misguided devotion.

intermediate.question: Jesus healed a man born blind by making mud with his saliva, putting it on the man's eyes, and telling him to wash in the Pool of Siloam. The man had never seen anything in his entire life until that moment.
intermediate.explanation: John 9 records this miracle in detail. Jesus spat on the ground, made mud, spread it on the blind man's eyes, and told him 'Go, wash in the Pool of Siloam.' The man went, washed, and came home seeing. The detail that he was born blind (not just temporarily blinded) made this miracle even more remarkable — it was the creation of sight, not merely restoration. The Pharisees interrogated the man and his parents but could not deny the miracle.

intermediate.question: After his resurrection, Jesus appeared to more than 500 people at one time, according to Paul's account in 1 Corinthians 15, most of whom were still alive when Paul wrote and could have been consulted.
intermediate.explanation: Paul writes in 1 Corinthians 15:6 that Jesus 'appeared to more than five hundred of the brothers and sisters at the same time, most of whom are still living, though some have fallen asleep.' Paul's mention that most were 'still living' is effectively an invitation to verify the claim — he was pointing to living eyewitnesses who could confirm or deny the appearance. This was written approximately AD 55, only about 25 years after the events.

intermediate.question: The parable of the Pharisee and the tax collector (Luke 18) teaches that the Pharisee's prayer was accepted by God because of his righteousness, while the tax collector was rejected because of his sinfulness.
intermediate.explanation: Jesus taught the exact opposite. The Pharisee prayed 'God, I thank you that I am not like other people — robbers, evildoers, adulterers — or even like this tax collector.' The tax collector wouldn't even look up to heaven but beat his chest saying 'God, have mercy on me, a sinner.' Jesus said the tax collector went home justified before God, not the Pharisee: 'For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.'

intermediate.question: Jesus taught that the two greatest commandments are to love God with all your heart, soul, and mind, and to love your neighbour as yourself — and he said 'All the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments.'
intermediate.explanation: When asked which commandment was greatest, Jesus quoted Deuteronomy 6:5 ('Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind') and added Leviticus 19:18 ('Love your neighbour as yourself'). He declared that all of the Law and the Prophets — the entire Old Testament — hang on these two commands. Every other commandment is an expression of loving God and loving people.

intermediate.question: When Herod Antipas (the ruler of Galilee) heard about Jesus' miracles and teaching, he initially thought Jesus might be John the Baptist risen from the dead — because Herod had earlier executed John the Baptist by beheading.
intermediate.explanation: Mark 6:14-16 records that when Herod heard about Jesus, he said 'John, whom I beheaded, has been raised from the dead!' Herod had arrested John the Baptist for criticising Herod's marriage to his brother's wife Herodias. At Herod's birthday party, Herodias' daughter danced and Herod rashly promised her anything. Prompted by her mother, she asked for John's head on a platter, and Herod reluctantly complied.

intermediate.question: According to the Gospel of John, Jesus' crucifixion took place on the same day that the Passover lambs were being slaughtered in the Temple, making Jesus the ultimate Passover sacrifice.
intermediate.explanation: John's chronology places Jesus' crucifixion on the Day of Preparation for Passover (John 19:14), meaning Jesus died at the same time the Passover lambs were being sacrificed in the Temple. Paul later explicitly states 'Christ, our Passover lamb, has been sacrificed' (1 Corinthians 5:7). John the Baptist had introduced Jesus as 'the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world' (John 1:29). The timing was theologically intentional.

intermediate.question: Jesus' hometown of Nazareth enthusiastically received him when he returned to teach in the synagogue. The people were proud that one of their own had become a famous teacher and prophet.
intermediate.explanation: Nazareth rejected Jesus dramatically. Initially amazed at his teaching, the people quickly turned hostile: 'Isn't this Joseph's son?' Jesus remarked 'Truly I tell you, no prophet is accepted in his hometown.' When he compared their unbelief to Israel's rejection of Elijah and Elisha, they were furious and drove him out of town, attempting to throw him off a cliff. 'He could not do any miracles there' because of their unbelief.

intermediate.question: The title 'Christ' is not a surname but a title meaning 'the Anointed One' — the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew word 'Messiah' — referring to the long-awaited deliverer prophesied throughout the Old Testament.
intermediate.explanation: 'Christ' (Greek: Christos) and 'Messiah' (Hebrew: Mashiach) both mean 'Anointed One.' In the Old Testament, prophets, priests, and kings were anointed with oil to signify God's appointment to their role. The Messiah was the ultimate anointed figure who would combine all three roles. 'Jesus Christ' is therefore not a first and last name but a name and title: 'Jesus the Anointed One' or 'Jesus the Messiah.'

intermediate.question: On the road to Emmaus, when Jesus opened the Scriptures and explained how the entire Old Testament pointed to the Messiah's suffering and glory, the two disciples said their hearts were 'burning within them' as he spoke — yet they only recognised him when he broke bread.
intermediate.explanation: Luke 24:32 records the disciples saying 'Were not our hearts burning within us while he talked with us on the road and opened the Scriptures to us?' Despite this inner stirring, their eyes were not opened until the breaking of bread — a eucharistic moment that echoed the Last Supper. The instant they recognised him, he vanished. They immediately returned to Jerusalem to tell the other disciples.

intermediate.question: When Jesus healed a paralysed man lowered through the roof by his friends, the Pharisees accused Jesus of blasphemy because he said 'Your sins are forgiven' — and in Jewish theology, only God had the authority to forgive sins.
intermediate.explanation: The scribes and Pharisees said 'Who is this fellow who speaks blasphemy? Who can forgive sins but God alone?' Jesus' response was brilliant: 'Which is easier: to say "Your sins are forgiven" or to say "Get up and walk"?' Then he healed the paralytic to demonstrate that he had authority on earth to forgive sins. The implication was clear: if he could do the visible miracle, he could do the invisible one too — he had divine authority.

intermediate.question: Jesus performed more miracles in and around the town of Capernaum, located on the shore of the Sea of Galilee, than in any other single location — making it his effective 'home base' during his Galilean ministry.
intermediate.explanation: After leaving Nazareth, Jesus made Capernaum his base of operations (Matthew 4:13 — he 'went to live in Capernaum'). It was called 'his own town' (Matthew 9:1). Here he healed Peter's mother-in-law, the centurion's servant, the paralytic lowered through the roof, Jairus' daughter, the woman with the bleeding, and many others. Despite these miracles, Jesus later pronounced judgment on Capernaum for its unbelief (Matthew 11:23).

intermediate.question: The Magnificat — Mary's song of praise after learning she would be the mother of Jesus — contains themes of social reversal: God scattering the proud, bringing down rulers, lifting up the humble, and filling the hungry while sending the rich away empty.
intermediate.explanation: Mary's song (Luke 1:46-55) echoes Hannah's prayer in 1 Samuel 2 and is revolutionary in its social vision: 'He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty.' The Magnificat presents the incarnation as God's dramatic intervention on behalf of the poor, the oppressed, and the marginalised — a central theme in Luke's Gospel.

intermediate.question: Jesus wept over the city of Jerusalem because he foresaw its coming destruction and lamented that the people had rejected the peace God offered them.
intermediate.explanation: Luke 19:41-44 records that as Jesus approached Jerusalem on Palm Sunday, 'he saw the city and wept over it,' saying 'If you, even you, had only known on this day what would bring you peace — but now it is hidden from your eyes. The days will come upon you when your enemies will build an embankment against you and encircle you... They will not leave one stone on another, because you did not recognise the time of God's coming to you.'

intermediate.question: The resurrection of Jesus is unique in ancient history because, unlike mythological 'dying and rising gods' of the ancient world, it was proclaimed by eyewitnesses within their own lifetime and within walking distance of the events — where it could have been easily disproven.
intermediate.explanation: Unlike mythological resurrection stories (which were set in primordial time or distant locations), the early Christians proclaimed Jesus' resurrection in Jerusalem — where it happened — beginning just weeks after the event. The empty tomb could have been examined, and living eyewitnesses could have been questioned. Paul's early creed (1 Corinthians 15:3-7) lists specific, named witnesses, most of whom were still alive when he wrote. This proximity to the events in time and place is historically unique.
