advanced.question: The Gospel of Mark's Christology presents Jesus as gradually coming to understand his own divine identity during his ministry — starting as a simple teacher and only later realising he was the Messiah.
advanced.explanation: Mark presents Jesus as fully aware of his identity from the very beginning. The Gospel opens with 'The beginning of the gospel about Jesus the Messiah, the Son of God' (1:1). At his baptism, the divine voice affirms his identity. He commands demons who recognise him to be silent (the 'Messianic Secret'). What develops in Mark is not Jesus' self-understanding but the disciples' understanding of who Jesus is. The secrecy is strategic, not existential.

advanced.question: The concept of 'substitutionary atonement' — the idea that Jesus died 'in our place,' bearing the penalty for human sin — is found exclusively in later theological reflection by Paul and the church fathers, with no basis in Jesus' own words as recorded in the Gospels.
advanced.explanation: Jesus himself used substitutionary language. Mark 10:45 records Jesus saying 'The Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom (lytron) for (anti — meaning 'in place of') many.' At the Last Supper, he said 'This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins' (Matthew 26:28). The 'ransom' metaphor and 'for many' language (echoing Isaiah 53) indicate Jesus understood his death as substitutionary.

advanced.question: The earliest Christians worshipped Jesus as divine from the very beginning of the church, not as a result of gradual theological evolution over centuries of Greek philosophical influence.
advanced.explanation: Larry Hurtado's research demonstrates that 'devotion to Christ as divine' emerged explosively early — within the first two decades of Christianity. The pre-Pauline creed of 1 Corinthians 15:3-7 (dated to within 3-5 years of the crucifixion), the Aramaic prayer 'Maranatha' ('Come, Lord!' — 1 Corinthians 16:22), and the Christ-hymn of Philippians 2:6-11 all testify to divine worship of Jesus in the earliest, Jewish, pre-Hellenistic stage of Christianity.

advanced.question: The four canonical Gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John) were the only accounts of Jesus' life ever written in the early centuries of Christianity — no other 'gospels' existed.
advanced.explanation: Numerous non-canonical gospels were written, including the Gospel of Thomas, Gospel of Peter, Gospel of Philip, Gospel of Judas, Gospel of Mary, Infancy Gospel of Thomas, and Protevangelium of James, among others. Most date from the 2nd-4th centuries and reflect later theological developments (particularly Gnostic theology). The four canonical Gospels were recognised as authoritative because of their early date, apostolic connection, and wide acceptance across diverse Christian communities.

advanced.question: The 'criterion of multiple attestation' — a tool used in historical Jesus studies — holds that a tradition about Jesus is more likely historical if it appears in multiple independent sources (e.g., Mark, Q, Paul, John, or special Matthean/Lukan material) rather than in only one source.
advanced.explanation: Multiple attestation is considered one of the strongest indicators of historicity. When a tradition about Jesus appears independently in Mark, the Q source (material common to Matthew and Luke but absent from Mark), Paul's letters, John's Gospel, or unique Matthean/Lukan material, it demonstrates widespread early tradition rather than the invention of a single author. The Last Supper, the crucifixion, and the empty tomb are all multiply attested.

advanced.question: John's Gospel presents a significantly different chronological framework for Jesus' ministry compared to the Synoptic Gospels — notably placing the Temple cleansing at the beginning rather than the end, and recording three Passover feasts (suggesting a three-year ministry) versus the Synoptics' apparent one Passover (suggesting a one-year ministry).
advanced.explanation: The Synoptic Gospels mention only one Passover (the final one) and their narrative could compress Jesus' ministry into approximately one year. John records three Passovers (2:13, 6:4, 11:55) and possibly a fourth (5:1), establishing a ministry of at least three years. John also places the Temple cleansing at the beginning (chapter 2) while the Synoptics place it in the final week. These differences reflect John's more thematic/theological arrangement versus the Synoptics' more chronological approach.

advanced.question: The Roman historian Tacitus, writing around AD 116, mentions 'Christus' who 'suffered the extreme penalty during the reign of Tiberius at the hands of one of our procurators, Pontius Pilatus' — providing independent non-Christian confirmation of Jesus' execution under Pilate.
advanced.explanation: Tacitus' Annals 15.44 is one of the most important non-Christian references to Jesus. Writing about Nero's persecution of Christians after the Great Fire of Rome (AD 64), Tacitus notes that the movement originated from 'Christus' who was executed by Pontius Pilate during Tiberius' reign. As a Roman senator with access to imperial archives, Tacitus is considered a highly reliable historian. His hostile tone toward Christianity makes Christian interpolation extremely unlikely.

advanced.question: The 'high priestly prayer' of Jesus in John 17 — his longest recorded prayer — is focused primarily on Jesus' own needs and desires, asking the Father for personal glory and vindication.
advanced.explanation: While Jesus does pray 'Father, glorify me' (17:5), the prayer is overwhelmingly focused on others. Jesus prays for his disciples' unity (17:11, 21-23), protection (17:11, 15), sanctification in truth (17:17), and joy (17:13). He then extends his prayer beyond the twelve to 'those who will believe in me through their message' (17:20) — every future believer. The prayer moves from Jesus' relationship with the Father, to the immediate disciples, to the universal church. It is profoundly other-centered.

advanced.question: The fact that women were the first witnesses to the empty tomb and the resurrection strongly supports historicity, because in first-century Jewish and Roman culture, women's testimony was considered unreliable and would not have been chosen if the story were being fabricated.
advanced.explanation: This argument, known as the 'criterion of embarrassment,' is widely accepted by scholars across the theological spectrum. Josephus and the Mishnah indicate that women's testimony was generally not accepted in Jewish courts. If the early church were inventing the resurrection story, they would have chosen male witnesses — especially prominent apostles — to make the account credible. The fact that women are consistently named as the first witnesses in all four Gospels suggests the accounts reflect what actually happened, not what the church would have preferred.

advanced.question: The Gospel of Thomas, discovered at Nag Hammadi in 1945, is widely regarded by mainstream scholars as more historically reliable than the canonical Gospels for reconstructing the authentic words of Jesus.
advanced.explanation: While the Gospel of Thomas contains some sayings that may preserve early independent tradition, the majority of scholars do not consider it more reliable than the canonical Gospels overall. It is typically dated to the mid-to-late 2nd century (though some argue for an earlier core). It reflects Gnostic theology, has no passion or resurrection narrative, and many of its sayings appear to be secondary modifications of canonical Gospel material. Some scholars (like those in the Jesus Seminar) gave it higher weight, but this remains a minority position.
advanced.reference: Gospel of Thomas, Nag Hammadi scholarship

advanced.question: The phrase 'born again' (or 'born from above'), which Jesus used in his conversation with Nicodemus (John 3), relies on a deliberate ambiguity in the Greek word 'anothen,' which can mean either 'again' (a second time) or 'from above' (from heaven).
advanced.explanation: The Greek word 'anothen' is intentionally ambiguous — it means both 'again' (which Nicodemus understood literally: 'How can someone be born when they are old? Can they enter a second time into their mother's womb?') and 'from above' (which is Jesus' intended spiritual meaning — a heavenly, divine rebirth by the Holy Spirit). This double meaning is a literary device characteristic of John's Gospel, where misunderstandings become teaching opportunities.

advanced.question: The Apostle Paul, who wrote the earliest New Testament documents, never met Jesus during Jesus' earthly ministry and never claims to have received any information about Jesus from other apostles or eyewitnesses.
advanced.explanation: While Paul did not follow Jesus during his earthly ministry, he explicitly claims to have received tradition from others. In 1 Corinthians 15:3, he says 'I delivered to you as of first importance what I also received' — using technical rabbinic terms for formal transmission of tradition. Galatians 1:18 records his visit with Peter for 15 days, and he also met James. Paul received both his direct encounter with the risen Christ (Damascus road) AND formal tradition from the Jerusalem apostles.

advanced.question: The theological concept of the 'Incarnation' — that God became fully human in Jesus without ceasing to be fully God — is universally regarded by theologians as a perfectly logical, easily comprehensible doctrine that presents no philosophical difficulties.
advanced.explanation: The Incarnation is widely acknowledged as one of the most profound mysteries in Christian theology. How can one person be both fully God and fully human? How can the infinite become finite? How can the omniscient experience ignorance? Early church councils (Nicaea, Chalcedon) formulated boundaries — Jesus is 'truly God and truly man... without confusion, change, division, or separation' — but explicitly acknowledged that the full 'how' transcends human comprehension. It is a 'mystery' in the theological sense — a reality that exceeds, but does not contradict, reason.

advanced.question: The account of Jesus sweating 'drops of blood' in Gethsemane (Luke 22:44) describes a recognised medical condition called hematidrosis, which can occur under extreme psychological stress when capillaries in the sweat glands rupture and mix blood with perspiration.
advanced.explanation: Hematidrosis (also called hematohidrosis) is a rare but medically documented condition where extreme anxiety or emotional stress causes capillaries feeding the sweat glands to rupture, producing sweat tinged with blood. It has been observed in soldiers facing execution, prisoners before torture, and individuals under extreme emotional distress. Luke, traditionally identified as a physician (Colossians 4:14), is the only Gospel writer who records this detail, possibly reflecting medical awareness.

advanced.question: The early church's proclamation that Jesus rose 'on the third day' likely carries theological significance beyond simple chronology — in Jewish thought, the third day was associated with divine deliverance, reversal, and rescue.
advanced.explanation: The 'third day' motif runs throughout the Old Testament: Joseph released his brothers on the third day (Genesis 42:18), God appeared at Sinai on the third day (Exodus 19:11), Jonah was in the fish three days (Jonah 1:17), Hosea prophesied 'On the third day he will raise us up' (Hosea 6:2), and Esther approached the king on the third day (Esther 5:1). In Jewish tradition, the third day was the day God acts to deliver. Jesus' resurrection 'on the third day' fulfils this theological pattern of divine rescue.

advanced.question: The phrase 'right hand of God' — used to describe Jesus' position after the ascension — was understood in ancient Jewish thought as a metaphor for sharing in God's sovereign authority and power, not as a reference to a literal physical location in space.
advanced.explanation: Psalm 110:1 ('The LORD says to my lord: Sit at my right hand') was the most frequently quoted Old Testament verse in the New Testament. The 'right hand' in ancient Near Eastern court imagery was the position of highest honour and co-regency. When Stephen sees Jesus 'standing at the right hand of God' (Acts 7:55), it signifies Jesus sharing God's throne and exercising divine authority — a claim to full deity. It describes a relational/authority position, not a GPS coordinate.

advanced.question: The 'Q source' (from German 'Quelle' meaning 'source') is a hypothetical document containing primarily sayings of Jesus that scholars believe was used by both Matthew and Luke but not Mark. No physical copy of Q has ever been found.
advanced.explanation: Q is a hypothetical reconstruction based on material common to Matthew and Luke that is absent from Mark (approximately 235 verses). Since Matthew and Luke appear to have independently used this shared material (their wording often agrees closely where it overlaps), scholars posit a written source they both accessed. Q is estimated to have been composed around AD 50-60. While no copy has been found, its existence is accepted by the majority of New Testament scholars, though some (like Mark Goodacre) argue Luke used Matthew directly.

advanced.question: The resurrection narratives in the Gospels describe Jesus' post-resurrection body as identical in every way to a normal human body — with no unusual properties or capabilities beyond those of any living person.
advanced.explanation: The Gospels describe Jesus' resurrection body as both continuous with his pre-death body (he had the same wounds, he ate fish, he could be touched) and transformed in remarkable ways. He appeared inside locked rooms (John 20:19, 26), was initially unrecognised by people who knew him (Luke 24:16, John 20:14), vanished from sight (Luke 24:31), and eventually ascended to heaven. Paul describes this as a 'spiritual body' (1 Corinthians 15:44) — not a non-physical body, but a body fully animated and transformed by the Spirit.

advanced.question: The parables of Jesus were simple illustrations that any listener could understand immediately — they required no effort, context, or explanation, and Jesus never had to explain their meaning to anyone.
advanced.explanation: Jesus explicitly stated that parables concealed meaning from casual listeners while revealing it to committed disciples: 'The knowledge of the secrets of the kingdom of God has been given to you, but to others I speak in parables, so that seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand' (Luke 8:10). The disciples frequently asked for explanations (e.g., the parable of the sower, the wheat and tares). Parables functioned as 'subversive speech' — they drew listeners in and then upended their assumptions.

advanced.question: N.T. Wright's argument for the historicity of the resurrection emphasises that the early Christians' belief cannot be explained by Jewish precedent alone, because no Jews expected a single individual to be resurrected in the middle of history — resurrection was expected to happen to all people at the end of time.
advanced.explanation: Wright argues that Jewish belief in resurrection was (1) corporate (all the righteous, not one individual), (2) eschatological (at the end of history, not in the middle), and (3) physical (bodily, not spiritual). The Christian proclamation of one man resurrected in the middle of history, while the rest of the dead remained dead, was unprecedented in Judaism. No Jewish framework predicted or expected this. Wright contends that only an actual event — not theological reflection or grief experiences — can explain this unprecedented mutation in Jewish belief.
advanced.reference: N.T. Wright, 'The Resurrection of the Son of God'

advanced.question: The literary genre of the Gospels is best classified as ancient Greco-Roman biography (bios) rather than modern biography, myth, or fiction — they follow the conventions of biographical writing in the ancient world while containing distinctive theological interpretation.
advanced.explanation: Richard Burridge's groundbreaking work 'What Are the Gospels?' demonstrated that the Gospels match the formal features of Greco-Roman 'bioi': they focus on a single subject, open with origins/early life, cover the subject's public career, devote disproportionate space to death, and aim to inform and persuade. They are not modern biographies (they lack psychological analysis and strict chronology), not myths (they are rooted in specific historical times and places), and not fiction. They are theological biographies of Jesus.

advanced.question: The 'Son of Man' title that Jesus preferred was ambiguous and strategic — it could simply mean 'a human being' (as in Ezekiel) or could evoke the divine cosmic figure of Daniel 7, allowing Jesus to reveal his identity progressively without triggering premature confrontation.
advanced.explanation: The genius of 'Son of Man' as Jesus' preferred self-designation lies in its ambiguity. In Aramaic ('bar enasha'), it could simply mean 'a man' or 'someone.' In Ezekiel, it means 'mere mortal.' But in Daniel 7:13-14, the 'one like a son of man' is a heavenly figure who receives universal, everlasting dominion. By using this title, Jesus could speak about himself publicly while concealing the full import of his claims from casual listeners — revealing his divine authority progressively as the context demanded.

advanced.question: The early Christian hymn preserved in Philippians 2:6-11 is considered by many scholars to be pre-Pauline — meaning it was composed and circulated before Paul included it in his letter, making it one of the earliest theological compositions about Jesus' divine identity.
advanced.explanation: Most scholars regard Philippians 2:6-11 as a pre-Pauline hymn or creed that Paul incorporated into his letter (written around AD 60-62). Evidence includes its elevated poetic structure, vocabulary unusual for Paul, and theological density. If pre-Pauline, it dates to the AD 30s-50s — extremely early evidence that Christians confessed Jesus as one who was 'in the form of God' and worthy of universal worship ('every knee should bow... every tongue acknowledge that Jesus Christ is Lord'). This pre-dates any possible Hellenistic philosophical influence.

advanced.question: The destruction of Jerusalem and the Temple in AD 70 had no significant impact on how the Gospels were written or how early Christians understood Jesus' predictions — the Gospels were written purely from theological interest with no relationship to contemporary historical events.
advanced.explanation: The destruction of Jerusalem in AD 70 profoundly influenced Gospel composition. Mark (written around AD 65-70) may reflect the approaching crisis. Matthew and Luke (written after AD 70) show awareness of the destruction in how they present Jesus' predictions (Luke 21:20-24 specifies 'armies surrounding Jerusalem'). The fall of the Temple validated Jesus' prophecy and forced Christians to rethink the relationship between Jesus, the Temple, and God's presence. John's Gospel may present Jesus as the new Temple (John 2:21) partly in response to the Temple's destruction.

advanced.question: The theological concept known as 'recapitulation' — developed by the early church father Irenaeus (c. AD 130-202) — teaches that Jesus 'recapitulated' (relived and reversed) the entire story of Adam and humanity, succeeding at every point where Adam failed.
advanced.explanation: Irenaeus' recapitulation theory ('anakephalaiosis') presents Jesus as the 'Second Adam' who reverses the damage of the first Adam by reliving human experience and getting it right. Where Adam was tempted in a garden of abundance and fell, Jesus was tempted in a wilderness of deprivation and stood firm. Where Adam's disobedience brought death, Jesus' obedience brings life. Paul lays the groundwork: 'As in Adam all die, so in Christ all will be made alive' (1 Corinthians 15:22). Jesus doesn't just forgive the Fall — he reverses it.

advanced.question: The Johannine 'signs source' hypothesis proposes that the author of the Fourth Gospel may have drawn upon an earlier written collection of Jesus' miracles, which he called 'signs,' and that this source can be partially reconstructed from the text of John's Gospel.
advanced.explanation: Rudolf Bultmann and subsequent scholars have proposed that John used a 'Semeia (Signs) Source' — a pre-existing collection of Jesus' miracles originally compiled for evangelistic purposes. Evidence includes: the numbering of signs (John 2:11 — 'first sign'; 4:54 — 'second sign'), the concluding summary statement (20:30 — 'Jesus performed many other signs'), and occasional seams between narrative sections that may indicate source integration. While the hypothesis is debated, it explains certain literary features of John's Gospel.

advanced.question: Jesus' practice of calling God 'Abba' (an Aramaic term of intimate familial address, similar to 'Papa' or 'Daddy') was completely unprecedented in Jewish prayer and represented a radically new way of relating to God.
advanced.explanation: While Jesus' use of 'Abba' was distinctive, calling it 'completely unprecedented' overstates the case. Joachim Jeremias originally argued that no Jew ever addressed God as 'Abba,' but subsequent research (by scholars like James Barr and Mary Rose D'Angelo) has shown that Jewish literature does contain examples of intimate divine address. What remains distinctive is the frequency, consistency, and centrality of 'Abba' in Jesus' prayer life, and his teaching that all his followers could address God this way. The intimacy is real but not entirely without parallel.

advanced.question: The empty tomb tradition is attested independently in multiple early Christian sources — Mark, the pre-Pauline creed in 1 Corinthians 15 ('he was buried... he was raised'), John's independent account, and possibly the early preaching in Acts — making it one of the best-attested facts of early Christianity.
advanced.explanation: The empty tomb is attested in Mark (the earliest Gospel), is implied by the burial-resurrection sequence in the pre-Pauline creed of 1 Corinthians 15:4 (burial implies a tomb; resurrection implies the tomb was vacated), appears independently in John 20, and is assumed in the early preaching of Acts (2:29 — David's tomb is 'here to this day,' implying Jesus' tomb is NOT). Even many sceptical scholars (like Gerd Lüdemann) accept the empty tomb as historical, though they propose alternative explanations for it.

advanced.question: The 'Farewell Discourse' of Jesus in John 13-17 functions as a 'testament' or 'farewell address' — a well-known literary genre in ancient Jewish literature where a dying patriarch gives final instructions, predictions, and blessings to his successors.
advanced.explanation: The Farewell Discourse follows the pattern of the 'testamentary genre' found in Genesis 49 (Jacob's farewell), Deuteronomy 31-33 (Moses' farewell), and the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs. Common features include: awareness of approaching death, final instructions for the community, predictions of future events, comfort in the face of separation, and a prayer/blessing. John shapes Jesus' final teaching in this familiar literary form, presenting Jesus as the ultimate patriarch whose departing words establish the new covenant community.

advanced.question: The concept of 'realised eschatology' (associated with C.H. Dodd) argues that all eschatological promises were completely fulfilled in Jesus' first coming — there is nothing remaining to be fulfilled in the future, no second coming, and no future consummation.
advanced.explanation: While C.H. Dodd's 'realised eschatology' emphasised that the kingdom of God was powerfully present in Jesus' ministry ('The kingdom of God has come upon you' — Matthew 12:28), the pure form that denies any future dimension is not widely held. Most scholars today adopt 'inaugurated eschatology' (George Eldon Ladd, N.T. Wright) — the kingdom is 'already' present but 'not yet' fully consummated. Jesus taught both present reality (Luke 17:21) and future expectation (Matthew 25:31-46, the Lord's Prayer: 'Your kingdom come').

beginner.question: At a wedding celebration in the village of Cana, the hosts ran out of wine — a serious social embarrassment. Jesus' mother told him about the problem, and Jesus instructed the servants to fill six large stone jars with water. What happened when the servants drew out the liquid?
options: The water remained water but tasted better
The water had turned into wine — and the best wine the master of the banquet had ever tasted
The jars overflowed with milk and honey
The water turned into grape juice
beginner.explanation: This was Jesus' first recorded miracle. The master of the banquet tasted the water-turned-wine and was amazed, telling the bridegroom 'Everyone brings out the choice wine first... but you have saved the best till now!' John calls this 'the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory,' and his disciples believed in him.

beginner.question: A huge crowd of over 5,000 men (plus women and children) had been listening to Jesus teach all day in a remote area. The disciples wanted to send the hungry crowd away, but a young boy offered his small lunch. What did this boy's lunch consist of?
options: Seven loaves and a few small fish
Five barley loaves and two small fish
Three loaves of wheat bread and five fish
Ten rolls and one large fish
beginner.explanation: The boy had five small barley loaves (the cheapest bread, eaten by the poor) and two small fish. Jesus took this tiny offering, gave thanks, and distributed it to the entire crowd. Everyone ate until satisfied, and the disciples collected twelve baskets of leftovers — one for each apostle. This is the only miracle besides the resurrection recorded in all four Gospels.

beginner.question: The disciples were crossing the Sea of Galilee at night when a violent storm arose, threatening to capsize their boat. They were terrified — but then they saw Jesus approaching in a way that seemed impossible. How was Jesus coming toward them?
options: Swimming through the storm
Riding on a dolphin
Walking on the surface of the water
Flying through the clouds
beginner.explanation: Jesus walked on the stormy sea toward the boat. The disciples were terrified, thinking he was a ghost. Jesus called out 'Take courage! It is I. Don't be afraid.' Peter asked to come to Jesus on the water and actually did — until he looked at the waves, lost faith, and began to sink. Jesus caught him, saying 'You of little faith, why did you doubt?'

beginner.question: Jesus and his disciples were caught in a terrifying storm on the Sea of Galilee. Waves were crashing over the boat and the disciples feared they would drown. But Jesus was asleep in the stern. When the panicked disciples woke him, what did Jesus do to stop the storm?
options: He prayed for hours until the storm passed
He simply spoke to the wind and waves, saying 'Quiet! Be still!' and everything became immediately calm
He raised his hands and a shield of light appeared
He told the disciples to row harder
beginner.explanation: Jesus rebuked the wind and said to the waves 'Quiet! Be still!' Immediately the wind died down and the sea became completely calm. Then he asked the disciples 'Why are you so afraid? Do you still have no faith?' They were even more terrified by the calm than by the storm, saying 'Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!'

beginner.question: In the town of Capernaum, four friends were so determined to get their paralysed friend to Jesus that they couldn't be stopped by the large crowd blocking the door. They came up with a creative way to reach Jesus. What did they do?
options: They pushed through the crowd by force
They climbed onto the roof, made a hole in it, and lowered their friend down on his mat right in front of Jesus
They waited outside until the crowd left
They shouted through the window for Jesus to come out
beginner.explanation: The four friends carried the paralysed man up to the flat roof, dug through the clay and branches that made up the roofing material, and lowered him on his mat right in front of Jesus. Jesus, 'seeing their faith,' first said 'Son, your sins are forgiven,' then proved his authority by saying 'Get up, take your mat and go home.' The man stood up and walked out in full view of everyone.

beginner.question: Jesus encountered a man who was possessed by many demons and lived among the tombs, crying out and cutting himself with stones. No one could restrain him, not even with chains. When Jesus cast the demons out, he allowed them to enter a herd of animals nearby. What kind of animals were they?
options: Sheep
Goats
Pigs (swine)
Cattle
beginner.explanation: The demons called themselves 'Legion, for we are many' and begged Jesus not to send them out of the area. Jesus allowed them to enter a herd of about 2,000 pigs, which then rushed down the steep bank into the Sea of Galilee and drowned. The healed man was found 'sitting there, dressed and in his right mind.' The local people were so frightened that they asked Jesus to leave.

beginner.question: A synagogue leader named Jairus came to Jesus in desperation because his twelve-year-old daughter was dying. By the time Jesus reached the house, messengers arrived saying the girl had died. But Jesus went in, took the dead girl by the hand, and spoke to her. What Aramaic words did Jesus say?
options: 'Ephphatha' — 'Be opened'
'Talitha koum' — 'Little girl, I say to you, get up'
'Eloi, Eloi' — 'My God, my God'
'Maranatha' — 'Come, Lord'
beginner.explanation: Jesus told the mourners 'The child is not dead but asleep,' and they laughed at him. He put them all out, took the girl's hand, and said 'Talitha koum!' which means 'Little girl, I say to you, get up!' The girl immediately stood up and began walking around. Jesus told her parents to give her something to eat, and strictly ordered them not to tell anyone.

beginner.question: A woman had been suffering from constant bleeding for twelve long years. She had spent all her money on doctors but only grew worse. She believed that if she could just touch Jesus' clothing, she would be healed. When she touched the edge of his cloak in the crowd, what happened?
options: Nothing happened at first and she had to ask Jesus directly
Her bleeding stopped instantly, and Jesus felt power go out from him and asked 'Who touched my clothes?'
Jesus turned around and laid his hands on her head
She fainted and Jesus carried her to safety
beginner.explanation: The moment she touched his cloak, her bleeding stopped and she felt in her body that she was freed from her suffering. Jesus immediately knew that power had gone out from him and asked 'Who touched me?' The terrified woman fell at his feet and told the whole truth. Jesus said 'Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace and be freed from your suffering.'

beginner.question: Jesus' close friend Lazarus became seriously ill and died. By the time Jesus arrived in Bethany, Lazarus had been dead and sealed in a tomb for four days. His sister Martha warned that there would be a terrible smell. What did Jesus do at the tomb?
options: He prayed silently for several hours
He wept, then commanded 'Lazarus, come out!' and Lazarus walked out alive, still wrapped in burial cloths
He went into the tomb to anoint the body
He told the family to have faith and wait for the resurrection
beginner.explanation: Jesus first wept at the tomb (the shortest verse in the Bible). Then he told them to remove the stone. He prayed aloud so the crowd would believe, then shouted in a loud voice 'Lazarus, come out!' The dead man came out, his hands and feet wrapped in linen strips, his face covered with a cloth. Jesus said 'Take off the grave clothes and let him go.' Many Jews who witnessed this put their faith in Jesus.

beginner.question: In the Old Testament, God parted a large body of water so that the Israelites could escape from the Egyptian army on dry ground. Moses stretched out his hand and God drove the sea back with a strong wind all night. Which body of water was parted?
options: The Jordan River
The Mediterranean Sea
The Red Sea (or Sea of Reeds)
The Dead Sea
beginner.explanation: The Israelites were trapped between the Egyptian army and the Red Sea (or 'Sea of Reeds' in Hebrew). Moses stretched out his hand and God sent a powerful east wind that divided the waters, creating walls of water on both sides with dry ground in between. The Israelites crossed safely. When the Egyptians followed, God released the waters and the entire army was drowned.

beginner.question: When the Israelites wandered in the wilderness after leaving Egypt, they ran out of food and complained to Moses. God promised to provide food from heaven every morning. Each day, the people found thin flakes on the ground that tasted like wafers made with honey. What was this heavenly food called?
options: Angel bread
Manna
Heavenly grain
God's provision
beginner.explanation: The Israelites called it 'manna,' which likely comes from the Hebrew 'man hu' meaning 'What is it?' because they didn't know what it was. God provided manna six days a week for 40 years. They were told to gather only enough for one day (it would rot if stored), except on the sixth day when they gathered double because none appeared on the Sabbath.

beginner.question: The prophet Elijah had a dramatic showdown with 450 prophets of the false god Baal on Mount Carmel. Each side built an altar and called on their god to send fire from heaven. The prophets of Baal danced and shouted all day but nothing happened. When Elijah prayed, what happened?
options: A gentle rain fell on Elijah's altar
Fire fell from heaven and consumed the sacrifice, the wood, the stones, the soil, and even the water in the trench around the altar
Lightning struck both altars simultaneously
A voice from heaven declared Elijah the winner
beginner.explanation: To make the challenge even harder, Elijah had drenched his altar with twelve jars of water. When he prayed, fire fell from heaven and burned up the sacrifice, the wood, the stones, the soil, and licked up all the water in the trench. The people fell on their faces and cried 'The LORD — he is God! The LORD — he is God!'

beginner.question: Three young Jewish men — Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego — refused to bow down to a golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up. As punishment, they were thrown into a blazing furnace heated seven times hotter than normal. What happened to them inside the fire?
options: They were severely burned but survived
They were completely unharmed, and the king saw a fourth figure walking with them in the flames
Angels put out the fire immediately
The furnace collapsed around them but they escaped
beginner.explanation: When Nebuchadnezzar looked into the furnace, he was astonished: 'I see four men walking around in the fire, unbound and unharmed, and the fourth looks like a son of the gods.' The three men came out without a single hair singed, without their robes scorched, and without even the smell of smoke on them. Nebuchadnezzar praised their God and promoted them.

beginner.question: The prophet Daniel continued to pray to God three times a day despite a new law making it illegal to pray to anyone except the king. His enemies reported him and he was thrown into a den of lions as punishment. What happened to Daniel in the lions' den?
options: He fought off the lions with his bare hands
God sent an angel who shut the lions' mouths, and Daniel was found the next morning without a scratch
The lions were already asleep when he was thrown in
Daniel tamed the lions and they became his pets
beginner.explanation: King Darius, who liked Daniel but was forced by his own law to punish him, rushed to the den at first light and called out anxiously. Daniel answered that God had sent an angel to shut the lions' mouths because he was found innocent before God. Daniel was lifted out without a single wound. The king then threw Daniel's accusers into the den, and the lions overpowered them instantly.

beginner.question: A prophet named Jonah tried to run away from God's command to preach to Nineveh by boarding a ship sailing in the opposite direction. God sent a violent storm and Jonah was thrown overboard. What happened to Jonah in the sea?
options: He drowned and God raised him from the dead
A great fish swallowed him and he lived inside it for three days and three nights before being vomited onto dry land
He was rescued by passing sailors
Dolphins carried him safely to shore
beginner.explanation: God provided a great fish (often called a whale) that swallowed Jonah. Inside the fish for three days and three nights, Jonah prayed a prayer of repentance and thanksgiving. The fish then vomited him onto dry land, and Jonah went to Nineveh as God had originally commanded. Jesus later referenced this miracle as a sign pointing to his own three days in the tomb.

beginner.question: When Jesus visited the Pool of Bethesda in Jerusalem, he found a man who had been unable to walk for 38 years. The man explained that he had no one to help him into the pool when the water was stirred. What did Jesus say to heal him?
options: 'Your faith has made you well'
'Go and wash in the Pool of Siloam'
'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk'
'Be clean!'
beginner.explanation: Jesus asked the man a profound question first: 'Do you want to get well?' The man made excuses about having no one to help him. Jesus simply said 'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.' The man was instantly healed, picked up his mat, and walked. This miracle happened on the Sabbath, which angered the religious leaders who accused Jesus of breaking Sabbath rules.

beginner.question: Jesus encountered a man who had been born completely blind — he had never seen anything in his entire life. Jesus healed him in an unusual way. What method did Jesus use to give this man his sight?
options: He simply touched the man's eyes and they opened
He made mud with his saliva, put it on the man's eyes, and told him to wash in the Pool of Siloam
He prayed over the man for several hours
He breathed on the man's face
beginner.explanation: Jesus spat on the ground, made mud with the saliva, and applied it to the blind man's eyes. Then he told him 'Go, wash in the Pool of Siloam.' The man went, washed, and came back seeing for the first time in his life. When the Pharisees interrogated him about how he was healed, he gave the unforgettable answer: 'One thing I do know. I was blind but now I see!'

beginner.question: When the Israelites were about to enter the Promised Land, they needed to cross the Jordan River. God performed a miracle similar to the Red Sea crossing. What happened when the priests carrying the Ark of the Covenant stepped into the river?
options: A bridge of stone appeared
The water piled up in a heap upstream, and the riverbed became dry so all the people could cross on dry ground
The river became shallow enough to wade across
A strong wind dried up the entire river permanently
beginner.explanation: As soon as the priests' feet touched the water's edge, the Jordan River — which was at flood stage — stopped flowing. The water piled up in a heap far upstream while the priests stood in the middle of the dry riverbed holding the Ark. All Israel crossed on dry ground. God told Joshua to have twelve stones taken from the riverbed as a memorial of this miracle.

beginner.question: A Roman centurion (military officer) came to Jesus asking him to heal his servant who was paralysed and suffering terribly. When Jesus offered to go to his house, the centurion said something that amazed Jesus more than anything anyone in Israel had said. What did the centurion say?
options: 'Please hurry, my servant is dying'
'I am not worthy for you to come under my roof. Just say the word, and my servant will be healed'
'I will pay you anything if you heal him'
'I have heard of your great miracles and I believe'
beginner.explanation: The centurion understood authority — as a military commander, he knew that when he gave an order, it was carried out even from a distance. He believed Jesus had the same authority over sickness. Jesus was amazed and said 'Truly I tell you, I have not found anyone in Israel with such great faith.' The servant was healed at that very hour, without Jesus ever visiting the house.

beginner.question: Jesus was walking to the house of Jairus (whose daughter was dying) when a large crowd pressed around him. On the way, Jesus stopped because he felt power go out from him when someone in the crowd touched his cloak. Who had touched him?
options: A blind man hoping to see
A woman who had been bleeding for twelve years
A leper who wanted to be clean
A child who wanted a blessing
beginner.explanation: A woman who had been suffering from bleeding for twelve years had spent everything she had on doctors but only got worse. She thought 'If I just touch his clothes, I will be healed.' The moment she touched his cloak, her bleeding stopped. Jesus felt power go out from him, stopped, and asked 'Who touched me?' The woman confessed and Jesus said 'Your faith has healed you. Go in peace.'

beginner.question: Jesus was travelling when he came across a funeral procession in the town of Nain. A widow was weeping because her only son had died — meaning she had lost her husband and now her only child, leaving her with no support. What did Jesus do?
options: He comforted her with words of encouragement
He touched the coffin and said 'Young man, I say to you, get up!' and the dead man sat up and began to talk
He promised her that God would provide
He prayed for her and gave her money
beginner.explanation: Jesus' heart went out to the widow. He told her 'Don't cry,' then walked up and touched the bier (coffin). He said 'Young man, I say to you, get up!' The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother. The crowd was filled with awe and praised God, saying 'A great prophet has appeared among us!' News of this spread throughout Judea.

beginner.question: A man came to Jesus begging for help because his son was possessed by a spirit that threw him into fire and water to try to destroy him. The disciples had tried to cast the spirit out but failed. After Jesus healed the boy, the disciples asked privately why they couldn't drive it out. What did Jesus tell them?
options: 'You did not pray long enough'
'This kind can come out only by prayer' (and fasting in some manuscripts)
'You need more training'
'Only I have the authority to cast out this kind'
beginner.explanation: Jesus rebuked the evil spirit, which threw the boy into violent convulsions before coming out. The boy lay so still that people thought he was dead, but Jesus took him by the hand and lifted him up. When the disciples asked why they failed, Jesus said 'This kind can come out only by prayer.' He also told them their failure was due to lack of faith — 'If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, "Move" and it will move.'

beginner.question: When Moses was leading the Israelites through the wilderness, they desperately needed water. God told Moses to speak to a rock and water would pour out. But Moses was angry at the people's complaining and did something different. What did Moses do instead?
options: He dug a well in the sand
He struck the rock twice with his staff instead of speaking to it
He prayed for rain
He refused to get them water at all
beginner.explanation: In his frustration, Moses said to the people 'Listen, you rebels, must we bring you water out of this rock?' Then he struck the rock twice with his staff instead of speaking to it as God had instructed. Water gushed out abundantly, but God told Moses that because he had not trusted Him enough to honour Him as holy, Moses would not be allowed to enter the Promised Land.

beginner.question: In the Old Testament, a commander named Naaman had a serious skin disease (leprosy). He travelled from Syria to Israel to seek healing from the prophet Elisha. Elisha sent a messenger telling Naaman to do something simple, which initially made Naaman furious. What did Elisha tell Naaman to do?
options: Offer a sacrifice at the Temple
Wash seven times in the Jordan River
Climb to the top of Mount Carmel
Fast for three days
beginner.explanation: Naaman expected Elisha to come out personally, wave his hand over the leprosy, and dramatically call on God. Instead, Elisha didn't even come to the door — he sent a messenger saying 'Go, wash yourself seven times in the Jordan.' Naaman was furious: 'Are not the rivers of Damascus better?' But his servants persuaded him to try. He dipped seven times in the Jordan and his flesh was restored 'like that of a young boy.'

beginner.question: After Jesus fed a crowd of 4,000 people with seven loaves and a few small fish (a separate miracle from the feeding of the 5,000), how many baskets of leftovers did the disciples collect?
options: Twelve baskets
Seven baskets
Three baskets
Five baskets
beginner.explanation: After feeding the 4,000, the disciples collected seven basketfuls of broken pieces. Interestingly, in the feeding of the 5,000, they collected twelve baskets. Jesus later referenced both miracles specifically: 'When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many basketfuls did you pick up? Twelve. And when I broke the seven loaves for the four thousand, how many basketfuls? Seven.' The different numbers suggest symbolic meaning.

beginner.question: When Peter and John were going to the Temple to pray, they encountered a man who had been lame from birth and was begging at the Temple gate called Beautiful. Peter said 'Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you.' What did Peter do?
options: He gave the man food and clothing
He said 'In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk!' and helped him up — the man's feet and ankles became strong instantly
He prayed for the man and told him to come back tomorrow
He brought the man to the other apostles for healing
beginner.explanation: Peter said 'In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk!' and took the man by the right hand. Instantly the man's feet and ankles became strong. He jumped to his feet, began to walk, and went with them into the Temple courts, 'walking and jumping, and praising God.' The people were filled with wonder and amazement, and Peter used the opportunity to preach about Jesus.

beginner.question: When God sent ten plagues upon Egypt to convince Pharaoh to release the Israelites, the very first plague involved a dramatic transformation of Egypt's most important natural resource. What was the first plague?
options: Frogs covering the land
Darkness for three days
The Nile River turning to blood
Swarms of locusts
beginner.explanation: Moses stretched out his staff over the Nile and all the water in Egypt — the river, canals, ponds, and even water in wooden and stone containers — turned to blood. The fish died, the river stank, and the Egyptians could not drink the water. This was a direct challenge to the Egyptian god Hapi (god of the Nile), demonstrating that the God of Israel had power over Egypt's most vital resource.

beginner.question: During a severe drought and famine, God sent the prophet Elijah to stay with a poor widow in Zarephath. The widow only had a handful of flour and a little oil — enough for one last meal for herself and her son before they starved. What miracle did God perform?
options: He sent rain immediately to end the drought
The jar of flour was never used up and the jug of oil did not run dry until the drought ended
Food appeared from heaven each morning
The widow found gold buried in her yard
beginner.explanation: Elijah told the widow 'Don't be afraid. Go home and make a small loaf of bread for me first, then make something for yourself and your son. For this is what the LORD says: The jar of flour will not be used up and the jug of oil will not run dry until the day the LORD sends rain on the land.' She obeyed in faith, and just as God promised, the flour and oil miraculously lasted until the drought ended.

beginner.question: Jesus healed ten men who were suffering from leprosy (a devastating skin disease that made them outcasts from society). He told them to go show themselves to the priests, and as they went, they were healed. How many of the ten returned to thank Jesus?
options: All ten returned to thank him
Five of the ten returned
Only one returned — and he was a Samaritan
None of them returned
beginner.explanation: Only one of the ten healed lepers returned to thank Jesus — and he was a Samaritan, a foreigner despised by the Jews. He threw himself at Jesus' feet, thanking him. Jesus asked 'Were not all ten cleansed? Where are the other nine? Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner?' The story highlights that gratitude is rare and that outsiders sometimes show more faith than insiders.

beginner.question: After Jesus' resurrection, Peter was fishing with several disciples on the Sea of Galilee but caught nothing all night. A figure on the shore told them to cast their net on the other side of the boat. When they obeyed, what happened?
options: They caught a few small fish
They caught so many fish that they were unable to haul the net in — 153 large fish in total
The net came back empty again
A single enormous fish filled the entire net
beginner.explanation: When they cast the net on the right side of the boat as the stranger instructed, they caught 153 large fish — so many they couldn't haul the net into the boat. John recognised the figure on shore and said 'It is the Lord!' Peter immediately jumped into the water to swim to Jesus. When they landed, Jesus had already prepared breakfast of bread and fish over a charcoal fire. This was Jesus' third post-resurrection appearance to the disciples.

beginner.question: In the Old Testament, the walls of the heavily fortified city of Jericho fell down miraculously after the Israelites followed God's unusual battle plan. What did God tell them to do?
options: Use battering rams and siege weapons for seven days
March around the city once a day for six days, then seven times on the seventh day, blow trumpets, and shout
Pray without ceasing for a week
Dig tunnels under the walls
beginner.explanation: God's plan defied all military logic. The Israelites marched around Jericho once a day for six days with seven priests blowing ram's horn trumpets before the Ark of the Covenant. On the seventh day, they marched around seven times. At the sound of the trumpets and a great shout from the people, the walls of Jericho collapsed completely, and the Israelites took the city.

beginner.question: A leper came to Jesus and knelt before him, saying 'If you are willing, you can make me clean.' In that culture, lepers were untouchable outcasts — anyone who touched a leper became ceremonially unclean. How did Jesus respond?
options: He told the man to go wash in the Jordan River
He reached out his hand and touched the man, saying 'I am willing. Be clean!' and the leprosy disappeared instantly
He healed the man from a distance without touching him
He told the man to come back tomorrow
beginner.explanation: Jesus did something shocking — he reached out and touched the leper. In that culture, this was unthinkable. But instead of Jesus becoming unclean, the leper became clean. Jesus said 'I am willing. Be clean!' and immediately the leprosy disappeared. Then he told the man to show himself to the priest and offer the sacrifices Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.

beginner.question: When Moses first appeared before Pharaoh to demand the release of the Israelites, God gave Moses a sign to demonstrate divine power. Moses threw his staff on the ground and it transformed. What did the staff become?
options: A sword
A snake
A flowering rod
A pillar of fire
beginner.explanation: Moses threw his staff on the ground and it became a snake. Pharaoh's magicians duplicated this feat with their own staffs, but then Moses' snake swallowed all of their snakes — demonstrating that God's power was superior to Egyptian magic. This sign was first given to Moses at the burning bush to convince the Israelites that God had truly sent him.

beginner.question: After the apostle Peter was arrested by King Herod and imprisoned (chained between two soldiers with guards at the door), the church prayed earnestly for him. That night, something miraculous happened. How was Peter freed?
options: The other apostles broke him out of prison
An angel appeared, woke Peter up, caused his chains to fall off, and led him past the guards and through the iron gate — which opened by itself
An earthquake destroyed the prison walls
Peter convinced the guards to let him go
beginner.explanation: An angel appeared in Peter's cell and a light shone. The angel struck Peter on the side to wake him and said 'Quick, get up!' Peter's chains fell off his wrists. The angel led him past the guards (who didn't notice) and through the iron gate, which opened by itself. Peter went to Mary's house where the church was praying for him. When he knocked, a servant girl named Rhoda was so overjoyed she forgot to open the door!

beginner.question: Jesus healed a man with a withered (shrivelled, paralysed) hand on the Sabbath day in a synagogue, while the Pharisees watched to see if he would 'break' the Sabbath rules. Before healing the man, what pointed question did Jesus ask the Pharisees?
options: 'Do you believe I can do this?'
'Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?'
'Has no one ever healed on the Sabbath before?'
'Is this man not worth more than your rules?'
beginner.explanation: Jesus asked 'Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?' The Pharisees remained silent. Jesus looked at them with anger, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, then told the man 'Stretch out your hand.' The man stretched it out and it was completely restored. The Pharisees went out and immediately began plotting how to kill Jesus.

intermediate.question: When the prophet Elisha died and was buried, an extraordinary miracle occurred at his grave. Some Israelites were burying a man when they spotted a Moabite raiding party. In their hurry, they threw the man's body into Elisha's tomb. What happened when the body touched Elisha's bones?
options: The tomb sealed itself shut
The dead man came back to life and stood up on his feet
Elisha's bones turned to dust
A bright light filled the tomb
intermediate.explanation: When the body touched Elisha's bones, the man came back to life and stood up on his feet. This posthumous miracle is unique in the Bible and demonstrated that God's power was not limited even by the prophet's death. It fulfilled Elisha's request for a 'double portion' of Elijah's spirit — even in death, Elisha performed miracles.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elisha performed a miracle for a desperate widow whose deceased husband's creditor was coming to take her two sons as slaves. She had nothing except a small jar of olive oil. What did Elisha tell her to do?
options: Sell the oil and pay the debt
Go to all her neighbours and collect as many empty jars as possible, then pour her little oil into them — the oil kept flowing until every jar was full
Pray for three days and God would provide
Go to the Temple and ask the priests for help
intermediate.explanation: Elisha told the widow to borrow as many empty jars as she could from all her neighbours, shut the door, and pour oil from her small jar. Miraculously, the oil kept flowing, filling jar after jar, until there were no more empty jars left. Then the oil stopped. Elisha said 'Go, sell the oil and pay your debts. You and your sons can live on what is left.' The miracle matched the measure of her faith — she collected as many jars as she had faith to gather.

intermediate.question: In the book of Joshua, during a battle against the Amorites, Joshua needed more daylight to complete the victory. He made an extraordinary request to God in front of all Israel. What did Joshua ask God to do?
options: Send lightning against the enemy
Make the sun stand still in the sky (and it did, for about a full day)
Cause an earthquake to swallow the enemy army
Send a blinding fog to confuse the enemy
intermediate.explanation: Joshua said in the sight of Israel 'Sun, stand still over Gibeon, and you, moon, over the Valley of Aijalon.' The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down for about a full day. The text says 'There has never been a day like it before or since, a day when the LORD listened to a human being.' God also sent large hailstones that killed more enemies than the Israelites did with their swords.

intermediate.question: When the apostle Paul was shipwrecked on the island of Malta, he was gathering sticks for a fire when a venomous snake bit him and fastened onto his hand. The islanders expected him to swell up and die. What actually happened?
options: Paul screamed in pain but was eventually healed
Paul shook the snake off into the fire and suffered no ill effects whatsoever — the islanders then thought he was a god
Paul was sick for three days before recovering
Another disciple sucked the poison out
intermediate.explanation: Paul simply shook the snake off into the fire and suffered no harm at all. The islanders watched, expecting him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. When nothing happened after a long time, they changed their minds and said he must be a god. Paul then went on to heal the father of the island's chief official, Publius, who was sick with fever and dysentery, by praying and placing his hands on him.

intermediate.question: In the book of Numbers, when the Israelites complained and God sent venomous snakes among them, many people were bitten and died. God told Moses to make something and put it on a pole — anyone who looked at it would live. What did Moses make?
options: A golden serpent
A bronze snake
A wooden cross
A clay figurine of a snake
intermediate.explanation: Moses made a bronze snake and put it on a pole. Anyone who was bitten by a snake could look at the bronze snake and live. Jesus later directly referenced this miracle: 'Just as Moses lifted up the snake in the wilderness, so the Son of Man must be lifted up, that everyone who believes may have eternal life' (John 3:14-15). The bronze snake foreshadowed Jesus being lifted up on the cross.

intermediate.question: When the prophet Elisha was surrounded by an enemy army that had come to capture him, his servant was terrified. Elisha prayed that God would open his servant's eyes, and the servant saw something that completely changed his perspective. What did the servant see?
options: The enemy army fleeing in fear
The hills full of horses and chariots of fire surrounding and protecting Elisha
A massive wall of water about to flood the enemy
An army of angels descending from heaven
intermediate.explanation: Elisha told his terrified servant 'Don't be afraid. Those who are with us are more than those who are with them.' Then he prayed 'Open his eyes, LORD, so that he may see.' God opened the servant's eyes and he saw the hills full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha. Elisha then prayed for God to strike the enemy army with blindness, which He did. Elisha led the blinded soldiers to Samaria and told the king to feed them and send them home.

intermediate.question: After Jesus ascended to heaven, the apostle Peter's shadow falling on sick people as he walked by was believed to have healing power. People laid the sick on mats in the streets hoping Peter's shadow would fall on them. According to Acts, what was the result?
options: Nothing happened — shadows have no power
People brought the sick from surrounding towns and all of them were healed
Only a few were healed
Peter told them to stop being superstitious
intermediate.explanation: Acts 5:15-16 records that 'people brought the sick into the streets and laid them on beds and mats so that at least Peter's shadow might fall on some of them as he passed by. Crowds gathered also from the towns around Jerusalem, bringing their sick and those tormented by impure spirits, and all of them were healed.' This remarkable power demonstrated that the same Spirit that empowered Jesus was now working through His apostles.

intermediate.question: When God told Abraham that his elderly wife Sarah would have a son, Sarah laughed because she was about 90 years old and well past childbearing age. God's response included a rhetorical question that has become one of the most quoted lines about miracles. What did God ask?
options: 'Do you not believe in the LORD your God?'
'Is anything too hard for the LORD?'
'Have I not promised and will I not fulfil?'
'Why do you doubt my word?'
intermediate.explanation: God asked 'Is anything too hard for the LORD?' (Genesis 18:14). This rhetorical question — expecting the answer 'No!' — became a foundational statement about God's unlimited power. Sarah did conceive and gave birth to Isaac when Abraham was 100 years old. The angel Gabriel echoed this same principle when he told Mary she would conceive Jesus: 'Nothing will be impossible with God' (Luke 1:37).

intermediate.question: The apostle Paul performed an unusual miracle in Troas when a young man named Eutychus fell asleep during Paul's very long sermon (which went until midnight), fell from a third-storey window, and died. What did Paul do?
options: He asked God to forgive the young man
He went down, threw himself on the young man and embraced him, saying 'Don't be alarmed. He's alive!' — and the young man was restored to life
He finished his sermon first, then went to check on the young man
He asked Luke, the physician, to examine the body
intermediate.explanation: Paul went down, threw himself on Eutychus, and put his arms around him, echoing the Old Testament prophets Elijah (1 Kings 17) and Elisha (2 Kings 4) who raised children from the dead in similar fashion. Paul announced 'Don't be alarmed. He's alive!' The people took the young man home alive and were greatly comforted. And Paul continued talking until daylight — apparently undeterred by the incident!

intermediate.question: During the Exodus, God led the Israelites through the wilderness using two miraculous guides that showed them where to go, day and night. What were these two guides?
options: A star and an angel
A pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night
Two angelic figures walking ahead
A rainbow by day and the moon by night
intermediate.explanation: God went ahead of the Israelites in a pillar of cloud by day to guide them and a pillar of fire by night to give them light. These were visible manifestations of God's presence ('Shekinah glory'). The pillars never left their place — the cloud pillar did not leave by day, nor the fire pillar by night. During the Red Sea crossing, the pillar moved behind them to block the Egyptian army's advance.

intermediate.question: When Jesus healed a deaf man who also had a speech impediment, he used an unusual method that involved physical actions. According to Mark's Gospel, what specific things did Jesus do before saying 'Ephphatha' ('Be opened!')?
options: He touched the man's forehead and prayed
He put his fingers into the man's ears, spat, and touched the man's tongue
He waved his hands over the man
He breathed on the man's face
intermediate.explanation: Jesus took the man aside privately, put his fingers into the man's ears, spat, and touched the man's tongue. He looked up to heaven, sighed deeply, and said 'Ephphatha!' ('Be opened!'). The man's ears were opened, his tongue was loosened, and he began to speak plainly. Jesus' physical actions may have communicated compassion to the deaf man, who could not hear verbal assurance.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elijah raised a widow's dead son back to life in one of the earliest resurrection miracles in the Bible. The widow had accused Elijah of bringing death to her household. What method did Elijah use to revive the boy?
options: He prayed from a distance
He stretched himself out over the boy three times and cried out to God, and the boy's life returned
He poured oil on the boy's head
He commanded the boy to rise in God's name
intermediate.explanation: Elijah carried the dead boy to the upper room where he was staying, laid him on the bed, and stretched himself out on the boy three times. He cried out 'LORD my God, let this boy's life return to him!' The LORD heard Elijah's prayer and the boy's life returned to him. Elijah carried the living boy back to his mother, who said 'Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the LORD from your mouth is the truth.'

intermediate.question: When King Hezekiah was told by the prophet Isaiah that he was going to die from his illness, Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed with bitter weeping. God heard his prayer and added 15 years to his life. What miraculous sign did God give to confirm this promise?
options: A rainbow appeared in the sky
The shadow on the stairway of Ahaz went backward ten steps
Rain fell from a cloudless sky
A star appeared during daytime
intermediate.explanation: Isaiah asked Hezekiah whether he wanted the shadow to go forward or backward ten steps. Hezekiah said going forward would be easy — so he chose the harder sign, backward. Isaiah called out to the LORD, and the shadow went back ten steps on the stairway of Ahaz. This apparently involved the sun's position reversing, making it one of the most dramatic astronomical miracles in the Bible.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, a sorcerer named Simon (Simon Magus) in Samaria was so impressed by the miracles performed through the apostles that he offered them money for the ability to give the Holy Spirit through the laying on of hands. How did Peter respond?
options: He accepted Simon's money and taught him
He sternly rebuked Simon, saying 'May your money perish with you, because you thought you could buy the gift of God with money!'
He ignored Simon's request
He said the ability would cost even more money
intermediate.explanation: Peter's sharp rebuke — 'May your money perish with you!' — established an important principle: God's gifts cannot be purchased with money. Peter told Simon 'You have no part or share in this ministry, because your heart is not right before God. Repent of this wickedness and pray to the Lord.' The practice of buying spiritual offices later became known as 'simony' — named after Simon Magus.

intermediate.question: Jesus cursed a fig tree that had leaves but no fruit, and it withered from the roots. While this seems like a strange miracle, scholars see it as a prophetic sign-act. What did the fig tree symbolise in this context?
options: The Roman Empire, which appeared powerful but was spiritually bankrupt
Israel/the Temple, which had an outward appearance of religious activity (leaves) but produced no genuine spiritual fruit
The disciples' lack of faith
The barrenness of the wilderness
intermediate.explanation: The fig tree was a common Old Testament symbol for Israel (Jeremiah 8:13, Hosea 9:10). Mark deliberately places the fig tree cursing around the Temple cleansing (fig tree cursed → Temple cleansed → fig tree withered), linking them. The Temple had impressive external activity (leaves) but no genuine spiritual fruit. Jesus was pronouncing judgment on a religious system that looked alive but was spiritually dead.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elisha purified a deadly pot of stew during a famine. The company of prophets had accidentally gathered poisonous gourds and added them to the pot. When they cried out 'There is death in the pot!', what did Elisha do to make the stew safe?
options: He poured the stew out and made new stew
He threw flour into the pot and the stew became harmless
He boiled the stew for several more hours
He prayed over the pot for an hour
intermediate.explanation: Elisha simply said 'Get some flour' and threw it into the pot. He then said 'Serve it to the people to eat.' The flour had no natural ability to counteract poison — it was a symbolic act of faith. The deadly stew became perfectly safe to eat. This miracle demonstrates God's provision during famine and Elisha's role as a prophet who brings life where there is death.

intermediate.question: When Peter was imprisoned by Herod and miraculously freed by an angel in the middle of the night, he went to the house where the believers were praying for his release. When a servant girl named Rhoda answered his knock, what happened?
options: She let him in immediately
She was so overjoyed that she ran back without opening the door to tell everyone, and they didn't believe her — they said 'It must be his angel'
She screamed and fainted
She didn't recognise Peter
intermediate.explanation: Rhoda recognised Peter's voice and was so excited she forgot to open the door! She ran back and exclaimed 'Peter is at the door!' The praying believers — who had been praying for Peter's release — said 'You're out of your mind!' and then 'It must be his angel.' Meanwhile Peter kept knocking. When they finally opened the door and saw him, they were astonished. The irony is delightful: they were praying for a miracle but didn't believe it when it happened.

intermediate.question: In one of his most dramatic healings, Jesus encountered a man in the synagogue on the Sabbath who had a shrivelled (withered) hand. The Pharisees were watching closely to see if Jesus would heal on the Sabbath so they could accuse him. Jesus told the man to do something bold in front of everyone. What did Jesus say?
options: 'Come to me after the service'
'Stand up in front of everyone... Stretch out your hand' — and when he did, his hand was completely restored
'Go home and pray, and you will be healed by morning'
'Wash your hand in the ritual bath'
intermediate.explanation: Jesus deliberately made this healing as public as possible. He told the man 'Stand up in front of everyone,' then asked the Pharisees the pointed question about doing good or evil on the Sabbath. When they refused to answer, Jesus looked at them with anger and deep distress, then told the man 'Stretch out your hand.' The man stretched it out and his hand was completely restored. The Pharisees went out and immediately began plotting to kill Jesus.

intermediate.question: During the Exodus, God sent ten plagues upon Egypt. The tenth and most devastating plague was the death of every firstborn son. But the Israelites were protected by a specific action they had to take. What did they do to protect their families?
options: They prayed all night in the Temple
They slaughtered a lamb and painted its blood on the doorframes of their houses — the angel of death 'passed over' homes with blood on the door
They locked their doors and stayed inside
They wore white garments and carried candles
intermediate.explanation: Each Israelite family slaughtered a lamb, roasted it, and painted its blood on the top and sides of their doorframe. When the destroyer went through Egypt at midnight, he 'passed over' every house marked with blood. This event became the annual Passover festival. Christians see this as a foreshadowing of Jesus, 'the Lamb of God,' whose blood protects believers from judgment.

intermediate.question: A Syrophoenician (Canaanite) woman begged Jesus to cast a demon out of her daughter. Jesus initially seemed to refuse, saying 'It is not right to take the children's bread and toss it to the dogs.' The woman gave a remarkable reply that changed Jesus' response. What did she say?
options: 'But even Gentiles deserve God's mercy'
'Yes, Lord, but even the dogs under the table eat the children's crumbs'
'I know I am not worthy, but please help my daughter'
'Surely God's love extends to all nations'
intermediate.explanation: The woman's reply was brilliant in its humility and wit — she didn't argue against Jesus' framework but worked within it. Even the 'crumbs' of Jesus' power would be more than enough for her daughter. Jesus was impressed: 'Woman, you have great faith! Your request is granted.' Her daughter was healed that very hour. The story demonstrates that faith, not ethnicity, opens the door to God's miraculous power.

intermediate.question: When an axe head fell into the Jordan River during tree-cutting, a young prophet was distressed because the axe was borrowed. The prophet Elisha performed a small but remarkable miracle to recover it. What did Elisha do?
options: He dived into the river and retrieved it
He cut a stick, threw it into the water where the axe had fallen, and the iron axe head floated to the surface
He parted the river to reveal the axe
He told the young man to reach into the water and it would come to his hand
intermediate.explanation: Elisha cut a stick and threw it into the water at the place where the axe head had fallen. The heavy iron axe head floated to the surface, defying the law of gravity. The young prophet reached out and picked it up. This seemingly small miracle showed God's care for everyday concerns — even a borrowed tool. Iron was expensive in ancient Israel, and losing a borrowed axe was a serious matter.

intermediate.question: When Paul and Silas were beaten and thrown into prison in Philippi with their feet fastened in stocks, they did something remarkable at midnight that preceded their miraculous release. What were they doing when the earthquake struck?
options: Planning their escape
Sleeping soundly
Praying and singing hymns to God, while the other prisoners listened
Arguing with the guards
intermediate.explanation: At midnight, Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God with their backs bleeding and their feet in stocks. Suddenly a violent earthquake shook the prison, all the doors flew open, and every prisoner's chains came loose. The jailer drew his sword to kill himself (Roman jailers were executed if prisoners escaped), but Paul shouted 'Don't harm yourself! We are all here!' The jailer asked 'What must I do to be saved?' and believed that night.

intermediate.question: In one of the strangest miracles in the Bible, a prophet named Balaam was riding his donkey when the donkey suddenly stopped and refused to move. Balaam beat the donkey three times, not realising why it had stopped. What extraordinary thing did the donkey do?
options: It ran away at full speed
It spoke to Balaam in human words, asking why Balaam was beating it — the donkey had seen an angel with a drawn sword blocking the road that Balaam couldn't see
It transformed into a horse
It lay down and refused to get up
intermediate.explanation: The donkey could see the angel of the LORD standing in the road with a drawn sword, even though Balaam could not. When Balaam beat the donkey, God opened the donkey's mouth and it said 'What have I done to you to make you beat me these three times?' Then God opened Balaam's eyes and he saw the angel, who told him 'If the donkey had not turned away, I would certainly have killed you by now.'

intermediate.question: On the day of Pentecost, when the Holy Spirit descended on the disciples, they began speaking in other languages they had never learned. Jews from many nations were in Jerusalem and each heard the disciples speaking in their own native language. How many people were baptised that day after Peter's sermon?
options: About 500
About 1,000
About 3,000
About 5,000
intermediate.explanation: About 3,000 people were baptised and added to the church on that single day. The crowd was amazed that Galileans (considered uneducated) were speaking fluently in Parthian, Median, Elamite, Mesopotamian, and many other languages. Some accused them of being drunk, but Peter pointed out it was only 9 AM and explained that this was the fulfilment of Joel's prophecy about God pouring out His Spirit.

intermediate.question: Jesus performed a unique two-stage healing miracle at Bethsaida. He healed a blind man, but unusually, the healing happened in two stages rather than instantly. What happened after the first stage?
options: The man could hear but not see
The man could see people, but they looked 'like trees walking around' — Jesus then touched his eyes again and his sight was fully restored
The man could see out of one eye but not the other
The man could see only in bright light
intermediate.explanation: After Jesus spat on the man's eyes and put his hands on him the first time, the man said 'I see people; they look like trees walking around.' Jesus then put his hands on the man's eyes again, and his eyes were opened — he could see everything clearly. This is the only recorded two-stage miracle of Jesus. Some scholars see it as a parable about the disciples' own gradual understanding of who Jesus was.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elisha performed a miracle for a wealthy Shunammite woman who had provided him with a guest room. She was childless and her husband was old. Elisha promised her a son, and she gave birth the next year. But when the child died suddenly, what did Elisha do?
options: He prayed from his home and the boy recovered
He went to the boy, lay on him with his mouth on the boy's mouth, his eyes on his eyes, and his hands on his hands — the boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes
He sent his staff with a servant to place on the boy
He told the woman to take the boy to the Temple
intermediate.explanation: Elisha first sent his servant Gehazi ahead with his staff to place on the boy's face, but nothing happened. When Elisha arrived, he went in alone, prayed, and lay upon the child — mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, hands to hands. The boy's body grew warm. Elisha walked back and forth in the room, then stretched out on the boy again. The boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes. Elisha gave him back to his grateful mother.

intermediate.question: When Peter arrived at the house of a believer named Tabitha (Dorcas) in Joppa, she had already died. The room was full of weeping widows showing the robes and clothing she had made for them. Peter sent everyone out of the room and performed a miracle. What happened?
options: He prayed for three days and she revived
He knelt and prayed, then turned to the dead woman and said 'Tabitha, get up' — she opened her eyes, saw Peter, and sat up
He anointed her with oil and she recovered
He called the other apostles to pray together
intermediate.explanation: Peter sent all the weeping mourners out of the room, knelt down and prayed, then turned to the body and said 'Tabitha, get up.' She opened her eyes, saw Peter, and sat up. He helped her to her feet and called the believers and widows back in, presenting her alive. This miracle became known all over Joppa and many people believed in the Lord. The account closely parallels Jesus raising Jairus' daughter.

intermediate.question: During the conquest of Canaan, the Israelites were defeated at the small city of Ai after their victory at Jericho. God revealed that one man had sinned by keeping plunder from Jericho that was supposed to be devoted to God. Once the sin was dealt with, what happened at Ai?
options: The walls of Ai fell like Jericho's
God gave Israel victory through an ambush strategy — the entire city was destroyed
God sent a plague on the people of Ai
Israel simply walked in and took the city without a fight
