intermediate.explanation: After Achan's sin was dealt with, God told Joshua to set an ambush behind the city. Joshua sent 5,000 men to hide behind Ai, then led the main force to pretend to flee. When Ai's warriors chased them, the ambush force entered and burned the city. The retreating Israelites turned and attacked, catching Ai's army between two forces. God used both miraculous intervention and human strategy.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, handkerchiefs and aprons that had merely touched the apostle Paul were taken to the sick, and the sick were healed and evil spirits left them. This extraordinary phenomenon occurred in which city during Paul's extended ministry there?
options: Jerusalem
Antioch
Ephesus
Rome
intermediate.explanation: Acts 19:11-12 records that 'God did extraordinary miracles through Paul, so that even handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched him were taken to the sick, and their illnesses were cured and the evil spirits left them.' This happened in Ephesus during Paul's two-year ministry there. The miracles were so remarkable that Luke specifically calls them 'extraordinary' — unusual even by the standards of the apostolic age.

intermediate.question: Jesus healed a woman in the synagogue who had been bent over double for eighteen years, unable to straighten up at all. When the synagogue leader was indignant because Jesus healed on the Sabbath, Jesus called him a hypocrite. What comparison did Jesus make?
options: He compared the Pharisees to whitewashed tombs
He pointed out that they would untie their donkey or ox to lead it to water on the Sabbath — shouldn't this woman, bound by Satan for 18 years, be set free?
He quoted the law of Moses about healing
He asked if they had never shown mercy on the Sabbath
intermediate.explanation: Jesus said 'You hypocrites! Doesn't each of you on the Sabbath untie your ox or donkey from the stall and lead it out to give it water? Then should not this woman, a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has kept bound for eighteen long years, be set free on the Sabbath day from what bound her?' His opponents were humiliated, but the people were delighted at the wonderful things he was doing.

intermediate.question: When the Israelites crossed the Jordan River into the Promised Land, God instructed Joshua to set up a memorial. How many stones were taken from the riverbed, and what did they represent?
options: Seven stones, one for each day of creation
Twelve stones, one for each tribe of Israel
Forty stones, one for each year in the wilderness
Two stones, representing the two tablets of the law
intermediate.explanation: Joshua chose one man from each of the twelve tribes to take a stone from the middle of the Jordan where the priests had stood with the Ark. The twelve stones were set up at Gilgal as a memorial. Joshua explained: 'In the future when your descendants ask their parents, "What do these stones mean?" tell them that Israel crossed the Jordan on dry ground, so that all the peoples of the earth might know that the hand of the LORD is powerful.'

intermediate.question: Peter's encounter with a paralysed man named Aeneas in Lydda resulted in a remarkable healing. What were Peter's exact words to Aeneas, who had been bedridden for eight years?
options: 'Be healed in the name of Jesus'
'Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and roll up your mat' — and Aeneas immediately got up
'Rise up and walk'
'Your faith has made you well'
intermediate.explanation: Peter's words are significant: he said 'Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and roll up your mat.' Peter made it clear that the healing came from Jesus Christ, not from Peter himself. Aeneas, who had been paralysed and bedridden for eight years, immediately got up. All those who lived in Lydda and Sharon saw him and turned to the Lord.

intermediate.question: After Jesus fed the 5,000, he sent his disciples ahead in a boat while he went up a mountainside to pray alone. When the disciples were in the middle of the lake straining at the oars against a strong headwind, at what time of night did Jesus come to them walking on the water?
options: Shortly after sunset
Around midnight
Shortly before dawn (the fourth watch of the night, between 3 and 6 AM)
Just after midnight
intermediate.explanation: Mark 6:48 says Jesus came to them 'shortly before dawn' — literally 'the fourth watch of the night,' which was between 3 and 6 AM. The disciples had been straining at the oars for hours against a strong headwind. Jesus was walking on the lake and 'was about to pass by them' — an echo of Old Testament theophanies where God 'passes by' (Exodus 33:19, 1 Kings 19:11). The disciples thought he was a ghost and cried out in terror.

intermediate.question: In the Old Testament, Aaron's staff miraculously budded, blossomed, and produced almonds overnight as a sign from God to settle a dispute. What was the dispute about?
options: Whether Moses or Aaron should lead Israel
Which tribe had the right to the priesthood — God chose Levi (Aaron's tribe) by making only his staff bud among twelve tribal staffs
Whether the Israelites should enter Canaan or return to Egypt
Who should be the next judge of Israel
intermediate.explanation: After Korah's rebellion against Moses and Aaron's leadership, God settled the question of priestly authority permanently. He told Moses to collect a staff from each of the twelve tribal leaders. Overnight, Aaron's staff (representing Levi) not only budded but also blossomed and produced ripe almonds. God commanded that Aaron's staff be kept before the Ark as a perpetual reminder.

intermediate.question: When Jesus was arrested in the Garden of Gethsemane, Peter drew a sword and cut off the right ear of the high priest's servant, whose name was Malchus. This was Jesus' final healing miracle before the cross. What did Jesus do?
options: He rebuked Peter and told Malchus to see a doctor
He touched the servant's ear and healed it, while telling Peter to put away his sword
He told the soldiers to bandage the wound
He ignored the injury and focused on his arrest
intermediate.explanation: Jesus said 'No more of this!' and touched Malchus' ear, healing it completely. He then rebuked Peter: 'Put your sword back in its place, for all who draw the sword will die by the sword. Do you think I cannot call on my Father, and he will at once put at my disposal more than twelve legions of angels?' This final miracle showed mercy to the very people arresting him.

advanced.question: Scholars categorise the miracles of Jesus in the Gospels into four main types. Which of the following is NOT one of the standard categories used in academic study of Gospel miracles?
options: Nature miracles (calming storms, walking on water, feeding multitudes)
Exorcisms (casting out demons)
Healing miracles (restoring sight, curing leprosy, healing paralysis)
Political miracles (overthrowing governments, freeing prisoners from Roman authority)
advanced.explanation: The four standard categories of Jesus' miracles in scholarship are: (1) healing miracles, (2) exorcisms, (3) nature miracles, and (4) raising the dead (resuscitations). Jesus explicitly rejected 'political miracles' — he refused to be made king by force (John 6:15) and told Pilate 'My kingdom is not of this world.' His miracles addressed physical, spiritual, and natural realms but intentionally avoided the political realm his contemporaries expected.

advanced.question: The feeding of the 5,000 is the only miracle (besides the resurrection) recorded in all four Gospels. Each Gospel includes distinct details. Which Gospel uniquely identifies the boy with the five loaves and two fish and specifies that the loaves were made of barley?
options: Matthew
Mark
Luke
John
advanced.explanation: Only John's Gospel mentions the boy (paidarion) and specifies the loaves as barley loaves (the cheapest bread, food of the poor). John also uniquely connects this miracle to the 'Bread of Life' discourse that follows (John 6:22-59). The barley detail may intentionally echo Elisha's miracle of feeding 100 men with twenty barley loaves (2 Kings 4:42-44) — Jesus exceeds Elisha as he feeds 5,000 with even less.

advanced.question: The 'nature miracles' of Jesus (calming the storm, walking on water, feeding the multitudes, cursing the fig tree) are considered by many scholars to carry deeper theological significance beyond the literal events. What Old Testament imagery do they primarily evoke?
options: The victories of King David over his enemies
God's sovereign power over chaos, sea, and creation as depicted in the Psalms and Job — demonstrating that Jesus exercises divine authority over the natural world
The agricultural festivals of ancient Israel
The building of Solomon's Temple
advanced.explanation: The Old Testament consistently depicts control over the sea, storms, and creation as exclusively God's domain. Psalm 107:29 — God 'stilled the storm to a whisper'; Job 9:8 — God 'treads on the waves of the sea'; Psalm 78:24 — God 'rained down manna.' When Jesus calms storms, walks on water, and multiplies food, the Gospel writers present him exercising divine prerogatives that the Old Testament reserves for God alone. The disciples' question 'Who is this?' implies they are recognising divine identity.

advanced.question: The Greek word 'semeion' (sign) is John's preferred term for Jesus' miracles, while the Synoptic Gospels prefer 'dunamis' (power/mighty work). What key theological difference does this vocabulary choice reflect?
options: John considered the miracles less important than the Synoptics did
'Semeion' emphasises that miracles point beyond themselves to reveal Jesus' identity and glory, while 'dunamis' emphasises the raw power and compassion behind them
The terms are completely interchangeable with no theological significance
'Dunamis' refers only to healing miracles while 'semeion' refers only to nature miracles
advanced.explanation: John's use of 'semeion' (sign) treats each miracle as a signpost pointing to a deeper spiritual truth about Jesus' identity. Turning water to wine 'signs' toward Jesus as the source of messianic joy. Healing the blind man 'signs' toward Jesus as 'the light of the world.' The Synoptics' 'dunamis' emphasises God's power breaking into the world through Jesus' compassionate action. Both perspectives are complementary but reflect different theological emphases.

advanced.question: David Hume's famous philosophical argument against miracles (1748) has been widely debated for centuries. What is the core of Hume's argument?
options: Miracles are logically impossible because they violate the laws of physics
The testimony in favour of a miracle is never sufficient to establish it because the uniform experience of humanity against miracles always outweighs any testimony for them
Miracles only occur in primitive, pre-scientific societies
Miracles are possible but God would never perform them
advanced.explanation: Hume argued that since a miracle is a violation of natural law, and natural law is established by 'a firm and unalterable experience,' no testimony can ever be strong enough to make a miracle more probable than its not occurring. Critics (including C.S. Lewis, Alvin Plantinga, and John Earman) have pointed out the circularity: Hume assumes miracles don't occur in order to prove miracles don't occur. He defines 'uniform experience' against miracles before examining the evidence for them.

advanced.question: Jesus' exorcisms (casting out demons) are among the most historically well-attested aspects of his ministry, accepted even by sceptical scholars. Why are the exorcisms considered highly likely to be historical?
options: Because exorcism stories are easy to fabricate

They pass multiple criteria of historicity: they are multiply attested (in Mark, Q, L, and M sources), they caused embarrassment (critics accused Jesus of using demonic power), and they are culturally coherent with first-century Palestinian Judaism
Because the early church promoted exorcism as its primary ministry
Because Roman historians independently confirmed them
advanced.explanation: The exorcisms pass multiple criteria: (1) Multiple attestation — they appear in Mark, Q, special Luke, and special Matthew material; (2) Embarrassment — Jesus' enemies accused him of casting out demons by Beelzebul (Mark 3:22), which the church wouldn't have invented; (3) Coherence — exorcism was a recognised practice in first-century Judaism; (4) Dissimilarity — Jesus' exorcisms lacked the elaborate rituals, incantations, and props used by other ancient exorcists, making them distinctive. Even the sceptical Jesus Seminar accepted the historicity of Jesus as an exorcist.

advanced.question: The 'gift of miracles' (charismata iamaton) that Paul discusses in 1 Corinthians 12 is listed among the spiritual gifts given to the church. A major theological debate has centred on whether miraculous gifts continued after the apostolic era or ceased. What is the theological term for the view that miraculous gifts ceased with the death of the apostles?
options: Continuationism
Cessationism
Dispensationalism
Pentecostalism
advanced.explanation: Cessationism holds that certain miraculous/sign gifts (tongues, prophecy, healing, miracles) ceased with the completion of the New Testament canon and the death of the apostles. Advocates (including B.B. Warfield and many Reformed theologians) argue these gifts served to authenticate the apostles and were no longer needed. Continuationists (including Pentecostals, Charismatics, and scholars like Wayne Grudem and Craig Keener) argue that no biblical text teaches the cessation of these gifts.

advanced.question: In the Gospel of Mark, Jesus' miracles are sometimes followed by a command to secrecy ('Don't tell anyone'), yet in other cases Jesus tells the healed person to spread the news. This pattern is part of what scholars call the 'Messianic Secret.' In which notable case did Jesus actually command a healed man to GO and tell others?
options: The blind man at Bethsaida
The leper in Galilee
The Gerasene demoniac — Jesus told him 'Go home to your own people and tell them how much the Lord has done for you'
The paralytic at Capernaum
advanced.explanation: The Gerasene demoniac is a fascinating exception to the secrecy pattern. After casting out 'Legion,' Jesus told the man 'Go home to your own people and tell them how much the Lord has done for you.' This may be because the Decapolis (where it occurred) was predominantly Gentile territory, where there was less risk of misguided messianic fervour. The man 'went away and began to tell in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him. And all the people were amazed.'

advanced.question: The raising of Lazarus (John 11) differs significantly from the raisings of Jairus' daughter and the widow of Nain's son in a key detail that strengthens its miraculous nature. What is this crucial difference?
options: Lazarus was more well-known than the others
Lazarus had been dead for four days — well past any possibility of resuscitation — and his body had begun to decompose, making the miracle undeniable
Lazarus was raised in public while the others were raised privately
Lazarus was older than the other two
advanced.explanation: The four-day detail is theologically and historically crucial. Jewish tradition held that the soul lingered near the body for three days and departed on the fourth — meaning Lazarus was considered irrevocably dead. Martha's warning 'by this time there is a bad odour' confirms bodily decomposition had begun. Jesus deliberately waited two extra days (John 11:6) to ensure Lazarus would be dead four days, eliminating any possibility of natural resuscitation and making the miracle's reality beyond dispute.

advanced.question: Craig Keener's massive two-volume work 'Miracles' (2011) documented thousands of contemporary miracle claims from around the world, including medically documented healings. What was Keener's primary argument against the philosophical dismissal of miracles?
options: That every miracle claim is automatically true

That the sheer volume of credible, eyewitness testimony from diverse cultures and reliable witnesses — including cases with medical documentation — makes it intellectually irresponsible to dismiss all miracle claims a priori without examining the evidence
That science has now proven miracles are possible
That miracles only occur in developing countries
advanced.explanation: Keener argued that Hume's a priori dismissal of miracle testimony fails when confronted with the massive quantity and quality of modern miracle claims from every continent, culture, and socioeconomic context. He documented cases with medical records, multiple eyewitnesses, and physician verification. His point was not that every claim is genuine, but that blanket dismissal without investigation is not the position of an open-minded scholar but an uncritical assumption.

advanced.question: The Old Testament concept of 'signs and wonders' (otot u-moftim) differs from the New Testament concept in an important way. In the Old Testament, who is the primary performer of 'signs and wonders'?
options: The prophets, who perform signs independently of God
God Himself, working through intermediaries like Moses, Elijah, and Elisha — the humans are always portrayed as channels, never independent sources, of miraculous power
The priests in the Temple
The kings of Israel
advanced.explanation: In the Old Testament, signs and wonders are consistently attributed to God's direct action, even when performed through human intermediaries. Moses doesn't claim 'I parted the Red Sea' but stretches out his staff as God acts. Elijah doesn't generate fire from heaven but prays and God answers. This pattern continues in the New Testament — Peter says 'In the name of Jesus Christ, walk' and Paul says 'God did extraordinary miracles through Paul.' The miracle-worker is always a channel, never the source.

advanced.question: The 'principle of analogy' — used by the historian Ernst Troeltsch (1898) — has been a major methodological objection to accepting biblical miracles as historical. What does this principle state?
options: Ancient texts should be interpreted literally
Historical judgments must be based on analogy with present experience — since we don't observe miracles today, we cannot accept them as historical events in the past
Miracles in different religions should be compared
Biblical miracles should be evaluated using the same criteria as other ancient texts
advanced.explanation: Troeltsch argued that since our present experience does not include miracles, historical method requires us to explain ancient miracle reports through natural causes. Critics respond that this principle begs the question — it assumes miracles don't happen in order to conclude they didn't happen. Wolfhart Pannenberg and N.T. Wright have argued that the principle of analogy is methodologically appropriate for most history but cannot be used to exclude unique, unprecedented events a priori.

advanced.question: Jesus' healing of the man born blind in John 9 includes a theological debate about the relationship between sin and suffering. The disciples asked 'Who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?' Jesus' answer challenged a widely held belief. What did Jesus say?
options: 'His parents sinned, and he bears the consequences'
'Neither this man nor his parents sinned — this happened so that the works of God might be displayed in him'
'All suffering is caused by personal sin'
'This is a punishment for sins committed in a past life'
advanced.explanation: Jesus rejected the simplistic equation of suffering with personal sin that was common in first-century Judaism (and remains common today). He said the blindness was not caused by anyone's sin but existed 'so that the works of God might be displayed in him.' This reframed suffering from a backward-looking question ('Who caused this?') to a forward-looking one ('What will God do through this?'). It also challenged the 'retribution theology' that the book of Job had already critiqued.

advanced.question: The ten plagues of Egypt have been the subject of various naturalistic explanations (volcanic eruptions, red algae blooms, insect swarms, etc.). From a theological perspective, regardless of whether natural mechanisms were involved, what was the primary purpose of the plagues?
options: To punish the Egyptian people for their personal sins
Each plague was a direct challenge to a specific Egyptian god — demonstrating YHWH's supremacy over the entire Egyptian pantheon
To destroy Egypt's economy so they couldn't pursue the Israelites
To test Moses' faith before the Exodus
advanced.explanation: Exodus 12:12 explicitly states: 'I will bring judgment on all the gods of Egypt.' Each plague targeted a specific Egyptian deity: the Nile turning to blood challenged Hapi (Nile god); frogs challenged Heqet (frog goddess of fertility); darkness challenged Ra (sun god); the death of firstborn challenged Pharaoh himself (considered divine). The plagues were a systematic theological dismantling of the Egyptian religious system, proving YHWH's sovereignty.

advanced.question: The concept of 'theophany' — a visible manifestation of God — is closely related to miracles in the Old Testament. Which of the following is considered the most dramatic theophany in the Old Testament?
options: God walking with Adam in the Garden of Eden
God appearing to Abraham at the oaks of Mamre
God's descent on Mount Sinai with thunder, lightning, thick cloud, trumpet blast, fire, smoke, and earthquake — so terrifying that even Moses said 'I am trembling with fear'
God appearing to Elijah in the still small voice
advanced.explanation: The Sinai theophany (Exodus 19-20) is the most dramatic divine manifestation in the Old Testament. The mountain burned with fire, was covered in smoke and thick cloud, the ground shook, and a trumpet grew louder and louder. God descended in fire and spoke the Ten Commandments audibly. The people were so terrified they stood at a distance and begged Moses 'Speak to us yourself and we will listen. But do not have God speak to us or we will die.' Even Moses said 'I am trembling with fear.'

advanced.question: In Mark's Gospel, Jesus' miracles are concentrated in the first half (chapters 1-8), while the second half (chapters 9-16) is dominated by teaching about his coming suffering and death. What literary and theological purpose does this structural division serve?
options: Mark ran out of miracle stories to include
The first half establishes Jesus' divine power and authority, while the second half redefines messiahship through suffering — showing that the one who CAN do anything CHOOSES the path of the cross
The miracles and teachings were addressed to different audiences
Mark was combining two separate documents about Jesus
advanced.explanation: Mark's structure is theologically deliberate. The turning point is Peter's confession (8:29) followed immediately by the first passion prediction (8:31). The first half proves Jesus has divine authority — he can heal, exorcise, control nature, raise the dead. The second half shows he voluntarily surrenders that power: the one who calmed storms does not come down from the cross. This creates maximum theological impact — the crucifixion is not weakness but the supreme exercise of divine love.

advanced.question: The Gospel of John records exactly seven 'sign miracles' before the resurrection. The seventh and climactic sign — the raising of Lazarus — serves a unique narrative function in John. What does it directly trigger in the plot?
options: Jesus' triumphant entry into Jerusalem
The decision by the Jewish authorities to put Jesus to death — the greatest sign of life directly causes the plot that leads to Jesus' death
The Last Supper
Judas' decision to betray Jesus
advanced.explanation: John 11:45-53 records that the raising of Lazarus — the most powerful demonstration of Jesus' authority over death — was the immediate catalyst for the Sanhedrin's formal decision to kill Jesus. The irony is profound: the miracle that proved Jesus could give life became the reason they decided to take his life. Caiaphas unknowingly prophesied 'It is better that one man die for the people.' The giver of life must die so that life can be given to all.

advanced.question: The phrase 'your faith has healed you' (or 'your faith has saved you' — the Greek 'sesoken' means both) appears repeatedly in Jesus' healing narratives. What theological insight does the deliberate ambiguity of this phrase convey?
options: That faith is a magical force that controls healing
That physical healing and spiritual salvation are interconnected in Jesus' ministry — miracles are not just physical fixes but doorways to a deeper wholeness that encompasses body and soul
That only people with strong faith can be healed
That healing replaces the need for faith
advanced.explanation: The Greek word 'sozo' (to save/heal/make whole) deliberately bridges physical healing and spiritual salvation. When Jesus says 'Your faith has saved/healed you,' the ambiguity is intentional — healing is a partial, anticipatory experience of the comprehensive salvation Jesus brings. The miracles are 'signs' of the kingdom, previews of the complete restoration God will accomplish. They address the whole person, not just symptoms.

advanced.question: The Elijah-Elisha miracle cycle in 1-2 Kings includes roughly 16 miracles attributed to Elisha versus 8 to Elijah. This doubling is significant because of a specific request Elisha made before Elijah was taken to heaven. What was the theological significance of Elisha receiving a 'double portion' of Elijah's spirit?
options: Elisha wanted to be twice as powerful as Elijah
The 'double portion' was the inheritance right of the firstborn son — Elisha was claiming to be Elijah's primary spiritual heir and successor, not merely claiming double power
Elisha needed more power because his enemies were stronger
The double portion referred to receiving the Holy Spirit twice
advanced.explanation: In Israelite inheritance law (Deuteronomy 21:17), the firstborn son received a 'double portion' (pi shenayim) — not double the total, but twice the share of each other heir. Elisha's request was not for twice Elijah's power but for recognition as Elijah's primary successor and spiritual firstborn. That Elisha performed roughly twice as many miracles was God's confirmation that the request was granted. Elisha was Elijah's spiritual 'firstborn.'

advanced.question: The miracle of Jesus walking on water (Mark 6:48) contains a detail that most English readers miss: the text says Jesus 'was about to pass by them.' This phrase echoes specific Old Testament theophanies. Which Old Testament passages use similar 'passing by' language to describe divine self-revelation?
options: Genesis 1 (creation) and Genesis 3 (the Fall)
Exodus 33:19-23 (God 'passing by' Moses) and 1 Kings 19:11 (God 'passing by' Elijah at Horeb)
Joshua 3 (crossing the Jordan) and Joshua 6 (walls of Jericho)
Psalm 23 (the Lord is my shepherd) and Psalm 100 (make a joyful noise)
advanced.explanation: The phrase 'he was about to pass by them' (Mark 6:48) deliberately echoes two key theophanies. In Exodus 33:19-23, God tells Moses 'I will cause all my goodness to pass in front of you' as He reveals His glory. In 1 Kings 19:11, God tells Elijah 'The LORD is about to pass by.' Mark is signalling that Jesus walking on the water is a theophany — a divine self-revelation parallel to God's appearances to Moses and Elijah. Jesus IS the God who 'passes by.'

advanced.question: The concept of 'eschatological reversal' is central to understanding Jesus' miracles theologically. What does this concept mean in the context of miracles?
options: That miracles will become more common as the end times approach

Jesus' miracles are previews of the coming age — partial reversals of the effects of the Fall (disease, death, demonic oppression, natural chaos) that anticipate God's complete restoration of creation
That miracles in the Old Testament are more important than New Testament miracles
That each miracle reverses a specific Old Testament curse
advanced.explanation: Jesus' miracles function as 'inaugurated eschatology' in action — they are foretastes of the age to come breaking into the present. Healing reverses the bodily decay that entered through the Fall. Exorcism reverses demonic domination. Nature miracles reverse creation's subjection to chaos. Resurrection reverses death itself. Each miracle is a partial, anticipatory experience of the complete cosmic renewal described in Revelation 21: 'no more death or mourning or crying or pain.' The kingdom has begun but is not yet complete.

advanced.question: The miracle of Jesus healing on the Sabbath is recorded in multiple independent Gospel traditions and always provokes conflict with the religious authorities. How many Sabbath healing controversies are recorded across the four Gospels?
options: Three
Five
Seven
Nine
advanced.explanation: Seven Sabbath healing controversies are recorded: (1) the man with the withered hand (Mark 3:1-6), (2) the man at the Pool of Bethesda (John 5:1-18), (3) the man born blind (John 9:1-41), (4) the bent-over woman (Luke 13:10-17), (5) the man with dropsy (Luke 14:1-6), (6) a man with an unclean spirit in the synagogue (Mark 1:21-28), and (7) Peter's mother-in-law (Mark 1:29-31). The number seven may be intentional — Jesus is Lord of the Sabbath and heals on it perfectly/completely.

advanced.question: In the history of biblical interpretation, the 'demythologisation' programme of Rudolf Bultmann (1941) proposed a radical approach to miracle stories. What did Bultmann argue should be done with the miracle accounts in the Gospels?
options: They should be accepted literally as historical events
The mythological 'husk' (miracles, supernatural elements) should be stripped away to reveal the existential 'kernel' — the call to authentic human existence and decision in the face of God's Word
They should be treated as allegories about moral behaviour
They should be compared with miracles from other religions to find common truths
advanced.explanation: Bultmann argued that modern people cannot accept the three-tiered cosmology (heaven above, earth in the middle, hell below) that underlies the miracle stories. His solution was to 'demythologise' — interpret the myths existentially rather than literally. A miracle story is not about a historical event but about the human experience of being confronted by God's word and challenged to authentic existence. Critics (both conservative and liberal) have argued this approach strips the Gospel of its historical foundation and reduces Christianity to existentialist philosophy.

advanced.question: The miracle accounts in Acts follow a deliberate literary pattern that parallels the miracles of Jesus in the Gospels. Peter raises Tabitha from the dead (Acts 9), Paul raises Eutychus (Acts 20), and both heal lame men. What theological purpose does this parallelism serve?
options: It proves the apostles were equal to Jesus

It demonstrates continuity — the risen Jesus continues his miraculous ministry through his Spirit-empowered church, showing that the book of Acts is really about the ongoing acts of the risen Christ, not just his apostles
It shows the apostles copied Jesus' methods
It was a literary convention with no theological meaning
advanced.explanation: Luke structures Acts to show that Jesus' ministry continues through the church. Peter and Paul's miracles mirror Jesus': raising the dead, healing the lame, exorcisms, nature miracles. But crucially, the apostles always attribute the power to Jesus ('In the name of Jesus Christ, walk' — Acts 3:6). The book's full title could be 'The Continuing Acts of Jesus Christ Through His Spirit-Empowered Church.' The miracles demonstrate the risen Jesus is still actively at work.

advanced.question: Jesus' statement 'Whoever believes in me will do the works I have been doing, and they will do even greater things than these' (John 14:12) has been debated for centuries. What is the most commonly accepted interpretation of 'greater things'?
options: Future believers will perform more spectacular miracles than Jesus did

The 'greater things' refer not to more spectacular miracles but to the wider scope of ministry — through the Holy Spirit, the church would reach every nation and millions of people, accomplishing on a global scale what Jesus did locally in Palestine
Jesus was speaking hyperbolically and didn't mean it literally
Only the twelve apostles would do greater things
advanced.explanation: 'Greater' (meizona) likely refers to scope and extent, not to quality or spectacularity. Jesus' earthly ministry was limited to a small geographic area over three years. Through the Spirit, the church would heal, teach, and transform lives across every continent and throughout all of history. The book of Acts immediately begins fulfilling this: 3,000 saved at Pentecost, the gospel reaching Rome, and eventually the entire world. The 'greater works' are the worldwide expansion of Jesus' kingdom ministry.

advanced.question: The literary structure of the ten plagues of Egypt (Exodus 7-12) reveals a deliberate pattern. Scholars have identified that the plagues are arranged in three triads plus a climactic tenth plague. What pattern does each triad follow?
options: Each triad increases in geographic scope
In each triad, the first plague is announced by the river, the second at the palace, and the third comes without warning — showing an escalating pattern of judgment
Each triad targets a different social class
The triads alternate between natural and supernatural causes
advanced.explanation: The ten plagues follow a precise literary structure: three groups of three, plus the climactic tenth. In each triad: plague 1 (announced at the Nile), plague 2 (announced at the palace), plague 3 (comes without warning). This escalating pattern intensifies Pharaoh's confrontation with God. The triads also escalate in severity: annoyance (blood, frogs, gnats), suffering (flies, livestock, boils), destruction (hail, locusts, darkness), and finally death (firstborn). The structure demonstrates God's measured, escalating judgment.

advanced.question: The concept of 'prophetic sign-acts' (symbolic actions performed by prophets to embody their message) provides context for understanding some of Jesus' more unusual miracles. Which of Jesus' miracles is most clearly interpreted by scholars as a prophetic sign-act rather than (or in addition to) a compassionate healing?
options: Healing the blind man at Bethsaida
Cursing the fig tree — which symbolised God's judgment on fruitless Israel/Temple rather than being an act directed at the tree itself
Feeding the 5,000
Calming the storm
advanced.explanation: The cursing of the fig tree is the clearest example of a prophetic sign-act in Jesus' ministry. Like Jeremiah's smashed pot (Jeremiah 19), Ezekiel's lying on his side (Ezekiel 4), and Hosea's marriage to Gomer (Hosea 1-3), it was a dramatic, embodied prophecy. Mark's 'sandwich' structure — fig tree cursed, Temple cleansed, fig tree withered — makes the connection explicit: the fig tree represents Israel/Temple, which has leaves (religious appearance) but no fruit (genuine faithfulness).

advanced.question: The apostle Paul experienced a 'thorn in the flesh' that he asked God to remove three times, but God refused, saying 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.' This passage raises what important theological question about miracles?
options: Whether Paul was a genuine apostle
Why God sometimes chooses NOT to perform a miracle even when asked by a faithful servant — suggesting that unanswered prayer for healing is not necessarily a sign of insufficient faith
Whether the thorn was a physical or spiritual problem
Whether Paul should have prayed more than three times
advanced.explanation: Paul's unanswered prayer for healing is theologically significant because it comes from the same apostle through whom 'extraordinary miracles' occurred (Acts 19:11). If Paul — who healed others — could not secure his own healing, it demolishes the 'prosperity gospel' claim that sufficient faith always produces healing. God's response reveals a higher purpose: divine power displayed through human weakness. Healing is real but not guaranteed, and God's purposes sometimes include suffering.

advanced.question: The miracle of the virgin birth (or virginal conception) of Jesus is attested in two independent Gospel sources — Matthew and Luke — but is notably absent from Mark and John. How do scholars who affirm the virgin birth typically explain its absence from the other two Gospels?
options: Mark and John didn't believe in the virgin birth

Absence of mention is not the same as denial — Mark begins at Jesus' baptism (not birth), and John's prologue ('the Word became flesh') may presuppose it while addressing Jesus' origins at a deeper cosmic/theological level rather than a biological one
The virgin birth was a later addition to Matthew and Luke
Mark and John were written for audiences that wouldn't have understood the concept
advanced.explanation: The argument from silence is logically weak — Mark doesn't mention Jesus' birth at all (he begins at the baptism), so he neither affirms nor denies the virgin birth. John's prologue ('the Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us') addresses the incarnation at the cosmic level. John 1:13 may contain a veiled reference: some early manuscripts read 'who was born' (singular, referring to Jesus) 'not of natural descent, nor of human decision or a husband's will, but born of God.' The two independent attestations (Matthew and Luke) are actually strong evidence.

advanced.question: The concept of 'divine accommodation' has been used by theologians from Calvin to Warfield to explain how God performs miracles. What does divine accommodation mean in the context of miracles?
options: God adjusts the laws of nature to make miracles seem less dramatic

God adapts his miraculous activity to the cultural context, understanding, and needs of the people — performing different types of miracles in different eras and contexts while maintaining consistent purposes of revelation, redemption, and compassion
God only performs miracles when there is no natural explanation available
God accommodates human doubt by performing miracles on demand
advanced.explanation: Divine accommodation recognises that God's miraculous activity adapts to historical and cultural contexts. In the Exodus, God used dramatic nature miracles appropriate for confronting Egyptian religion. In Jesus' ministry, healings and exorcisms addressed the most pressing needs of first-century Palestine. In Acts, miracles authenticated the apostolic message in new cultural contexts. The purpose is consistent (revelation, redemption, compassion) but the form adapts. This explains why different biblical eras feature different types of miracles.

beginner.question: Jesus' very first miracle, according to John's Gospel, was turning water into wine at a wedding celebration in the village of Cana in Galilee.
beginner.explanation: John 2:11 explicitly calls this 'the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory.' Jesus instructed servants to fill six stone water jars with water, then draw some out. The master of the banquet tasted it and was amazed at the quality of the wine, telling the bridegroom 'You have saved the best till now.' This miracle revealed Jesus' glory and caused his disciples to believe in him.

beginner.question: When Jesus fed the 5,000 people, he started with five barley loaves and two small fish, and after everyone had eaten, the disciples collected twelve baskets of leftover food.
beginner.explanation: A boy had five small barley loaves and two small fish. Jesus gave thanks, broke the bread, and distributed it to the crowd. All 5,000 men (plus women and children) ate until they were satisfied. The twelve baskets of leftovers demonstrate that God's provision through Jesus is always more than enough — there is abundance, not mere sufficiency.

beginner.question: Moses parted the Jordan River to allow the Israelites to escape from the Egyptian army during the Exodus from Egypt.
beginner.explanation: Moses parted the Red Sea (or Sea of Reeds), not the Jordan River, for the escape from Egypt. The Jordan River was parted later by Joshua (Moses' successor) when the Israelites entered the Promised Land. These are two separate miracles — the Red Sea crossing happened at the beginning of the wilderness journey, and the Jordan crossing happened at the end, forty years later.

beginner.question: When Jesus walked on water toward the disciples' boat during a storm, the apostle Peter also walked on the water for a time before he became afraid and began to sink.
beginner.explanation: Peter said 'Lord, if it's you, tell me to come to you on the water.' Jesus said 'Come.' Peter got out of the boat and actually walked on the water toward Jesus. But when he saw the wind and waves, he was afraid and began to sink, crying out 'Lord, save me!' Jesus immediately reached out his hand, caught him, and said 'You of little faith, why did you doubt?'

beginner.question: When Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego were thrown into King Nebuchadnezzar's fiery furnace, they were badly burned but survived thanks to their strong willpower.
beginner.explanation: They were not burned at all — not even slightly. They came out of the furnace without a hair singed, their robes were not scorched, and there was no smell of fire on them. Additionally, Nebuchadnezzar saw a fourth figure in the fire 'like a son of the gods' walking with them. The miracle was not mere survival but complete supernatural protection from a furnace heated seven times hotter than normal.

beginner.question: Jesus raised three people from the dead during his earthly ministry: Jairus' twelve-year-old daughter, the widow of Nain's only son, and his friend Lazarus who had been dead for four days.
beginner.explanation: These three resurrection miracles show an escalating pattern. Jairus' daughter had just died (Mark 5:35-43). The widow of Nain's son was being carried to burial (Luke 7:11-17). Lazarus had been dead and entombed for four days and had begun to decompose (John 11:1-44). Each miracle demonstrated increasing power over death, culminating in Jesus' own resurrection.

beginner.question: When God sent ten plagues upon Egypt, the Israelites were affected by every plague just like the Egyptians — God did not distinguish between the two peoples.
beginner.explanation: God explicitly distinguished between the Israelites and the Egyptians. From the fourth plague onward, God said 'I will make a distinction between my people and your people.' The land of Goshen (where the Israelites lived) was protected from the flies, livestock disease, hail, darkness, and the death of the firstborn (through the blood on their doorframes). This distinction demonstrated God's covenant faithfulness to Israel.

beginner.question: Jonah was swallowed by a great fish and lived inside it for three days and three nights. Jesus later compared Jonah's experience to his own time in the tomb before his resurrection.
beginner.explanation: Jesus said 'For as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of a huge fish, so the Son of Man will be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth' (Matthew 12:40). Jonah's experience became a prophetic foreshadowing of Jesus' death, burial, and resurrection. Just as Jonah emerged from the fish alive, Jesus emerged from the tomb alive on the third day.

beginner.question: Daniel was thrown into the lions' den because he refused to stop praying to God, even though a law had been passed making it illegal to pray to anyone except the king for thirty days.
beginner.explanation: Daniel's enemies knew that the only way to trap him was through his faithfulness to God. They convinced King Darius to sign a decree that anyone who prayed to any god or person except the king for thirty days would be thrown into the lions' den. Daniel knew about the decree but continued to pray three times a day with his windows open toward Jerusalem, just as he had always done.

beginner.question: When Jesus calmed the storm on the Sea of Galilee, he had to pray for several hours before the wind and waves gradually subsided.
beginner.explanation: Jesus did not pray at length — he simply spoke directly to the wind and waves with authority. He said 'Quiet! Be still!' (Mark 4:39) and immediately the wind died down and the sea became completely calm. The instantaneous nature of the miracle was what shocked the disciples: 'Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!' Jesus demonstrated the same authority over nature that God exercised at creation.

beginner.question: The prophet Elijah was fed by ravens during a drought. God sent ravens to bring him bread and meat every morning and evening while he hid by the Brook Cherith.
beginner.explanation: After Elijah told King Ahab that no rain would fall except at Elijah's word, God directed him to hide by the Brook Cherith. 'The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.' Ravens were considered unclean birds in Jewish law, making God's choice of delivery service deliberately surprising and humbling.

beginner.question: When Jesus healed a leper by touching him, this was socially shocking because lepers were considered untouchable outcasts — anyone who touched a leper became ceremonially unclean under Jewish law.
beginner.explanation: Lepers were required to live outside the community, wear torn clothes, cover their mouths, and cry 'Unclean! Unclean!' when anyone approached. Touching a leper made you ceremonially unclean. But when Jesus touched the leper, instead of Jesus becoming unclean, the leper became clean. Jesus reversed the expected direction of contamination — his purity was more powerful than the disease's impurity.

beginner.question: When Jesus told the paralysed man at the Pool of Bethesda to 'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk,' the man was healed but it took several days before he could walk normally.
beginner.explanation: The man was healed instantly. John 5:9 says 'At once the man was cured; he picked up his mat and walked.' The immediacy of healing was characteristic of Jesus' miracles — they were not gradual recoveries but instant, complete restorations. The man had been paralysed for 38 years, but the moment Jesus spoke, he was able to stand, pick up his mat, and walk.

beginner.question: After Peter and John healed a lame man at the Beautiful Gate of the Temple, the man went into the Temple courts 'walking and jumping, and praising God,' and everyone who saw him was filled with wonder.
beginner.explanation: The man, who had been lame from birth and was over 40 years old, was instantly healed when Peter said 'In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk!' He jumped to his feet and went into the Temple, walking, jumping, and praising God. The people recognised him as the beggar who sat at the Beautiful Gate every day, and they were filled with wonder and amazement.

beginner.question: The apostle Peter was miraculously freed from prison by an angel who caused his chains to fall off, led him past sleeping guards, and opened the iron gate by itself — all while Peter thought he was having a dream.
beginner.explanation: Peter was chained between two soldiers, with sentries at the door. An angel appeared, light shone in the cell, and the angel struck Peter to wake him. His chains fell off, and the angel led him past two sets of guards and through the iron gate, which opened by itself. Peter thought he was seeing a vision — it wasn't until he was outside on the street that 'he came to himself' and realised it was real.

beginner.question: When Jesus raised Lazarus from the dead, Lazarus had been in the tomb for only a few hours, which is why the miracle was relatively straightforward.
beginner.explanation: Lazarus had been dead for four days — not a few hours. Martha warned Jesus 'by this time there is a bad odour' because decomposition had begun. In Jewish belief, the soul departed the body after three days, meaning after four days Lazarus was considered irrevocably dead. Jesus deliberately waited to make the miracle undeniable. This was the most dramatic resurrection before Jesus' own.

beginner.question: The walls of Jericho fell after the Israelites used battering rams and siege weapons to break through the fortifications over a period of several weeks.
beginner.explanation: No conventional weapons were used at all. God told the Israelites to march around the city once a day for six days, with seven priests blowing trumpets before the Ark of the Covenant. On the seventh day, they marched around seven times. When the priests blew the trumpets and the people gave a great shout, the walls of Jericho collapsed. The victory was entirely miraculous, requiring only obedient faith.

beginner.question: When God provided manna for the Israelites in the wilderness, they could collect and store as much as they wanted for future use, and it would stay fresh indefinitely.
beginner.explanation: God specifically instructed them to gather only enough for one day. Anyone who tried to store extra found that it 'was full of maggots and began to smell' by morning. The only exception was the sixth day, when they gathered a double portion because no manna appeared on the Sabbath — and the extra portion miraculously stayed fresh overnight. This system taught daily dependence on God.

beginner.question: A Roman centurion demonstrated such remarkable faith that Jesus said 'Truly I tell you, I have not found anyone in Israel with such great faith.' The centurion believed Jesus could heal his servant simply by speaking a word, without needing to visit the sick man.
beginner.explanation: The centurion understood authority — he said 'I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, Go, and he goes; and that one, Come, and he comes.' He recognised that Jesus had the same kind of authority over sickness. Jesus was amazed and said this Gentile's faith exceeded anything he had found in Israel. The servant was healed at that very hour.

beginner.question: When the prophet Elisha purified a pot of stew that had been accidentally poisoned with wild gourds, he threw flour into the pot and the stew became safe to eat.
beginner.explanation: During a famine, one of the prophets gathered wild gourds (not knowing they were poisonous) and shredded them into the pot of stew. When they tasted it, they cried out 'There is death in the pot!' Elisha said 'Get some flour,' threw it into the pot, and said 'Serve it to the people to eat.' The flour had no natural ability to neutralise poison — God used this simple act as the vehicle for a miracle.

beginner.question: Jesus healed ten lepers at once, sending them to show themselves to the priests, and all ten returned to thank him for their healing.
beginner.explanation: Only ONE of the ten returned to thank Jesus — and he was a Samaritan (a foreigner). Jesus asked 'Were not all ten cleansed? Where are the other nine? Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner?' The 90% ingratitude rate highlights that receiving God's blessing doesn't automatically produce gratitude. The one who returned received not just physical healing but spiritual salvation.

beginner.question: When Moses threw his staff on the ground before Pharaoh, it became a snake. Pharaoh's magicians duplicated this feat, but Moses' snake swallowed all of their snakes.
beginner.explanation: When Moses threw down his staff and it became a snake, Pharaoh's sorcerers and magicians did the same thing with their staffs through their secret arts — their staffs also became snakes. But then Aaron's (Moses') staff swallowed up their staffs. This demonstrated that while Egyptian magic could imitate some divine signs, God's power was ultimately superior and would consume all imitations.

beginner.question: Jesus' miracle of walking on water is recorded in three of the four Gospels — Matthew, Mark, and John — but not in Luke.
beginner.explanation: The walking on water miracle appears in Matthew 14:22-33, Mark 6:45-52, and John 6:16-21, but Luke does not include it. Matthew's account is the most detailed, including Peter's attempt to walk on water. John's is the briefest but includes the notable detail that the boat 'immediately reached the shore where they were heading.' Luke may have omitted it due to space or thematic considerations.

beginner.question: The burning bush that Moses encountered in the wilderness was unusual because it was on fire but was not consumed by the flames — it kept burning without being destroyed.
beginner.explanation: Exodus 3:2 says 'the bush was on fire but it did not burn up.' When Moses turned aside to investigate this strange sight, God called to him from within the bush and told him to remove his sandals because he was standing on holy ground. The unconsumed bush was a sign of God's presence — fire that illuminates and purifies without destroying, just as God's holy presence would dwell among His people without consuming them.

beginner.question: After Jesus' resurrection, he appeared to his disciples on the shore of the Sea of Galilee and miraculously directed them to catch 153 large fish after they had caught nothing all night.
beginner.explanation: The disciples had fished all night without catching anything. Jesus (whom they didn't initially recognise) called from shore 'Throw your net on the right side of the boat and you will find some.' When they obeyed, they were unable to haul in the net because of the large number of fish — exactly 153 large fish. Despite the enormous catch, the net was not torn. John recognised Jesus and said 'It is the Lord!'

beginner.question: When Paul and Silas were in prison in Philippi at midnight, they were praying and singing hymns to God when a violent earthquake shook the foundations of the prison, opened all the doors, and loosened everyone's chains.
beginner.explanation: Despite being beaten, thrown into the inner cell, and having their feet fastened in stocks, Paul and Silas prayed and sang hymns at midnight while the other prisoners listened. A violent earthquake shook the prison foundations, every door flew open, and everyone's chains came loose. The jailer, assuming the prisoners had escaped, drew his sword to kill himself — but Paul shouted 'Don't harm yourself! We are all here!'

beginner.question: The feeding of the 5,000 is the only miracle of Jesus (other than the resurrection) that is recorded in all four Gospels — Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John.
beginner.explanation: This miracle appears in Matthew 14:13-21, Mark 6:30-44, Luke 9:10-17, and John 6:1-14. The fact that all four Gospel writers chose to include it emphasises its significance in the early church's memory of Jesus. No other miracle (except the resurrection itself) received this universal attestation across all four independent Gospel traditions.

beginner.question: When Jesus healed the man born blind in John 9, the Pharisees were so impressed by the miracle that they immediately accepted Jesus as the Messiah and praised God.
beginner.explanation: The Pharisees were furious, not impressed. They interrogated the healed man multiple times, called his parents to testify, accused Jesus of being a sinner for healing on the Sabbath, and ultimately threw the healed man out of the synagogue. The man himself had more spiritual insight than the Pharisees — when asked what he thought of Jesus, he said 'He is a prophet,' and later worshipped Jesus as 'Lord.'

beginner.question: God led the Israelites through the wilderness with a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night, guiding them on their journey for forty years.
beginner.explanation: Exodus 13:21-22 says 'By day the LORD went ahead of them in a pillar of cloud to guide them on their way and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel by day or night. Neither the pillar of cloud by day nor the pillar of fire by night left its place in front of the people.' These visible manifestations of God's presence guided, protected, and illuminated Israel throughout their entire wilderness journey.

beginner.question: When Elijah challenged the prophets of Baal on Mount Carmel, he made the challenge harder by pouring twelve jars of water on his altar and sacrifice before calling on God to send fire.
beginner.explanation: During a severe drought (when water was extremely precious), Elijah ordered twelve large jars of water poured over his sacrifice and altar — four jars three times. The water ran down, filling the trench around the altar. This made the miracle even more dramatic — not only did God send fire, but the fire consumed the sacrifice, the wood, the stones, the soil, and licked up all the water in the trench. There was no natural explanation possible.

beginner.question: The widow of Zarephath's jar of flour and jug of oil miraculously never ran out during the entire three-year drought, just as the prophet Elijah had promised in the name of the LORD.
beginner.explanation: Elijah told the destitute widow 'The jar of flour will not be used up and the jug of oil will not run dry until the day the LORD sends rain on the land.' The widow obeyed in faith, making bread for Elijah first despite having only enough for one last meal for herself and her son. For the entire duration of the drought, the flour and oil supernaturally replenished — a daily miracle of provision.

beginner.question: When God parted the Red Sea for the Israelites, the water formed walls on both their left and right sides, and they walked through on completely dry ground.
beginner.explanation: Exodus 14:22 states 'The Israelites went through the sea on dry ground, with a wall of water on their right and on their left.' God drove the sea back with a strong east wind all night long, turning the seabed into dry land. The water stood up like walls on both sides, creating a corridor for the entire nation to pass through safely. When the Egyptians followed, God released the waters.

beginner.question: When Jesus was arrested in the Garden of Gethsemane, Peter cut off the ear of the high priest's servant with a sword. Jesus healed the servant's ear — his last miracle before the crucifixion.
beginner.explanation: Peter struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his right ear. The servant's name was Malchus (John 18:10). Jesus said 'No more of this!' and touched the man's ear and healed it (Luke 22:51). This was Jesus' final healing miracle, performed for a member of the very group arresting him. Even at the moment of his arrest, Jesus showed compassion to his enemies.

beginner.question: When four friends lowered a paralysed man through the roof to reach Jesus, Jesus first forgave the man's sins before healing his body — which caused the religious leaders to accuse Jesus of blasphemy.
beginner.explanation: Jesus saw the faith of the four friends and said 'Son, your sins are forgiven.' The teachers of the law thought 'Why does this fellow talk like that? He's blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?' Jesus knew their thoughts and said 'Which is easier: to say "Your sins are forgiven" or "Get up and walk"?' Then he healed the paralytic to prove he had authority to forgive sins — connecting physical healing to spiritual restoration.

beginner.question: The miracle of Jesus turning water into wine at the wedding in Cana was performed using six stone water jars that each held twenty to thirty gallons, meaning Jesus created approximately 120 to 180 gallons of excellent wine.
beginner.explanation: John 2:6 specifies 'six stone water jars, the kind used by the Jews for ceremonial washing, each holding from twenty to thirty gallons.' This means Jesus created between 120 and 180 gallons of wine — an extraordinary amount. The master of the banquet remarked on its exceptional quality: 'You have saved the best till now.' The lavish quantity and superior quality symbolised the abundant, superior nature of the messianic age Jesus was inaugurating.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elisha performed a miracle after his own death — when a dead man's body was thrown into Elisha's tomb and touched his bones, the dead man came back to life.
intermediate.explanation: 2 Kings 13:20-21 records this unique posthumous miracle. Moabite raiders were approaching, so some Israelites hastily threw a dead man's body into Elisha's tomb. When the body touched Elisha's bones, the man came to life and stood on his feet. This is the only posthumous miracle in the Bible and fulfilled Elisha's request for a 'double portion' of Elijah's spirit — God's power continued even after the prophet's death.

intermediate.question: Jesus performed two separate feeding miracles — feeding 5,000 with five loaves and two fish (with twelve baskets of leftovers) and feeding 4,000 with seven loaves and a few fish (with seven baskets of leftovers).
intermediate.explanation: These are two distinct miracles recorded in different locations and circumstances. The feeding of the 5,000 appears in all four Gospels (Matthew 14, Mark 6, Luke 9, John 6), while the feeding of the 4,000 appears in Matthew 15 and Mark 8. Jesus himself distinguished between the two events: 'Don't you remember the five loaves for the five thousand, and how many basketfuls you gathered? Or the seven loaves for the four thousand?' (Matthew 16:9-10).

intermediate.question: When God sent the ten plagues on Egypt, Pharaoh's magicians were able to duplicate the first two plagues (turning water to blood and producing frogs) through their own 'secret arts,' but they could not replicate the third plague (gnats/lice).
intermediate.explanation: Pharaoh's magicians replicated the first plague (blood — Exodus 7:22) and the second (frogs — Exodus 8:7) through their secret arts. But when Aaron struck the dust and gnats appeared everywhere, the magicians tried to produce gnats but could not. They told Pharaoh 'This is the finger of God.' From this point onward, the magicians could not compete with God's power and eventually could not even appear before Moses due to the plague of boils.

intermediate.question: In the book of Acts, handkerchiefs and aprons that had merely touched the apostle Paul were taken to sick people, and their illnesses were cured and evil spirits left them.
intermediate.explanation: Acts 19:11-12 records that 'God did extraordinary miracles through Paul, so that even handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched him were taken to the sick, and their illnesses were cured and the evil spirits left them.' Luke specifically calls these 'extraordinary' miracles — unusual even by apostolic standards. This occurred during Paul's two-year ministry in Ephesus. The power was clearly God's, channelled through Paul's physical contact with the objects.

intermediate.question: When Jesus healed a blind man at Bethsaida, the healing occurred in two stages — after the first touch, the man could see people but they looked 'like trees walking around,' and only after Jesus' second touch was his sight fully restored.
intermediate.explanation: This is the only recorded two-stage miracle of Jesus (Mark 8:22-26). After Jesus spat on the man's eyes and laid his hands on him the first time, the man said 'I see people; they look like trees walking around.' Jesus put his hands on the man's eyes again, and this time his sight was fully restored — he could see everything clearly. Many scholars see this as a parable about the disciples' gradual understanding of Jesus' identity.

intermediate.question: The miracle of Joshua commanding the sun to stand still over Gibeon lasted for approximately one full day — 'The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down about a full day.'
intermediate.explanation: Joshua 10:13 states 'The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down about a full day. There has never been a day like it before or since, a day when the LORD listened to a human being.' Joshua needed extra daylight to complete the military victory over the Amorites. This is one of the most debated miracles in the Bible — whether it was a literal solar event, atmospheric phenomenon, or literary expression of divine intervention.

intermediate.question: When the apostle Peter's shadow fell on sick people in the streets of Jerusalem, all of them were healed — according to the book of Acts.
intermediate.explanation: Acts 5:15-16 records that 'people brought the sick into the streets and laid them on beds and mats so that at least Peter's shadow might fall on some of them as he passed by. Crowds gathered also from the towns around Jerusalem, bringing their sick and those tormented by impure spirits, and all of them were healed.' This extraordinary miracle demonstrated the power of the risen Christ working through the apostolic church.

intermediate.question: When Naaman the Syrian general was healed of leprosy by washing seven times in the Jordan River as Elisha instructed, he was initially furious because he expected a more dramatic healing method and considered the rivers of Damascus to be cleaner.
intermediate.explanation: Naaman expected Elisha to come out personally, stand before him, call on God's name, wave his hand over the leprosy, and dramatically cure him. Instead, Elisha didn't even come to the door — he sent a messenger with simple instructions. Naaman was enraged: 'Are not Abana and Pharpar, the rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel?' His servants wisely persuaded him: 'If the prophet had told you to do some great thing, would you not have done it?'

intermediate.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus only performed miracles in Jewish territory and never healed or helped Gentiles (non-Jews) during his ministry.
intermediate.explanation: Jesus performed miracles for several Gentiles: the Roman centurion's servant (Matthew 8:5-13), the Syrophoenician woman's daughter (Mark 7:24-30), the Gerasene demoniac in the Decapolis (Mark 5:1-20), and the feeding of the 4,000 which likely occurred in predominantly Gentile territory. Jesus praised the centurion's faith as greater than any he found in Israel. These Gentile healings foreshadowed the gospel going to all nations.

intermediate.question: When Paul was bitten by a venomous snake on the island of Malta after his shipwreck, he suffered no ill effects whatsoever — the islanders initially expected him to die but then changed their minds and thought he was a god.
intermediate.explanation: Acts 28:3-6 records that a viper fastened onto Paul's hand as he was gathering sticks for a fire. The islanders expected him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. But Paul shook the snake off into the fire and suffered no harm. After watching for a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen, the islanders changed their minds and said he must be a god. Paul then went on to heal the father of the island's chief official.

intermediate.question: When God parted the Jordan River for Joshua and the Israelites to cross into the Promised Land, the priests carrying the Ark of the Covenant had to stand in the middle of the dry riverbed until all the people had crossed.
intermediate.explanation: Joshua 3:17 states 'The priests who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD stopped in the middle of the Jordan and stood on dry ground, while all Israel passed by until the whole nation had completed the crossing on dry ground.' The priests' role was crucial — they represented God's presence (through the Ark) literally standing in the gap so the people could pass safely. As soon as the priests came out, the waters returned.

intermediate.question: The miracle of Jesus cursing the fig tree and it withering overnight was simply Jesus being frustrated and hungry — it had no deeper symbolic or prophetic meaning.
intermediate.explanation: The cursing of the fig tree was a prophetic sign-act, not an expression of hunger frustration. Mark deliberately 'sandwiches' the fig tree incident around the Temple cleansing (fig tree cursed → Temple cleansed → fig tree withered), connecting them thematically. The fig tree represented Israel/Temple — it had impressive leaves (religious activity) but no fruit (genuine faithfulness). The withering symbolised coming judgment on a fruitless religious system.

intermediate.question: When Elisha told the widow to collect as many empty jars as she could and pour her small amount of oil into them, the oil miraculously kept flowing until every jar was full — but it stopped flowing when there were no more empty jars left.
intermediate.explanation: 2 Kings 4:6 records that when the last jar was full, 'the oil stopped flowing.' The amount of the miracle matched the amount of the woman's preparation (faith). If she had collected more jars, more oil would have flowed. Elisha then told her to sell the oil, pay her debts, and live on the rest. The miracle principle: God's supply matches the vessel of faith provided.

intermediate.question: The young man Eutychus fell from a third-storey window during Paul's sermon in Troas and died. Paul went down, embraced him, and declared he was alive — and Eutychus was restored to life.
intermediate.explanation: Acts 20:9-12 says Eutychus 'sank into a deep sleep as Paul talked on and on. When he was sound asleep, he fell to the ground from the third storey and was picked up dead.' Paul went down, threw himself on the young man, put his arms around him, and said 'Don't be alarmed. He's alive!' The people took the young man home alive and were greatly comforted. Notably, Paul then went back upstairs and continued talking until daylight!

intermediate.question: In the Old Testament, Aaron's staff miraculously budded, blossomed, and produced almonds overnight — serving as God's confirmation that the tribe of Levi was chosen for the priesthood.
intermediate.explanation: After Korah's rebellion questioned the priestly authority of Aaron's family, God settled the dispute. He told Moses to collect one staff from each of the twelve tribal leaders and place them in the Tabernacle overnight. The next morning, Aaron's staff (representing Levi) had budded, blossomed, and produced ripe almonds — going through an entire growing season overnight. God commanded that Aaron's staff be kept before the Ark as a permanent sign.

intermediate.question: When Elisha struck the Jordan River with Elijah's cloak, the water divided just as it had for Elijah, confirming that Elisha had received Elijah's prophetic authority.
intermediate.explanation: After Elijah was taken to heaven in a whirlwind, Elisha picked up Elijah's cloak, went back to the Jordan River, struck the water with it, and said 'Where now is the LORD, the God of Elijah?' The water divided to the right and to the left, and Elisha crossed over. When the company of prophets saw this, they said 'The spirit of Elijah is resting on Elisha,' and they bowed to the ground before him.

intermediate.question: The miracle of Jesus healing the woman who had been bleeding for twelve years occurred while Jesus was on his way to heal someone else — Jairus' daughter — making it an interruption that tested Jairus' faith in Jesus' ability to help his dying daughter.
intermediate.explanation: Jairus had begged Jesus to come urgently because his daughter was dying. On the way, Jesus stopped because the bleeding woman touched his cloak. During this delay, messengers arrived saying Jairus' daughter had died. The delay tested Jairus' faith — would he still believe when the situation seemed hopeless? Jesus told him 'Don't be afraid; just believe.' He went on to raise the girl from the dead, demonstrating that God's timing is perfect even when it seems too late.

intermediate.question: During the battle against the Amorites, God not only made the sun stand still for Joshua but also sent large hailstones that killed more enemies than the Israelite soldiers did with their swords.
intermediate.explanation: Joshua 10:11 records that 'the LORD hurled large hailstones down on them, and more of them died from the hail than were killed by the swords of the Israelites.' The hailstones fell on the fleeing Amorite army but not on the Israelites. This was followed by the sun standing still for about a full day. Together, these miracles ensured complete victory and demonstrated that God was fighting for Israel.

intermediate.question: When Peter raised Tabitha (Dorcas) from the dead in Joppa, his method closely paralleled what Jesus had done when raising Jairus' daughter — he sent everyone out of the room, prayed, and spoke to the dead person.
intermediate.explanation: The parallels are striking: Jesus put everyone out before raising Jairus' daughter (Mark 5:40), and Peter 'sent them all out of the room' (Acts 9:40). Jesus took Jairus' daughter's hand and said 'Talitha koum' ('Little girl, get up'), and Peter said 'Tabitha, get up' — the Aramaic names are almost identical (Talitha/Tabitha). Peter's actions show he was modelling his ministry on Jesus' example. The miracle became known throughout Joppa and many believed.

intermediate.question: The prophet Elisha multiplied twenty barley loaves to feed one hundred men — a miracle that Jesus later exceeded by feeding thousands with even fewer loaves.
intermediate.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:42-44, a man brought Elisha twenty loaves of barley bread. Elisha said 'Give it to the people to eat.' His servant objected: 'How can I set this before a hundred men?' Elisha repeated 'They will eat and have some left over.' They ate and had leftovers, just as Elisha had said. Jesus' feeding miracles (5,000 with five loaves, 4,000 with seven) far exceeded Elisha's, demonstrating that Jesus was 'greater than' the prophets.

intermediate.question: When an iron axe head fell into the Jordan River, the prophet Elisha made it float to the surface by throwing a stick into the water — one of the more unusual miracles in the Old Testament.
intermediate.explanation: A young prophet was cutting trees when his borrowed axe head fell into the Jordan River. He cried out to Elisha in distress because the axe was borrowed. Elisha asked 'Where did it fall?' When shown the spot, Elisha cut a stick and threw it into the water. The heavy iron axe head floated to the surface, defying the law of gravity. The young man reached out and took it. This miracle demonstrated God's care for everyday, practical concerns.

intermediate.question: According to Acts, when Paul was in Ephesus, some Jewish exorcists tried to cast out demons using Jesus' name without actually being believers, saying 'In the name of the Jesus whom Paul preaches, I command you to come out.' The evil spirit responded by saying 'Jesus I know, and Paul I know about, but who are you?' and attacked them.
intermediate.explanation: The seven sons of Sceva (a Jewish chief priest) tried to use Jesus' name as a magical formula without genuine faith. The evil spirit said 'Jesus I know, and Paul I know about, but who are you?' and the possessed man attacked them — they fled the house naked and bleeding. This incident 'became known to the Jews and Greeks living in Ephesus,' and 'the name of the Lord Jesus was held in high honour.'

intermediate.question: When God destroyed the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah with fire and brimstone from heaven, Lot's wife looked back at the burning cities despite being warned not to, and she was turned into a pillar of salt.
intermediate.explanation: Genesis 19:26 states simply: 'But Lot's wife looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.' The angels had explicitly warned 'Don't look back, and don't stop anywhere in the plain!' Her looking back may have represented longing for the condemned city's lifestyle rather than moving forward in obedience. Jesus referenced this event in Luke 17:32: 'Remember Lot's wife!' — warning against attachment to worldly things when God calls for decisive action.

intermediate.question: The ninth plague of Egypt — three days of complete darkness — was so thick that 'no one could see anyone else or move about for three days,' but the Israelites had light in their dwellings.
intermediate.explanation: Exodus 10:21-23 describes a 'darkness that can be felt' covering all of Egypt for three days. No one could see anyone else or leave their place. But 'all the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.' This plague was a direct attack on Ra, the Egyptian sun god — the most powerful deity in the Egyptian pantheon. YHWH demonstrated absolute power over the very source of light that the Egyptians worshipped.

intermediate.question: When Elisha was surrounded by the Aramean army sent to capture him, he prayed and God struck the entire enemy army with blindness. Elisha then led the blinded soldiers to Samaria and told the king of Israel to kill them all.
intermediate.explanation: Elisha did pray for God to strike the army with blindness, and he did lead them to Samaria. However, he did NOT tell the king to kill them. When the king asked 'Shall I kill them?', Elisha said 'Would you kill those you have captured with your own sword and bow? Set food and water before them so that they may eat and drink and then go back to their master.' The king prepared a great feast for them and sent them home. After that, the Aramean raids stopped.

intermediate.question: The apostle Paul experienced a dramatic conversion on the road to Damascus when the risen Jesus appeared to him in a blinding light. This encounter left Paul physically blind for three days until a believer named Ananias came and laid hands on him, restoring his sight.
intermediate.explanation: Acts 9 records that a light from heaven flashed around Paul (then called Saul), and Jesus' voice said 'Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me?' Paul was blinded for three days and didn't eat or drink. God told a reluctant believer named Ananias to go to Paul. When Ananias laid his hands on Paul, something like scales fell from Paul's eyes and his sight was restored. He was baptised and began preaching that Jesus was the Son of God.

intermediate.question: When Jesus healed the woman bent over double for eighteen years in the synagogue, he attributed her condition to Satan — saying she was 'a woman whom Satan has kept bound for eighteen long years.'
intermediate.explanation: Luke 13:16 records Jesus' words: 'Then should not this woman, a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has kept bound for eighteen long years, be set free on the Sabbath day from what bound her?' This is significant because Jesus attributed her physical condition to spiritual bondage — not to personal sin or simple physical disease. Her healing was both physical (she straightened up) and spiritual (she was freed from Satan's bondage).

intermediate.question: According to the Gospels, Jesus sometimes chose NOT to perform miracles in certain places. In his hometown of Nazareth, 'he could not do any miracles there, except lay his hands on a few sick people and heal them' — and the reason given was the people's lack of faith.
intermediate.explanation: Mark 6:5-6 records 'He could not do any miracles there, except lay his hands on a few sick people and heal them. He was amazed at their lack of faith.' The people of Nazareth said 'Isn't this the carpenter's son?' and were offended by him.
