Jesus responded with the Rich Fool parable, showing that accumulating wealth while being spiritually bankrupt is the ultimate foolishness.

intermediate.question: The Parable of the Good Samaritan mentions that the priest and the Levite 'passed by on the other side' of the road when they saw the beaten man. Biblical scholars have identified a possible reason related to Jewish purity laws. What was it?
options: They were late for an important meeting
If the man was dead or dying, touching him would make them ceremonially unclean — unable to perform their Temple duties — so they chose ritual purity over human compassion
They thought it was a trap set by robbers
They didn't see the man because the road was dark
intermediate.explanation: Under Jewish law, contact with a dead body caused seven days of ceremonial uncleanness (Numbers 19:11). For a priest or Levite heading to Temple service, this would disqualify them from their duties. The parable forces a choice: obey the purity law (don't touch what might be a corpse) or obey the law of love (help a dying man). Jesus' answer is clear — human compassion trumps ritual requirements. The Samaritan, unconcerned with Jewish purity laws, simply saw a human being in need and helped.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, when the father saw his son returning from a great distance, he did something that was considered deeply undignified for an elderly Middle Eastern patriarch. What did the father do?
options: He sent a servant to meet the son
He ran to his son — running was considered shameful for a dignified older man in that culture, as it required hitching up one's robes and exposing one's legs
He waited at the gate until the son arrived
He called the entire village to witness the return
intermediate.explanation: Kenneth Bailey's research into Middle Eastern culture reveals that a distinguished older man would never run — it was considered deeply undignified and shameful. The father had to hitch up his robes, exposing his legs, and run through the village. Some scholars suggest the father ran to reach his son before the village did, because the village might have performed a 'kezazah' ceremony (breaking a pot and declaring the son cut off) for squandering the family wealth among Gentiles. The father's run was an act of protective love, absorbing the shame himself.

intermediate.question: Jesus told a parable about a tower builder and a king going to war, both of whom needed to count the cost before beginning. In what context did Jesus tell these twin parables?
options: He was teaching about financial planning

He was teaching about the cost of discipleship — warning that following him requires total commitment, like a builder who must calculate the full cost before starting or a king who must assess whether he can win before going to war
He was discussing military strategy
He was advising on building projects
intermediate.explanation: Jesus was speaking to large crowds who were following him, and he said 'If anyone comes to me and does not hate father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters — yes, even their own life — such a person cannot be my disciple.' He then told the tower and war parables to illustrate that discipleship requires counting the full cost beforehand. A half-built tower is a monument to foolishness; a king who can't win should sue for peace. Following Jesus is not a casual decision — it demands everything.

intermediate.question: The 'Parable of the Two Debtors' is a brief parable Jesus told at a dinner hosted by a Pharisee named Simon, after a sinful woman washed Jesus' feet with her tears and anointed them with perfume. What was the parable's core question?
options: 'Which debtor was more honest?'
'Now which of them will love the moneylender more?' — the one forgiven a larger debt (500 denarii) or the one forgiven a smaller debt (50 denarii)
'Which debtor will repay the money first?'
'Which debtor was more righteous?'
intermediate.explanation: Two people owed money to a moneylender. One owed 500 denarii, the other 50. Neither could pay, so the moneylender cancelled both debts. Jesus asked Simon 'Which will love him more?' Simon answered 'The one who had the bigger debt forgiven.' Jesus replied 'You have judged correctly.' He then pointed to the woman: she loved much because she had been forgiven much. Simon, who saw himself as having little to be forgiven, showed little love. The parable reveals that awareness of forgiveness produces love.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Ten Virgins, the oil in the lamps is commonly interpreted as representing something essential that cannot be shared or borrowed at the last minute. What do most scholars believe the oil represents?
options: Financial wealth
Genuine personal faith, spiritual preparedness, and a living relationship with God — something that cannot be transferred from one person to another
Knowledge of Scripture
Church membership
intermediate.explanation: While interpretations vary, the most common view is that the oil represents genuine spiritual readiness — personal faith, the Holy Spirit's presence, or authentic relationship with God. The key detail is that it cannot be shared: 'There may not be enough for both us and you.' Spiritual preparedness is personal — no one else's faith can substitute for yours at the decisive moment. The foolish virgins had the outward form (lamps) but lacked the inner reality (oil) needed when the bridegroom finally arrived.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Sheep and the Goats (Matthew 25), Jesus identifies himself with 'the least of these brothers and sisters of mine.' This phrase — 'the least of these' — has been debated by scholars. What are the two main interpretations?
options: Whether 'these' refers to angels or humans
Whether 'the least of these brothers and sisters' refers specifically to Christian missionaries/disciples whom people helped or rejected, OR more broadly to any person in need regardless of faith
Whether 'the least' means children or adults
Whether the parable applies to Jews or Gentiles only
intermediate.explanation: The narrow interpretation holds that 'my brothers and sisters' refers to Jesus' followers (especially travelling missionaries — Matthew 10:40-42) — nations are judged by how they treated Christian messengers. The broad interpretation sees 'the least of these' as any suffering person. The narrow reading is supported by Matthew's use of 'brothers' for disciples (12:49-50, 28:10). The broad reading emphasises universal compassion. Either way, the parable teaches that how we treat vulnerable people reveals our relationship with Jesus.

intermediate.question: Jesus' Parable of the Dishonest Manager (Luke 16) concludes with a famous statement about the relationship between God and money. What did Jesus say?
options: 'Money is the root of all evil'
'No one can serve two masters. Either you will hate the one and love the other, or you will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money (Mammon)'
'Give all your money to the poor'
'The love of money leads to destruction'
intermediate.explanation: Jesus' conclusion — 'You cannot serve both God and Mammon' — uses the Aramaic word 'Mammon' (wealth/material possessions) and personifies it as a rival master competing with God for our allegiance. Luke notes that 'the Pharisees, who loved money, heard all this and were sneering at Jesus.' The statement is absolute: you can USE money while serving God, but you cannot SERVE money while serving God. Money is a tool, not a master. The moment it becomes your master, it displaces God.

intermediate.question: The Parable of the Growing Seed (Mark 4:26-29) is unique to Mark's Gospel — it appears in no other Gospel. A farmer scatters seed on the ground and then goes about his normal life. 'Night and day, whether he sleeps or gets up, the seed sprouts and grows, though he does not know how.' What key teaching about the kingdom of God does this unique parable convey?
options: That farmers should work harder
That the kingdom of God grows by its own inherent divine power — mysteriously, gradually, and inevitably — without depending on human effort to make it grow
That agriculture is sacred work
That seeds need sunlight to grow
intermediate.explanation: This parable emphasises the mysterious, autonomous growth of God's kingdom. The farmer does his part (scattering seed) but the growth happens 'all by itself' (Greek: automate — the origin of our word 'automatic'). The farmer doesn't understand how it grows. The kingdom of God has its own inherent life force — it will grow and reach harvest inevitably, not because of human effort but because of God's power working through the word that has been sown.

intermediate.question: In Luke's version of the Parable of the Great Banquet (Luke 14), the host sends servants out twice to fill the banquet hall. The first time they bring people from 'the streets and alleys of the town.' The second time they go further afield. Where does the host send them the second time?
options: To other towns and cities

'Go out to the roads and country lanes and compel them to come in, so that my house will be full' — representing the extension of God's invitation beyond the city (Israel) to the wider world (Gentiles)
To the marketplace
To the Temple
intermediate.explanation: The two-stage invitation pattern is significant: first, servants gather people from within the city (representing the marginalised within Israel — the poor, crippled, blind, lame). Then servants are sent beyond the city boundaries to the 'roads and country lanes' (representing Gentiles and outsiders). This mirrors the pattern in Acts: the gospel goes first to Jerusalem, then to Judea and Samaria, then to the ends of the earth. God's banquet hall will be filled, even if the original invitees refuse.

intermediate.question: The Parable of the Friend at Midnight (Luke 11:5-8) teaches about prayer through a scenario involving hospitality obligations. In Middle Eastern culture, why was the man so desperate for bread at midnight that he disturbed his sleeping friend?
options: He was simply hungry
An unexpected guest had arrived and hospitality was a sacred duty — failing to provide food for a guest would bring shame not just on the host but on the entire village
He needed bread for a religious ceremony
He was baking for a market day
intermediate.explanation: In ancient Middle Eastern culture, hospitality was not optional — it was a sacred obligation that reflected on the entire community's honour. If a guest arrived and the host had no bread, the shame extended to the whole village. The man's midnight request was not selfish but desperate — he HAD to provide for his guest. Kenneth Bailey notes that the word translated 'persistence' (anaideia) actually means 'avoidance of shame' — the sleeping friend would eventually help because refusing would bring shame on his own village.

intermediate.question: Jesus told a parable about a Pharisee named Simon who invited Jesus to dinner but failed to provide basic courtesies. Jesus pointed out three things Simon failed to do that even a minimal host would provide. What were these three omissions?
options: Failed to pray, read Scripture, and offer a sacrifice
Failed to provide water for Jesus' feet, a kiss of greeting, and oil for his head — all standard hospitality gestures that Simon deliberately withheld
Failed to introduce Jesus, offer him the best seat, and serve wine
Failed to wash Jesus' hands, face, and feet
intermediate.explanation: Jesus said to Simon: 'I came into your house. You did not give me any water for my feet, but she wet my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair. You did not give me a kiss, but this woman has not stopped kissing my feet. You did not put oil on my head, but she has poured perfume on my feet.' Simon's deliberate omission of basic hospitality was a subtle insult — he invited Jesus but treated him with disrespect. The 'sinful' woman showed more honour than the 'righteous' Pharisee.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Barren Fig Tree (Luke 13), the gardener asks the vineyard owner for one more year to dig around the tree and fertilise it before cutting it down. Jesus told this parable immediately after discussing two tragic current events. What were they?
options: A drought and a flood

Pilate's massacre of Galilean worshippers (mixing their blood with their sacrifices) and the collapse of the tower of Siloam that killed eighteen people — Jesus used these events to discuss repentance, not political tragedy
Two earthquakes that destroyed nearby towns
The deaths of two prominent religious leaders
intermediate.explanation: People told Jesus about Galileans whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices, and Jesus referenced eighteen people killed when the tower of Siloam fell. In both cases, Jesus asked 'Do you think they were worse sinners than everyone else?' His answer: 'No! But unless you repent, you too will all perish.' The fig tree parable immediately follows — Israel is like the barren tree being given one last chance to bear fruit before judgment. The current events were a wake-up call, not proof of others' sinfulness.

intermediate.question: The Parable of the Mustard Seed contains an element that would have startled Jesus' audience. The mustard plant in Palestine was known for growing into a large shrub, and Jesus says 'the birds come and perch in its branches.' In Old Testament prophetic literature, what did a great tree sheltering birds typically symbolise?
options: A beautiful garden
A great empire or kingdom that provides shelter and safety for many nations — echoing Daniel 4 (Nebuchadnezzar's tree) and Ezekiel 17 and 31 (cedar of Lebanon)
Paradise or the Garden of Eden
The Temple in Jerusalem
intermediate.explanation: In Daniel 4:12, Nebuchadnezzar's kingdom is pictured as a tree 'whose top touched the sky, visible to the ends of the earth, with beautiful leaves and abundant fruit, providing food for all. Under it wild animals found shelter, and the birds lived in its branches.' Similarly, Ezekiel 17:23 and 31:6 use the same imagery for great empires. By using this imagery for the mustard plant (a humble shrub, not a mighty cedar), Jesus subversively suggests that God's kingdom starts smaller and humbler than any human empire but will grow to shelter all nations.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Talents, the master's statement 'Well done, good and faithful servant' is identical for both the five-talent and two-talent servants despite their different results. The one-talent servant's excuse was 'I knew that you are a hard man... so I was afraid.' How did the master respond to this excuse?
options: He accepted the excuse and forgave the servant
He called the servant 'wicked and lazy' and said 'If you knew I was a hard man, you should have at least put my money on deposit with the bankers, so I would have received it back with interest'
He gave the servant another chance
He reduced the servant's punishment
intermediate.explanation: The master's response is devastating: he judges the servant by his own words. 'If you truly believed I was harsh, that should have motivated you to at least do the bare minimum — put the money in the bank for interest. Instead, fear paralysed you into doing nothing.' The master then takes the one talent and gives it to the servant with ten. The principle: 'Whoever has will be given more; whoever does not have, even what they have will be taken from them.' The parable warns that fearful inaction with God's gifts is not caution — it's disobedience.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Rich Man and Lazarus, Abraham tells the rich man that a 'great chasm has been set in place' between paradise and Hades, so that no one can cross from one side to the other. This detail addresses which theological question?
options: Whether prayers for the dead are effective
Whether there is an opportunity to change one's eternal destiny after death — the chasm indicates that post-mortem decisions about one's relationship with God are final and irrevocable
Whether heaven and hell are real physical places
Whether reincarnation is possible
intermediate.explanation: The 'great chasm' (Greek: chasma mega) permanently fixed between the two sides teaches that after death, one's spiritual destination is sealed. There is no crossing from torment to comfort or vice versa. This contradicts the notion of post-mortem 'second chances.' The rich man's urgent request to warn his living brothers reinforces this: the time for decision is NOW, during life. Abraham's response — 'They have Moses and the Prophets; let them listen to them' — shows that sufficient information is available in this life.

intermediate.question: Jesus said 'You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its saltiness, how can it be made salty again? It is no longer good for anything, except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot.' In first-century Palestine, what kind of salt could actually 'lose its saltiness'?
options: Pure sea salt from evaporation
Salt from the Dead Sea area, which was mixed with gypsum and other minerals — when the sodium chloride leached out, a tasteless powder of impurities remained that looked like salt but had no flavour
Any salt that got wet
Salt that was stored too long
intermediate.explanation: Pure sodium chloride cannot lose its saltiness — it's a stable compound. But salt from the Dead Sea area (which Jesus' audience used) was impure, mixed with gypsum, marl, and other minerals. When the actual salt (NaCl) dissolved or leached out through exposure to moisture, what remained looked like salt but was tasteless and useless. It was literally 'thrown out' — used to pave paths because that's all it was good for. Jesus warned that his followers can look like 'salt' outwardly but lose their essential character.

intermediate.question: The Parable of the Tenants (Matthew 21:33-46) opens with details that directly echo a well-known Old Testament passage. The vineyard owner 'planted a vineyard, put a wall around it, dug a winepress in it, and built a watchtower.' Which Old Testament passage is Jesus deliberately referencing?
options: Psalm 23 (the Lord is my shepherd)
Isaiah 5:1-7 (the Song of the Vineyard) — where God describes Israel as a vineyard he carefully cultivated but that produced only bad fruit
Genesis 2 (the Garden of Eden)
Jeremiah 31 (the new covenant)
intermediate.explanation: Jesus' opening words are a near-verbatim quote from Isaiah 5:1-2: 'My loved one had a vineyard on a fertile hillside. He dug it up, cleared it of stones, and planted the choicest vines. He built a watchtower in it and cut out a winepress.' Isaiah's vineyard parable ends with God's judgment on Israel for producing bad fruit. Jesus updates Isaiah's parable — the problem is now specifically the tenants (religious leaders) who refuse to give God his due and who kill his servants (prophets) and his son (Jesus).

intermediate.question: Jesus told the Parable of the Unforgiving Servant (Matthew 18) in response to a specific question from Peter about forgiveness. Peter asked 'Lord, how many times shall I forgive my brother or sister who sins against me? Up to seven times?' How did Jesus respond?
options: 'Yes, seven times is enough'
'Not seven times, but seventy-seven times' (or 'seventy times seven') — meaning forgiveness should be unlimited
'Three times is sufficient'
'Forgive them once, then confront them'
intermediate.explanation: Peter probably thought he was being generous by suggesting seven times — rabbinical teaching typically required forgiving three times. But Jesus said 'Not seven times, but seventy-seven times' (some translations: 'seventy times seven' = 490). Either way, the point is the same: stop counting. Forgiveness is not a mathematical exercise with a limit — it reflects God's limitless forgiveness toward us. Jesus then told the parable of the unmerciful servant to illustrate why: because our debt to God dwarfs any debt owed to us.

intermediate.question: In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, the father's actions when the son returns include giving him three specific items — the best robe, a ring, and sandals. Each of these items carried symbolic significance in the ancient world. What did they collectively represent?
options: Material comfort and luxury

Full restoration to sonship — the robe signified honour, the ring signified authority (a signet ring for family business), and the sandals signified that he was a son, not a servant (servants went barefoot)
Religious purity and righteousness
Preparation for a journey
intermediate.explanation: Each gift reversed the son's degradation: the 'best robe' (the father's own robe) publicly restored honour and status; the ring (a signet ring) restored authority to act on behalf of the family in business transactions; the sandals distinguished him as a son (slaves went barefoot). Together, these three items said 'You are not a hired servant — you are my son, fully restored.' The son's rehearsed speech ('make me like a hired servant') was cut off — the father wouldn't even let him finish the demotion request.

advanced.question: Scholars classify Jesus' parables into several categories based on their literary form. Which of the following is NOT one of the standard literary categories used in academic parable study?
options: Similitudes (extended comparisons using typical, recurring events — 'The kingdom of heaven is like...')
Example stories (providing a model of behaviour to imitate or avoid — like the Good Samaritan)
Narrative parables (full stories with plot, characters, and resolution — like the Prodigal Son)
Didactic hymns (songs composed to teach doctrine through melody)
advanced.explanation: The three standard categories in parable scholarship are: (1) Similitudes — short comparisons using typical, repeatable situations (mustard seed, yeast, lost coin); (2) Narrative parables — longer stories with developed plots and characters (Prodigal Son, Talents, Tenants); (3) Example stories — narratives offering a model of behaviour (Good Samaritan, Rich Fool, Pharisee and Tax Collector). Some scholars add a fourth: 'allegories' (Sower, Weeds). 'Didactic hymns' is not a parable category.

advanced.question: Adolf Jülicher's groundbreaking 1888 work on parables established a principle that dominated parable interpretation for nearly a century. What was Jülicher's key argument?
options: Each parable is a complex allegory with a hidden meaning for every detail
Each parable makes only one main point — the details are merely scenic background and should not be allegorised into separate theological meanings
Parables are fictional and have no historical basis
Parables can only be understood by reading them in Hebrew
advanced.explanation: Jülicher reacted against centuries of excessive allegorisation (where every detail in a parable was given a separate hidden meaning — the inn in the Good Samaritan = the church, the two coins = the two sacraments, etc.). He argued each parable has one central point. While his reaction was needed, most modern scholars (like Klyne Snodgrass, Craig Blomberg) now see Jülicher as overcorrecting — some parables (like the Sower and Tenants) do have multiple intentional correspondences without being full-blown allegories.

advanced.question: C.H. Dodd's influential definition of a parable (1935) has been widely quoted in scholarship. He described a parable as 'a metaphor or simile drawn from nature or common life, arresting the hearer by its vividness or strangeness, and leaving the mind in sufficient doubt about its precise application to tease it into active thought.' What key insight about parables does this definition capture?
options: Parables are simple stories that require no thought

Parables are designed to make the listener work — they don't just deliver information but provoke reflection, engagement, and self-examination through a combination of familiarity (common life) and surprise (strangeness)
Parables are only about agriculture
Parables are primarily entertainment
advanced.explanation: Dodd's definition highlights that parables are not passive information delivery but active engagement tools. They use familiar settings (farming, cooking, weddings) but introduce unexpected twists that force listeners to reconsider their assumptions. The Good Samaritan makes a hated foreigner the hero. The Prodigal Son makes a wasteful son the centre of celebration. The Workers in the Vineyard pays everyone equally. These 'strange' elements 'tease the mind into active thought' — demanding that hearers rethink their values.
advanced.reference: C.H. Dodd, 'The Parables of the Kingdom' (1935)

advanced.question: The literary function of parables as 'narrative theology' means they communicate theological truths in a way that systematic propositions cannot. What unique advantage do parables have over propositional theological statements?
options: Parables are shorter and easier to memorise

Parables draw the listener into the story, creating identification with characters and situations — the listener makes the judgment on the characters and then discovers they have judged themselves (as Nathan's parable did to David in 2 Samuel 12)
Parables are more entertaining
Parables avoid controversial topics
advanced.explanation: The classic example is Nathan's parable to David (2 Samuel 12:1-7). Nathan told David about a rich man who stole a poor man's only lamb. David was furious: 'The man who did this must die!' Nathan said 'You are the man!' The parable bypassed David's defences — he judged the character in the story before realising he was judging himself. Jesus' parables function similarly: the Pharisees condemn the tenants (Matthew 21:41) before realising 'He was talking about them' (21:45). Parables are weapons of self-revelation.

advanced.question: Kenneth Bailey's 'Poet and Peasant' (1976) revolutionised parable interpretation by analysing Jesus' parables through the lens of Middle Eastern peasant culture. What key cultural insight did Bailey bring to the Parable of the Prodigal Son?
options: He showed that pig farming was common in Palestine

He demonstrated that the father's running was culturally shocking — a dignified patriarch never ran — and may have been a deliberate act to reach the son before the village could perform a 'kezazah' ceremony (a public rejection ceremony for anyone who lost the family inheritance among Gentiles)
He proved the parable was historically true
He showed that the parable was based on an Egyptian folk tale
advanced.explanation: Bailey spent forty years in the Middle East interviewing peasant communities about their cultural norms. He discovered that: (1) the inheritance request was equivalent to wishing the father dead; (2) an elderly patriarch would never run — it was deeply shameful; (3) the village might perform a 'kezazah' ceremony, breaking a pot and declaring the son cut off from the community. The father ran to reach his son first, absorbing the shame of running to protect his son from public rejection. This transforms the parable from a nice story about forgiveness into a dramatic picture of God's costly, shame-absorbing love.
advanced.reference: Kenneth Bailey, 'Poet and Peasant' (1976), 'The Cross and the Prodigal' (2005)

advanced.question: The 'parabolic discourse' of Matthew 13 contains seven (or eight) parables told in sequence. This cluster is one of five major discourse sections in Matthew's Gospel. What literary principle governs the arrangement of these parables within Matthew 13?
options: They are arranged randomly

They follow a chiastic (ABCBA) pattern with the Parable of the Treasure at the centre, and they move from public teaching (to the crowds beside the sea) to private explanation (to the disciples inside the house)
They are arranged chronologically in the order Jesus told them
They are arranged from shortest to longest
advanced.explanation: Matthew 13 has a careful literary structure. Parables are told publicly by the sea (Sower, Weeds, Mustard Seed, Yeast), then Jesus moves inside a house and speaks privately to the disciples (Treasure, Pearl, Net, Householder). There is a transition at the midpoint where Jesus explains why he speaks in parables (13:10-17) and provides the private interpretation of the Sower and Weeds. The movement from public to private mirrors the parables' own function — concealing truth from the resistant while revealing it to the receptive.

advanced.question: The three 'lost things' parables of Luke 15 (Lost Sheep, Lost Coin, Lost Son) have been analysed as a carefully constructed literary unit with an escalating pattern. What is the escalating element across the three parables?
options: The size of the lost item increases

The value and personal significance of what is lost escalates — from 1 of 100 sheep (1%), to 1 of 10 coins (10%), to 1 of 2 sons (50%) — and the emotional intensity and relational complexity increases with each parable
The search becomes easier in each parable
The celebration gets smaller in each parable
advanced.explanation: The proportion lost escalates: 1/100 (sheep), 1/10 (coin), 1/2 (son). The emotional intensity also escalates: a shepherd's concern for a sheep, a woman's desperate search for a coin, a father's heartbreak over a child. The relational complexity escalates too: animals, objects, family. The third parable adds dimensions absent from the first two: the lost one's rebellion (the son chose to leave), the cost of restoration (the father's dignity), and the unexpected antagonist (the older brother). Together they create a comprehensive picture of God's seeking, costly love.

advanced.question: The Parable of the Unjust Judge (Luke 18:1-8) ends with a surprising and often overlooked question from Jesus: 'When the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on the earth?' What theological significance does this final question carry?
options: It's a rhetorical question expecting the answer 'yes'

It shifts the parable from being merely about persistent prayer to an eschatological warning — persistent, faith-filled prayer is precisely what will be tested and found lacking in the final days, making the parable about end-times faithfulness rather than just a prayer technique
It suggests that faith will completely disappear
It has no connection to the rest of the parable
advanced.explanation: The closing question transforms the parable. It's not just about 'keep praying and you'll get what you want.' The eschatological context (Luke 17:22-37 immediately precedes it) makes it about maintaining faith during the long, difficult wait for Jesus' return. God WILL bring justice — but the real question is whether his people will still be faithfully praying when he comes. The question expects a sobering answer: persistent faith will be rare. The parable is a call to the kind of faith that doesn't quit, even when God seems delayed.

advanced.question: In the history of parable interpretation, the allegorical method dominated from the early church fathers (especially Augustine and Origen) through the medieval period. Augustine's interpretation of the Good Samaritan is a famous example. How did Augustine allegorise this parable?
options: He interpreted it as a simple moral lesson about helping strangers

He made every detail a theological symbol: the man = Adam, Jerusalem = the heavenly city, Jericho = mortality, robbers = the devil, priest and Levite = the Old Testament law, the Samaritan = Christ, the inn = the church, the two coins = the two sacraments (baptism and Eucharist), the innkeeper = the apostle Paul
He rejected the parable as unhistorical
He interpreted it as a prophecy about the destruction of Jerusalem
advanced.explanation: Augustine's elaborate allegory assigned a theological meaning to every detail. While creative and theologically rich, this method can make the text say whatever the interpreter wants. Jülicher's later reaction against this method was understandable — but the pendulum swung too far the other way. Modern scholars recognise that Jesus' parables are neither pure allegories (every detail has a fixed meaning) nor pure similitudes (only one point). They occupy a middle ground where some details carry intentional symbolic weight and others are narrative scenery.

advanced.question: The concept of the 'polyvalence' of parables (the idea that parables can legitimately carry multiple meanings) has been debated by scholars. What is the strongest argument for polyvalence in parables?
options: That parables are so vague that any interpretation is equally valid

Jesus himself provided multiple layers of meaning in some parables — the Sower has both an agricultural surface meaning AND an explicit allegorical interpretation (Matthew 13:18-23), showing that Jesus intended parables to work at multiple levels simultaneously
That different cultures interpret things differently
That the Gospel writers made errors in recording the parables
advanced.explanation: Jesus' own interpretation of the Sower (Mark 4:13-20) demonstrates that he intended some parables to work at multiple levels. The story functions at the agricultural level (a farmer planting seed), at the personal level (how individuals respond to God's word), and at the salvation-historical level (the kingdom's reception in Jesus' ministry). Similarly, the Parable of the Tenants works at both the narrative level and as an allegory of Israel's history. The issue is not whether parables can have multiple meanings but whether those meanings are controlled by authorial intent and literary context.

advanced.question: The 'kingdom of God/heaven' is the primary subject of Jesus' parables. Scholars have identified three temporal aspects of the kingdom that the parables address. Which of the following correctly describes all three?
options: Past kingdom, present kingdom, future kingdom

The kingdom as present reality (mustard seed, yeast — it's already growing), the kingdom as future consummation (wheat and weeds, net — there will be a final separation), and the kingdom as demanding a present response (treasure, pearl — act now!)
Earthly kingdom, heavenly kingdom, eternal kingdom
Political kingdom, spiritual kingdom, social kingdom
advanced.explanation: The parables present the kingdom as: (1) Already present and growing — mustard seed and yeast show the kingdom is here now, growing mysteriously and pervasively; (2) Not yet consummated — the wheat and weeds, the net, and the sheep and goats all point to a future separation/judgment; (3) Demanding an urgent present response — the treasure and pearl show that discovering the kingdom requires immediate, total commitment. This 'already/not yet' framework (inaugurated eschatology) is the key to understanding Jesus' kingdom parables.

advanced.question: The Parable of the Sheep and the Goats (Matthew 25:31-46) is technically classified by many scholars not as a parable but as an 'apocalyptic discourse' or 'prophetic vision.' What is the primary reason for this classification?
options: It doesn't contain agricultural imagery

Unlike parables (which use fictional analogies to illustrate truth), this passage describes a literal future event — the Son of Man's final judgment — with real consequences, making it more a prophetic prediction than a fictional comparison
It's too long to be a parable
It appears in only one Gospel
advanced.explanation: While commonly called a 'parable,' Matthew 25:31-46 lacks the typical parable formula ('the kingdom of heaven is like...'). It directly describes the Son of Man coming in glory, sitting on his throne, and separating all nations. The sheep and goats are metaphorical labels for real categories of people, not fictional characters in a story. Scholars like Klyne Snodgrass classify it as an apocalyptic judgment scene rather than a true parable, though it uses parabolic imagery (sheep/goats) within a prophetic framework.

advanced.question: The 'two-source hypothesis' in Gospel studies (that Matthew and Luke independently used Mark and a hypothetical source called 'Q') has implications for parable study. Several parables appear in both Matthew and Luke but not in Mark, suggesting they come from Q. Which of the following parables is attributed to the Q source?
options: The Parable of the Prodigal Son (only in Luke)
The Parable of the Mustard Seed (in Mark too)
The Parable of the Yeast/Leaven — found in both Matthew 13:33 and Luke 13:20-21 with very similar wording, but absent from Mark
The Parable of the Good Samaritan (only in Luke)
advanced.explanation: The Parable of the Yeast appears in both Matthew (13:33) and Luke (13:20-21) with near-identical wording but is absent from Mark. This pattern (Matthew + Luke - Mark) is the signature of Q material. Other parables attributed to Q include the Parable of the Lost Sheep (Matthew 18/Luke 15), the Talents/Minas (Matthew 25/Luke 19), and the Wedding Feast/Great Banquet (Matthew 22/Luke 14). The Prodigal Son and Good Samaritan are unique to Luke ('L' material), while the Weeds and Workers in the Vineyard are unique to Matthew ('M' material).

advanced.question: The concept of 'reversal' is a key structural element in many of Jesus' parables. Characters who seem admirable turn out to be condemned, and characters who seem contemptible turn out to be vindicated. This pattern serves a specific rhetorical function. What is it?
options: To create entertaining plot twists

To subvert the audience's moral and social assumptions — by luring listeners to identify with the 'respectable' character and then reversing expectations, Jesus forces them to confront their own self-righteousness, prejudice, or false confidence
To confuse the audience so they ask more questions
To show that morality is relative
advanced.explanation: The reversal pattern is a masterful rhetorical strategy. In the Pharisee and Tax Collector, the 'righteous' Pharisee is condemned while the 'sinner' tax collector is justified. In the Good Samaritan, the 'heroes' (priest, Levite) fail while the 'villain' (Samaritan) succeeds. In the Prodigal Son, the 'good' older brother is the one who needs correction. The audience naturally identifies with the respectable character — then the reversal exposes their own attitudes. The parables are mirrors that show listeners their true spiritual condition.

advanced.question: The Parable of the Shrewd Manager (Luke 16:1-13) is widely regarded as the most difficult of all Jesus' parables. One scholarly interpretation suggests that the manager was not actually cheating his master when he reduced the debts. What is this interpretation?
options: The manager was simply correcting accounting errors

The manager was removing his own commission (the amount he had added to the bills as his personal markup) — so the reduced bills represented the actual debt owed to the master, not a theft from the master
The master had overcharged the debtors
The debts were forgiven as part of a Jubilee year
advanced.explanation: This interpretation (advocated by J. Duncan M. Derrett and others) argues that managers in antiquity commonly inflated bills with their own commission or interest charges (which were technically illegal under Jewish law). When the manager reduced the debts, he was removing his own commission — giving up his personal profit to make friends. This explains why the master 'commended' the manager: the master wasn't cheated because the reduced amounts represented the true debt. The manager sacrificed his own income to secure his future — a model of using present resources wisely.

advanced.question: The relationship between Jesus' parables and rabbinic parables (meshalim) has been extensively studied. While there are similarities (both use common life situations, agricultural imagery, and king/father figures), what is the most significant difference between Jesus' parables and rabbinic parables?
options: Rabbinic parables are longer

Jesus' parables introduce genuine surprise, reversal, and moral challenge that subvert audience expectations, whereas rabbinic parables typically illustrate or reinforce existing teaching without challenging the audience's fundamental assumptions
Rabbinic parables use animals while Jesus uses humans
There are no meaningful differences
advanced.explanation: Rabbinic parables (found in Talmud and Midrash) typically illustrate a point already made from Scripture — they reinforce the status quo of religious understanding. Jesus' parables do something more radical: they challenge, subvert, and overturn the audience's assumptions. A rabbi would never make a Samaritan the hero of a story about neighbourly love, never suggest that a tax collector was more righteous than a Pharisee, never imply that latecomers deserve equal reward. Jesus' parables are not just illustrations — they are provocations that demand a transformed worldview.

advanced.question: In Mark 4:33-34, the evangelist notes that Jesus 'did not say anything to [the crowds] without using a parable. But when he was alone with his own disciples, he explained everything.' This distinction between public and private teaching has implications for understanding the purpose of parables. What key insight does this reveal?
options: Jesus was hiding the truth from everyone

Parables functioned as a two-tier communication strategy — they were public 'riddles' that concealed truth from the resistant while simultaneously inviting the receptive to seek private explanation, effectively sorting listeners by spiritual receptivity
Jesus didn't trust the crowds
Parables were only meant for entertainment
advanced.explanation: Mark 4:11-12 makes this explicit: 'The secret of the kingdom of God has been given to you. But to those on the outside everything is said in parables so that they may be ever seeing but never perceiving.' Parables function like a filter: those who are genuinely interested come closer, ask questions, and receive deeper understanding. Those who are hostile or indifferent hear a story and walk away. The same parable simultaneously reveals (to the receptive) and conceals (from the resistant). It's not arbitrary exclusion but a response to prior spiritual posture.

advanced.question: The Parable of the Ten Minas (Luke 19:11-27) includes the detail about citizens who 'hated the nobleman and sent a delegation saying, "We don't want this man to be our king."' This detail, absent from the parallel Parable of the Talents, reflects a historical event. What historical allusion does Luke's audience recognise?
options: The Maccabean revolt against Greek rule

Archelaus son of Herod travelling to Rome in 4 BC to receive his kingdom, while a Jewish delegation of fifty followed to protest before Augustus — and Archelaus' subsequent brutal reprisals against those who opposed him
The Roman conquest of Jerusalem
Solomon's accession to the throne
advanced.explanation: After Herod the Great's death (4 BC), his son Archelaus went to Rome to have Augustus confirm his kingship over Judea. A delegation of fifty Jews followed to oppose his appointment, citing his cruelty. Augustus granted him the territory (as ethnarch, not king) and Archelaus later punished those who had opposed him. Jesus' audience — many of whom would remember this event from 30 years earlier — would hear the parable as a warning: rejecting God's appointed King carries consequences far more serious than rejecting Archelaus.

advanced.question: The concept of 'extravagance' in the parables has been identified by scholars as a deliberate literary strategy. Many parables contain details that are unrealistically extreme. What theological purpose does this extravagance serve?
options: Jesus exaggerated because he was a poor storyteller

The deliberate exaggeration (a debt of 10,000 talents, 100-fold harvest, a log in your eye, a camel through a needle) signals that Jesus is talking about God's kingdom — where grace, generosity, judgment, and demand all operate on a scale that shatters ordinary human categories
The extreme numbers reflect accurate historical economics
Jesus wanted his stories to be memorable for children
advanced.explanation: The extravagance is intentional and theological: 10,000 talents (an impossible debt = our sin before God), a 100-fold harvest (extraordinary by any standard = the kingdom's fruitfulness), selling everything for a pearl (total commitment = the kingdom's demand), a log in your eye (absurdly hyperbolic = the blindness of judgmentalism). These exaggerations signal that the parables are not about ordinary human affairs but about the kingdom of God, where everything operates on a different scale. God's grace is not moderate — it's extravagant.

advanced.question: The Gospel of Thomas (a non-canonical Gnostic text discovered at Nag Hammadi in 1945) contains versions of several of Jesus' parables found in the canonical Gospels. How do scholars typically assess the relationship between Thomas' parables and the Synoptic versions?
options: Thomas is universally regarded as more authentic than the canonical Gospels

Most scholars view Thomas' versions as secondary adaptations of the Synoptic parables, often stripped of their narrative context and given Gnostic interpretations — though a minority argue some Thomas versions may preserve independent early traditions
Thomas contains completely different parables with no overlap
Thomas is considered a direct copy of Matthew
advanced.explanation: Thomas contains versions of the Sower, Mustard Seed, Wheat and Tares, Hidden Treasure, Pearl, Tenants, Rich Fool, and others. Most scholars (including Craig Evans and Simon Gathercole) view them as dependent on the Synoptics, modified to fit Gnostic theology. A minority (Stephen Patterson, Helmut Koester) argue Thomas preserves some independent early traditions. The parables in Thomas generally lack narrative context, moral application, and eschatological urgency — reflecting Gnostic emphasis on inner knowledge rather than narrative salvation history.

advanced.question: The 'parable of the Wicked Tenants' (Mark 12:1-12) has been described by scholars as the most transparently allegorical of Jesus' parables. Jesus' use of this parable in the Temple courts during his final week constitutes what kind of prophetic action?
options: A peaceful meditation on God's patience

A public indictment of the Temple authorities in their own territory — Jesus, standing in the Temple, tells a story that the chief priests recognise is aimed at them, effectively putting them on trial in their own courtroom
A private warning given only to the disciples
An abstract theological reflection with no specific target
advanced.explanation: The setting is crucial: Jesus tells this parable in the Temple courts (Mark 11:27) — the chief priests' own domain. The parable indicts them directly: they are the tenants who abuse their position, mistreat God's messengers (the prophets), and will kill the owner's son (Jesus). Mark notes 'they knew he had spoken the parable against them' (12:12). This is prophetic confrontation at its most dramatic — Jesus, days before his death, publicly indicts the religious establishment in their own headquarters. The parable is both prediction and provocation.

advanced.question: The use of the term 'mashal' in Hebrew encompasses a broader range of literary forms than the English word 'parable.' What literary forms does the Hebrew 'mashal' include beyond simple narrative stories?
options: Only long narrative stories
Proverbs, riddles, allegories, taunt songs, prophetic oracles, similitudes, and wisdom sayings — the term covers almost any form of figurative or comparative speech
Only agricultural metaphors
Only questions and answers
advanced.explanation: The Hebrew 'mashal' (from a root meaning 'to be like, to compare') encompasses a remarkably broad range of literary forms: proverbial sayings (Proverbs 10:1), riddles (Judges 14:14), allegories (Ezekiel 17), taunt songs (Isaiah 14:4), prophetic oracles (Numbers 23:7), wisdom sayings (Ecclesiastes), and narrative parables. Jesus' 'parables' include all these forms — from one-liners ('Physician, heal yourself') to developed narratives (Prodigal Son). Understanding this breadth helps explain why the Gospels classify such diverse material as 'parables.'

advanced.question: The 'eschatological crisis parables' (Ten Virgins, Talents, Sheep and Goats in Matthew 25; Budding Fig Tree in Mark 13; Thief in the Night in Luke 12) share a common urgent message about the kingdom. What distinguishes these parables from Jesus' other kingdom parables?
options: They focus on the present experience of the kingdom
They emphasise the unexpected, sudden nature of the kingdom's consummation and the absolute necessity of being prepared NOW — because when the moment arrives, it will be too late to prepare
They are shorter and simpler than other parables
They contain no moral judgment
advanced.explanation: The eschatological crisis parables share several features: (1) an unexpected arrival (bridegroom, master, Son of Man, thief); (2) a sharp division between prepared and unprepared; (3) the impossibility of last-minute preparation (no borrowing oil, no extending the deadline); (4) irreversible consequences. These parables create urgent tension: the kingdom's consummation is certain but its timing is unknown, making constant readiness essential. They counterbalance the 'growth parables' (mustard seed, yeast) which emphasise the kingdom's gradual present development.

advanced.question: Joachim Jeremias' influential work 'The Parables of Jesus' (1947) argued that to understand the parables correctly, we must recover their original 'Sitz im Leben' (life setting) in Jesus' ministry. Jeremias identified several ways the early church had modified the parables. Which of the following is one of his proposed modifications?
options: The early church shortened every parable

The early church allegorised, universalised, and applied parables to church situations (like the delay of Jesus' return) that were different from the original situations in Jesus' ministry — so recovering the original setting is necessary for accurate interpretation
The early church translated the parables into Greek without changes
The early church added humour to make the parables more entertaining
advanced.explanation: Jeremias identified ten ways the church adapted Jesus' parables: (1) translation from Aramaic to Greek; (2) changing audience (from opponents to disciples); (3) adding explanatory applications; (4) allegorising details; (5) combining originally separate parables; (6) adapting to the delay of the Parousia; (7) moralising; (8) universalising (from specific to general); (9) adding christological elements; (10) contextualising for church situations. While some scholars think Jeremias went too far, his core insight — that context shapes meaning — remains fundamental to parable interpretation.

advanced.question: The Parable of the Labourers in the Vineyard (Matthew 20:1-16) has been interpreted by some liberation theologians and economic ethicists as containing implications for economic justice. What is this reading's key argument?
options: That all workers should be paid minimum wage

That the parable envisions an economic model based on need rather than strict merit — the landowner pays everyone enough to live on (a denarius was a day's subsistence wage) regardless of hours worked, suggesting that in God's kingdom, basic human needs take priority over market calculations of 'earning'
That unions should negotiate equal pay
That the parable condemns all wealthy people
advanced.explanation: This interpretation notes that a denarius was the minimum daily subsistence wage — what a family needed to survive one day. Workers hired at 5 PM still had families to feed. The landowner's question 'Are you envious because I am generous?' challenges the assumption that strict proportional compensation is the highest form of justice. While the parable's primary meaning is about God's grace (the 'last' entering the kingdom receive full salvation, not a partial version), the economic dimension is real: in God's economy, human need may matter more than human calculations of 'deserving.'

advanced.question: The phrase 'the kingdom of heaven is like...' (found frequently in Matthew's Gospel) has been misunderstood as meaning that the kingdom is IDENTICAL to the item mentioned. Scholars have identified a more precise grammatical function. What does the phrase actually introduce?
options: A direct equation between the kingdom and one specific element
The entire parable/situation that follows — 'the kingdom of heaven is like' means 'the kingdom of heaven may be compared to the following situation/scenario,' not to any single element within it
A metaphor for heaven as a physical place
A comparison between the kingdom and earthly politics
advanced.explanation: When Jesus says 'The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed,' he doesn't mean the kingdom IS a mustard seed. The formula introduces a comparison between the kingdom and the WHOLE SCENARIO described. 'The kingdom of heaven is like a landowner who hired workers' means the kingdom operates according to the dynamics illustrated by the entire story. Klyne Snodgrass calls this the 'it is the case with X as with Y' formula — comparing complex situations, not equating individual items.

advanced.question: The 'seed parables' (Sower, Growing Seed, Mustard Seed, Wheat and Weeds) share a common agricultural context but make distinct theological points. What common underlying theology unites all four seed parables?
options: That farming is the most important occupation

That the kingdom of God operates according to God's timetable and power — humans sow, but God gives the growth; the outcome is certain despite obstacles (birds, rocks, thorns, weeds), apparent insignificance (mustard seed), and mysterious process (growing seed)
That Israel should return to an agricultural economy
That only farmers can understand the kingdom
advanced.explanation: All four seed parables teach that the kingdom grows by divine power according to divine timing: the Sower shows varied responses but guaranteed fruitfulness in good soil; the Growing Seed shows the kingdom growing 'all by itself' (automate); the Mustard Seed shows massive growth from tiny beginnings; the Wheat and Weeds shows that obstacles won't prevent the harvest. Together they create a comprehensive theology of kingdom growth: certain in outcome, mysterious in process, divine in power, gradual in timing, and mixed in reception.

advanced.question: The literary technique of 'end stress' (where the most important character or element appears last in the parable) has been identified as a key structural principle in Jesus' storytelling. Which parable best illustrates this technique?
options: The Parable of the Talents (the important servant appears first)

The Good Samaritan — the priest and Levite appear first, building audience expectation, and the Samaritan (the key character whose response carries the parable's message) appears last, delivering maximum rhetorical impact
The Parable of the Sower (all soils appear equally important)
The Parable of the Yeast (it has no characters)
advanced.explanation: In the Good Samaritan, Jesus builds a series — priest, Levite — creating an expectation pattern (the audience would expect 'Israelite layman' as the third figure, completing a standard Jewish triad). Instead, Jesus substitutes a Samaritan — delivering a shock at the climactic final position. This technique appears in other parables too: the Prodigal Son (the older brother appears last and carries the unresolved challenge), the Workers in the Vineyard (the last-hired appear first in payment, receiving end-stress), the Pharisee and Tax Collector (the tax collector's prayer comes last).

advanced.question: The open-ended conclusion of the Parable of the Prodigal Son (Luke 15:11-32) is a deliberate literary choice. The story ends with the father's appeal to the older brother, but we never learn whether the older brother enters the feast or stays outside. What is the purpose of this unresolved ending?
options: Luke accidentally omitted the ending

The open ending IS the point — the parable was addressed to the Pharisees (represented by the older brother), and Jesus leaves the question hanging because the decision is theirs to make: will they enter the celebration of God's grace toward sinners, or will they remain outside in self-righteous resentment?
The original ending was lost
Jesus was interrupted before finishing the story
advanced.explanation: The open ending is one of the most brilliant literary moves in all of Jesus' parables. The Pharisees who hear the parable ARE the older brother — they're the ones standing outside, angry that God is celebrating with sinners. By leaving the ending open, Jesus throws the decision back at them: 'The father is pleading with you to come in. What will you do?' The parable doesn't just tell a story — it creates a moment of decision for its audience. Every hearer must decide: will I be the older brother who stays outside, or will I enter the feast of grace?

advanced.question: Klyne Snodgrass' comprehensive work 'Stories with Intent' (2008) argued that parables should not be interpreted as timeless moral lessons divorced from their historical context. What was Snodgrass' central thesis about how parables should be interpreted?
options: Parables should be interpreted only through modern literary theory

Parables are 'stories with intent' — they are purposeful theological instruments told by Jesus to specific audiences in specific situations, and their meaning is found at the intersection of story, audience, and occasion, not in abstract principles extracted from their narrative context
Parables should be interpreted literally as historical events
Parables can mean whatever the reader wants them to mean
advanced.explanation: Snodgrass argued that three factors must converge for accurate interpretation: (1) the story itself — its literary features, cultural background, and Old Testament echoes; (2) the audience — who was Jesus speaking to and what were their assumptions? (3) the occasion — what situation prompted the parable? The Good Samaritan means something different when told to a self-justifying lawyer than as a general sermon illustration. The Prodigal Son means something different when told to murmuring Pharisees than as a comforting message to sinners. Context determines meaning.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Good Samaritan was told by Jesus in response to a lawyer's question 'Who is my neighbour?' The story teaches that a neighbour is anyone in need, regardless of their ethnicity, religion, or social status.
beginner.explanation: The lawyer wanted to limit the definition of 'neighbour' to justify himself. But by making the hero a Samaritan — someone the Jews despised — Jesus demolished all boundaries. The question was not 'Who qualifies as my neighbour?' but 'Am I being a neighbour?' Jesus concluded by saying 'Go and do likewise' — love is not defined by the recipient's identity but by the giver's action.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, the father refused to take back his wayward son and told him he had to work as a hired servant to earn his place back in the family.
beginner.explanation: The father did the opposite — he ran to meet his son (undignified for a Middle Eastern patriarch), embraced him, kissed him, and interrupted his rehearsed 'make me a servant' speech. He ordered the best robe, a ring (signet ring = authority), sandals (slaves went barefoot; sons wore sandals), and a celebration with a fattened calf. The son was fully restored as a son, not demoted to a servant. The father's response pictures God's extravagant, unconditional grace.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Sower, the seed that fell on good soil and produced a crop represents people who hear God's word, accept it, and produce fruit — some thirty, some sixty, and some a hundred times what was sown.
beginner.explanation: Jesus explained that the good soil represents 'those with a noble and good heart, who hear the word, retain it, and by persevering produce a crop' (Luke 8:15). The varying yields (30, 60, 100-fold) show that even among those who genuinely receive the word, there are different levels of fruitfulness. But all good soil produces something — the mark of genuine reception is fruit, not just hearing.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Mustard Seed teaches that the kingdom of God starts very small (like the smallest seed used in Palestinian agriculture) but grows into something surprisingly large.
beginner.explanation: Jesus compared the kingdom to a mustard seed, which was proverbially the smallest seed used in Jewish agriculture. Despite its tiny beginning, it grew into a large shrub or small tree where birds could perch in its branches. The kingdom of God started with Jesus and a handful of followers but would grow to encompass millions across the entire world. The parable encourages faith when the kingdom seems insignificantly small.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Talents, the servant who buried his one talent in the ground was praised by his master for keeping the money safe.
beginner.explanation: The master was furious with the servant who buried his talent. He called him 'wicked and lazy,' took his talent away, and gave it to the servant with ten talents. The master said that at minimum the servant should have deposited the money with bankers to earn interest. The parable teaches that God gives everyone gifts and abilities and expects them to be used productively, not hidden out of fear. Fearful inaction is not caution — it's disobedience.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Lost Sheep teaches that there is more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous people who do not need to repent.
beginner.explanation: Jesus said 'I tell you that in the same way there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent' (Luke 15:7). The shepherd left the ninety-nine to search for the one lost sheep, illustrating God's passionate pursuit of every individual who is lost. The parable was directed at Pharisees who criticised Jesus for welcoming sinners.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Wise and Foolish Builders, the wise man built his house on sand and the foolish man built his house on rock.
beginner.explanation: It's the reverse: the WISE man built on rock, and the FOOLISH man built on sand. When the rain came, the floods rose, and the wind blew, the house on the rock stood firm while the house on the sand collapsed 'with a great crash.' Jesus said the wise builder represents anyone who hears his words AND puts them into practice, while the foolish builder hears but does not obey.

beginner.question: Jesus' Parable of the Rich Fool ends with God telling the rich man 'You fool! This very night your life will be demanded from you.' The rich man died that night without ever getting to enjoy his new barns full of grain.
beginner.explanation: The rich man had just decided to tear down his barns, build bigger ones, store all his grain, and then 'take life easy — eat, drink and be merry.' But God said 'This very night your life will be demanded from you. Then who will get what you have prepared for yourself?' Jesus concluded: 'This is how it will be with whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich toward God.' The parable warns against finding security in material wealth while neglecting eternal matters.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Tax Collector and the Pharisee, Jesus said the Pharisee went home justified before God because of his impressive list of spiritual accomplishments.
beginner.explanation: It was the tax collector — not the Pharisee — who went home justified. The Pharisee's prayer was a self-congratulatory list of achievements ('I fast, I tithe, I'm better than others'). The tax collector simply beat his chest and prayed 'God, have mercy on me, a sinner.' Jesus said the tax collector, not the Pharisee, went home right with God, 'for all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.'

beginner.question: The three parables of Luke 15 — the Lost Sheep, the Lost Coin, and the Lost Son (Prodigal Son) — were all told by Jesus in response to the Pharisees criticising him for welcoming sinners and eating with them.
beginner.explanation: Luke 15:1-2 provides the context for all three parables: 'Now the tax collectors and sinners were all gathering around to hear Jesus. But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, "This man welcomes sinners and eats with them."' Jesus then told all three parables in sequence, each making the same point: God actively seeks the lost and throws a celebration when they are found. The Pharisees' resentment mirrors the older brother's anger in the third parable.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Hidden Treasure, the man who found treasure in a field sold everything he had to buy the field — and he did this joyfully, not reluctantly.
beginner.explanation: Matthew 13:44 says 'in his joy' the man went and sold all he had. The key word is 'joy' — the man wasn't making a painful sacrifice but a thrilling investment. He gave up everything, but what he gained was worth infinitely more. The kingdom of God is so valuable that giving up everything for it isn't a loss but the greatest bargain imaginable. True kingdom commitment is driven by joy, not grim obligation.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Weeds (Tares) teaches that we should immediately separate the good people from the bad people in the world rather than waiting for God to sort them out.
beginner.explanation: The master explicitly said 'Let both grow together until the harvest' — do NOT try to pull up the weeds now, because you'll damage the wheat in the process. The separation happens at the harvest (the end of the age) when the angels (not humans) will sort the wheat from the weeds. The parable warns against premature judgment — it's not our job to decide who's 'in' and who's 'out.' That's God's responsibility at the final judgment.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Ten Virgins teaches that the five wise virgins were willing to share their oil with the five foolish virgins so everyone could enter the wedding.
beginner.explanation: The wise virgins did NOT share their oil. They said 'No, there may not be enough for both us and you. Instead, go to those who sell oil and buy some for yourselves.' While the foolish virgins were away buying oil, the bridegroom arrived and the door was shut. When they returned and knocked, the bridegroom said 'Truly I tell you, I don't know you.' The parable teaches that spiritual preparedness is personal — it cannot be borrowed from someone else at the last minute.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Good Samaritan, the Samaritan not only bandaged the injured man's wounds but also took him to an inn, paid for his care, and promised to pay any additional expenses on his return trip.
beginner.explanation: The Samaritan went far beyond basic first aid. He 'bandaged his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he put the man on his own donkey, brought him to an inn and took care of him. The next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper. "Look after him," he said, "and when I return, I will reimburse you for any extra expense you may have."' Two denarii would cover about two weeks of care. The Samaritan's generosity was lavish, open-ended, and personally costly.

beginner.question: Jesus told a parable saying 'No one lights a lamp and hides it in a clay jar or puts it under a bed. Instead, they put it on a stand, so that those who come in can see the light.' This teaches that faith should be visible, not hidden.
beginner.explanation: Jesus said 'No one lights a lamp and hides it in a clay jar or puts it under a bed. Instead, they put it on a stand, so that those who come in can see the light' (Luke 8:16). The parable teaches that the truth of the kingdom — the light Jesus brings — is meant to be displayed openly, not hidden. Disciples are meant to be visible witnesses, not secret believers. 'You are the light of the world. A town built on a hill cannot be hidden' (Matthew 5:14).

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Two Sons (Matthew 21:28-32), Jesus said that tax collectors and prostitutes were entering the kingdom of God ahead of the chief priests and elders because they responded to John the Baptist's message with repentance while the religious leaders did not.
beginner.explanation: Jesus told the chief priests and elders: 'Truly I tell you, the tax collectors and the prostitutes are entering the kingdom of God ahead of you. For John came to you to show you the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him, but the tax collectors and the prostitutes did. And even after you saw this, you did not repent and believe him.' The parable of the two sons illustrated this: the first son (like the tax collectors) initially said no but later obeyed; the second (like the leaders) said yes but never acted.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Yeast (Leaven) teaches that just a small amount of yeast can permeate and transform an entire large batch of dough — illustrating how the kingdom of God starts small but has an unstoppable, transforming influence.
beginner.explanation: A woman mixed a small amount of yeast into three measures of flour — a large quantity, about 40-60 pounds. The yeast permeated the entire batch, transforming it all. You can't see yeast working from the outside, but its effect is total and irreversible. Like the mustard seed parable, this teaches that the kingdom of God starts small and hidden but has an unstoppable, permeating influence that transforms everything it touches.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Sheep and the Goats, the 'goats' (unrighteous) are condemned not for committing terrible crimes but for failing to help those in need — the hungry, thirsty, strangers, naked, sick, and imprisoned.
beginner.explanation: The goats are not accused of murder, theft, or blasphemy. Their sin is omission, not commission — they failed to act. 'Whatever you did not do for one of the least of these, you did not do for me.' They simply walked past the hungry, ignored the stranger, overlooked the sick, and never visited the prisoner. The parable teaches that sins of neglect — failing to love when you could have — are as serious as sins of action.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Rich Man and Lazarus is the only parable in which Jesus gives a character a personal name — the beggar is called Lazarus.
beginner.explanation: In all of Jesus' other parables, characters are identified by type: 'a man,' 'a king,' 'a father,' 'a widow,' 'a Pharisee.' Only in this parable does Jesus name a character. The name 'Lazarus' (from Hebrew Eleazar, meaning 'God helps') is significant — the man whom no human helped bore the name 'God helps' because God was his ultimate helper. Interestingly, the rich man remains unnamed — in God's kingdom, the anonymous beggar has an identity while the famous rich man has none.

beginner.question: Jesus concluded the Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard by saying 'So the last will be first, and the first will be last' — meaning that God's grace often reverses human expectations about who deserves reward.
beginner.explanation: The workers hired at dawn (who worked all day) expected more pay than those hired at 5 PM (who worked only one hour), but everyone received the same wage. The landowner said 'Are you envious because I am generous?' God's kingdom operates on grace, not strict merit. Those who come to faith late receive the same salvation as those who have followed God their whole lives. The principle 'the last shall be first' overturns human calculations about earning and deserving.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Persistent Widow, Jesus compared God to the unjust judge — teaching that God is reluctant to answer prayers and must be worn down by persistence.
beginner.explanation: Jesus did NOT compare God to the unjust judge — the parable works by CONTRAST, not comparison. The point is: if even an unjust, godless judge who doesn't care about anyone will eventually respond to persistence, how much MORE will God — who is perfectly just, loves His children, and genuinely wants to help — respond to their prayers? God is eager to answer, not reluctant. The parable teaches us to keep praying because God IS listening and WILL act.

beginner.question: Jesus said 'You are the salt of the earth' and warned that if salt loses its saltiness, it is 'no longer good for anything, except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot by men.'
beginner.explanation: Jesus warned his followers that they are meant to be 'salt' — a preserving, flavouring, purifying influence in the world. But if they lose their distinctive character (their 'saltiness'), they become useless. In first-century Palestine, impure salt from the Dead Sea region could indeed lose its sodium chloride content, leaving a tasteless residue that was thrown on paths. The warning is clear: disciples who lose their spiritual distinctiveness have no purpose.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Great Banquet teaches that when the originally invited guests refused to come, the host filled his table with people from the streets — the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame — representing God's welcome of outsiders and outcasts into His kingdom.
beginner.explanation: The originally invited guests (representing the religious establishment) all made excuses — one bought a field, another bought oxen, another just got married. The enraged host sent his servants to bring in the marginalised from the streets and alleys, and then from the roads and country lanes. Jesus was teaching that God's invitation to the kingdom, rejected by the religious insiders, extends to the very people the insiders looked down on — and eventually to the Gentile nations.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Unmerciful Servant, after the king cancelled the servant's enormous debt, the servant immediately forgave a fellow servant's small debt in gratitude.
beginner.explanation: The servant did the OPPOSITE. Despite being forgiven an astronomically large debt (ten thousand talents — millions of dollars), he went out and found a fellow servant who owed him a tiny amount (a hundred denarii — a few months' wages), grabbed him by the throat, and had him thrown into prison until he could pay. When the king heard, he was furious and handed the ungrateful servant over to the jailers 'to be tortured, until he should pay back all he owed.'

beginner.question: Jesus' teaching about the plank in your own eye and the speck in your brother's eye warns against judging others for small faults while ignoring your own much larger faults.
beginner.explanation: Jesus used deliberately humorous, exaggerated imagery: 'Why do you look at the speck of sawdust in your brother's eye and pay no attention to the plank in your own eye?' The absurd image of someone with a huge plank sticking out of their eye trying to perform delicate eye surgery on someone else makes the point unforgettable. We tend to magnify others' faults while minimising our own. Jesus doesn't prohibit discernment — he says 'first take the plank out of your own eye, THEN you will see clearly.'

beginner.question: The parable of the vine and the branches (John 15) teaches that Jesus is the vine and his followers are the branches — branches that remain connected to the vine bear fruit, but branches that are cut off wither and die.
beginner.explanation: Jesus said 'I am the vine; you are the branches. If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit; apart from me you can do nothing.' Branches that don't bear fruit are cut off and thrown into the fire. Branches that do bear fruit are pruned to be even more fruitful. The key word is 'remain' (Greek: meno) — spiritual fruitfulness comes from staying connected to Jesus, not from human effort apart from him.

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Tenants (Wicked Vinedressers), the vineyard owner sent multiple servants to collect the harvest, but the tenants beat one, killed another, and stoned a third. Finally, the owner sent his own son, thinking they would respect him, but they killed the son too.
beginner.explanation: The servants represent the prophets God sent to Israel throughout history, who were repeatedly persecuted, rejected, and killed. The son represents Jesus himself, whom the religious leaders would soon crucify. The vineyard (Israel) would be taken from the wicked tenants and given to others. Jesus quoted Psalm 118:22 — 'The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.' The chief priests 'knew he had spoken the parable against them.'

beginner.question: In the Parable of the Unforgiving Servant, Peter asked Jesus how many times he should forgive someone who sins against him — 'up to seven times?' Jesus replied 'not seven times, but seventy-seven times' (or seventy times seven), meaning forgiveness should be unlimited.
beginner.explanation: Peter probably thought he was being exceptionally generous — rabbinical teaching typically required forgiving someone three times. Peter more than doubled it to seven. But Jesus said 'not seven times, but seventy-seven times' (some translations: 'seventy times seven' = 490). Either way, the point is identical: stop counting. Forgiveness is not a mathematical exercise with a limit. Jesus then told the parable of the unmerciful servant to show why: our debt to God is so immense that we have no right to withhold forgiveness from others.

beginner.question: Jesus said 'You cannot serve both God and money (Mammon)' — teaching that wealth and faith are mutually exclusive and that owning any possessions is sinful.
beginner.explanation: Jesus said you cannot SERVE both God and money — meaning money cannot be your master alongside God. He did not say owning possessions is sinful. Many of Jesus' followers were wealthy (Joseph of Arimathea, Zacchaeus after conversion, the women who supported Jesus' ministry from their own means — Luke 8:3). The issue is not having money but being mastered by it. You can USE money while serving God, but you cannot SERVE money while serving God. Money is a useful servant but a terrible master.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Barren Fig Tree shows a gardener pleading with the vineyard owner to give the fruitless tree one more year of special care before cutting it down — illustrating God's patience and willingness to give people more time to repent.
beginner.explanation: The vineyard owner wanted to cut down the unfruitful fig tree immediately — it had wasted three years of soil. But the gardener interceded: 'Leave it alone for one more year, and I'll dig around it and fertilise it. If it bears fruit next year, fine! If not, then cut it down.' This pictures God's patient mercy — giving extra time and special care to those who aren't bearing spiritual fruit. But the patience has a limit: 'if not, then cut it down.' Grace extends time but doesn't eliminate accountability.

beginner.question: The Parable of the Pearl of Great Value teaches that a merchant sold everything he had to buy one exceptionally valuable pearl — representing the total commitment required to enter the kingdom of God.
