But God had not abandoned her — He had already placed Ruth at her side, and through Ruth's marriage to Boaz, Naomi would become the grandmother of Obed, great-grandmother of King David, and ancestor of Jesus.

beginner.question: Moses' mother, Jochebed, did something daring and creative to save her baby from Pharaoh's decree that all Hebrew baby boys be thrown into the Nile. What did she do?
options: She hid him in a cave for three months
She hid him for three months, then placed him in a waterproof basket among the reeds of the Nile, where Pharaoh's daughter found him
She disguised him as a girl
She sent him to live with relatives in another country
beginner.explanation: Jochebed hid baby Moses for three months, but when she could no longer conceal him, she made a papyrus basket, coated it with tar and pitch to make it waterproof, placed the baby inside, and set it among the reeds along the bank of the Nile. Pharaoh's daughter came to bathe and found the basket. She felt sorry for the crying baby and adopted him as her own son. Through Miriam's quick thinking, Jochebed was hired to nurse her own son.

beginner.question: Abigail was described as an intelligent and beautiful woman married to a foolish, harsh man named Nabal. When Nabal insulted David and David marched out with 400 soldiers to kill him, Abigail quickly gathered supplies and rode out to meet David. What did she do?
options: She challenged David to a duel
She fell at David's feet, apologised for her husband, and persuaded David not to shed innocent blood in anger — her wisdom prevented a massacre
She offered David money to go away
She told David where Nabal was hiding
beginner.explanation: Abigail loaded donkeys with bread, wine, sheep, grain, raisin cakes, and fig cakes, and rode out to intercept David. She fell at his feet and took the blame upon herself: 'Please pay no attention to that wicked man Nabal.' She persuaded David that God would establish his kingdom and that he shouldn't have blood on his hands from vengeance. David was so impressed he said 'Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who has sent you today to meet me.' After Nabal died, David married Abigail.

beginner.question: When Jesus and his disciples attended a wedding in the village of Cana, the wine ran out — a serious social embarrassment for the hosts. Jesus' mother Mary noticed the problem and told Jesus about it. What did Mary then say to the servants?
options: 'Fill the jars with water'
'Wait for Jesus to decide what to do'
'Do whatever he tells you'
'Go buy more wine from the market'
beginner.explanation: Mary's instruction to the servants — 'Do whatever he tells you' — showed her quiet confidence that Jesus would act. Jesus then told the servants to fill six stone water jars with water, and the water was turned into the finest wine the master of the banquet had ever tasted. This was Jesus' first recorded miracle. Mary's simple words 'Do whatever he tells you' have been embraced by Christians for centuries as a model of faithful trust in Jesus.

beginner.question: Priscilla (also called Prisca) was a prominent woman in the early church who, together with her husband Aquila, did something bold when they heard the eloquent preacher Apollos speaking in the synagogue. Apollos knew the Scriptures well but his understanding was incomplete. What did Priscilla and Aquila do?
options: They reported him to the apostles
They publicly corrected him in the synagogue
They invited him to their home and explained to him the way of God more adequately — privately and respectfully filling in the gaps in his knowledge
They told him to stop preaching
beginner.explanation: Priscilla and Aquila 'invited him to their home and explained to him the way of God more adequately.' Their approach was gracious — private rather than public, instructive rather than confrontational. Notably, Priscilla is mentioned first in this account (Acts 18:26), suggesting she may have been the primary teacher. After this instruction, Apollos became one of the most effective preachers in the early church, 'vigorously refuting his Jewish opponents in public debate.'

beginner.question: Hagar was an Egyptian slave woman who belonged to Sarah, Abraham's wife. When Sarah couldn't have children, she gave Hagar to Abraham to bear a child. But when Hagar became pregnant, conflict erupted. When Hagar fled into the wilderness, God found her and made her a remarkable promise. What did God promise?
options: That she could return to Egypt
That her descendants would be 'too numerous to count' — and He told her to name her son Ishmael, meaning 'God hears'
That she would become a queen
That she would never have to serve Sarah again
beginner.explanation: The angel of the LORD found Hagar near a spring in the desert and said 'I will increase your descendants so much that they will be too numerous to count.' He told her to name her son Ishmael ('God hears') because 'the LORD has heard of your misery.' Hagar responded by giving God a name — 'You are the God who sees me' (El Roi). She is the only person in the Bible who gave God a name. Hagar's story shows God's care for the marginalised and oppressed.

beginner.question: After Jesus rose from the dead, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene and then to other women, telling them to go and tell the disciples. In the culture of that time, women's testimony was not considered reliable in court. Why is it significant that women were the first witnesses of the resurrection?
options: It was simply a coincidence

It strongly supports the historical truth of the resurrection — if the story had been invented, the authors would never have chosen women as the primary witnesses since their testimony was considered unreliable in that culture
Women were the only ones allowed near the tomb
The disciples had asked the women to go first
beginner.explanation: In first-century Jewish and Roman culture, women's testimony was generally not accepted in legal proceedings. If the early Christians had invented the resurrection story, they would have made Peter or John the first witnesses — not women whose testimony could be dismissed. The fact that all four Gospels name women as the first witnesses is one of the strongest arguments for the historicity of the empty tomb: no one would fabricate a story with witnesses who would undermine its credibility.

beginner.question: Lydia was a successful businesswoman in the city of Philippi who sold expensive purple cloth. She heard the apostle Paul preaching by the river and responded to his message. What is Lydia known as in church history?
options: The first female apostle
The first convert to Christianity in Europe — she and her entire household were baptised
The first woman to write a book of the Bible
The first female priest
beginner.explanation: Lydia is considered the first European convert to Christianity. Acts 16:14 says 'The Lord opened her heart to respond to Paul's message.' She and her entire household were baptised, and she insisted that Paul and his companions stay at her home: 'If you consider me a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my house.' Her home became the meeting place for the first church in Philippi — the church Paul later wrote the letter to the Philippians to.

beginner.question: Delilah was a woman in the book of Judges who was bribed by the Philistine rulers to discover the source of Samson's supernatural strength. After persistent questioning, Samson finally told her his secret. What was the source of his strength?
options: His enormous size and muscles
His hair had never been cut — it was the sign of his Nazirite vow to God, and if his head were shaved, his strength would leave him
He ate a special diet of honey and meat
He wore a magical bracelet
beginner.explanation: Samson's long hair was the outward sign of his Nazirite vow — a special dedication to God from birth (Judges 13:5). His strength came from the Spirit of God, not from the hair itself, but the hair represented his covenant with God. After Delilah's persistent nagging ('she prodded him day after day until he was sick to death of it'), Samson told her the truth. She had his head shaved while he slept, and 'the LORD had left him.' The Philistines captured and blinded him.

beginner.question: When King Herod threw a birthday banquet and his stepdaughter danced for the guests, Herod was so pleased that he promised her anything she wanted — up to half his kingdom. Her mother Herodias told her what to ask for. What did she request?
options: Half the kingdom
Freedom for her family
The head of John the Baptist on a platter
Gold and jewels
beginner.explanation: Herodias hated John the Baptist because he had publicly declared that Herod's marriage to her was unlawful (Herod had married his brother's wife). Herodias saw her chance for revenge and told her daughter to ask for John's head. The girl went to Herod and said 'I want you to give me right now the head of John the Baptist on a platter.' Herod was greatly distressed but because of his oath and dinner guests, he sent an executioner to behead John in prison.

beginner.question: In the early church, a woman named Tabitha (also called Dorcas) was known for her kindness and charity — she was 'always doing good and helping the poor.' When she became ill and died, the widows she had helped wept and showed Peter the clothing she had made for them. What did Peter do?
options: He comforted the widows and prayed for them
He sent everyone out of the room, knelt and prayed, then said 'Tabitha, get up!' — and she opened her eyes, sat up, and was alive
He held a memorial service for her
He donated money to continue her charity work
beginner.explanation: Peter sent everyone out, knelt and prayed, then turned to the dead woman and said 'Tabitha, get up.' She opened her eyes, saw Peter, and sat up. He helped her to her feet and presented her alive to the believers and widows. This miracle became known all over Joppa and many people believed in the Lord. Tabitha/Dorcas is remembered as an example of a woman whose faith was expressed through practical acts of service and generosity.

beginner.question: Mary, the mother of Jesus, sang a powerful song of praise after Elizabeth confirmed that Mary's baby was from God. This song, known as the Magnificat, celebrates God's care for the humble and hungry. What is the opening line of Mary's song?
options: 'Praise the LORD, all you nations'
'The LORD is my shepherd, I shall not want'
'My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour'
'How great is our God'
beginner.explanation: Mary's Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55) begins 'My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour, for he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant.' The song echoes Hannah's prayer (1 Samuel 2) and celebrates God's pattern of reversing worldly power structures: 'He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty.' It is one of the most revolutionary texts in Scripture.

beginner.question: Ruth demonstrated extraordinary loyalty to her mother-in-law Naomi by leaving her homeland of Moab to live in Bethlehem. To provide food for them both, Ruth went to the fields to pick up leftover grain behind the harvesters — a practice allowed by Jewish law for the poor. Whose field did she 'happen' to end up in?
options: King Saul's field
Boaz's field — a wealthy relative of Naomi's late husband, who would become Ruth's husband
Eli the priest's field
Jesse's field
beginner.explanation: Ruth 2:3 says she 'found herself working in a field belonging to Boaz, who was from the clan of Elimelek' (Naomi's late husband). The text's phrase 'as it turned out' suggests divine providence disguised as coincidence. Boaz noticed Ruth's hard work and devotion to Naomi, treated her with extraordinary kindness, and eventually married her as a 'kinsman-redeemer.' Their son Obed was the grandfather of King David.

beginner.question: When the teachers of the law and Pharisees brought a woman caught in adultery to Jesus, they wanted to trap him by asking whether she should be stoned according to Moses' law. Jesus bent down and wrote on the ground, then stood up and gave a famous response. What did Jesus say?
options: 'Stone her as Moses commanded'
'Let her go free, she has done nothing wrong'
'Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her'
'Take her to the priests for judgment'
beginner.explanation: Jesus' response was brilliant — he didn't deny the law or condone the sin, but turned the judgment back on the accusers. 'Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone.' One by one, beginning with the oldest, they dropped their stones and walked away. When only Jesus and the woman remained, he asked 'Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?' She said 'No one, sir.' Jesus replied 'Then neither do I condemn you. Go now and leave your life of sin.'

intermediate.question: The prophet Huldah was a woman who played a crucial role during the reign of King Josiah. When the Book of the Law was discovered in the Temple after being lost for years, King Josiah sent his officials to consult a prophet about its message. Remarkably, they went to Huldah rather than to Jeremiah or Zephaniah (who were also active prophets at the time). What did Huldah prophesy?
options: That the Book of the Law was a forgery
She confirmed the book was authentic and prophesied that God's judgment would come upon Judah for breaking the covenant — but that Josiah would be spared because of his humble, repentant heart
That Josiah should destroy the book
That a new Temple should be built
intermediate.explanation: Huldah authenticated the discovered book (likely Deuteronomy), prophesied coming judgment on Judah for covenant unfaithfulness, but delivered a personal word of grace to Josiah: because he had humbled himself and wept before God, he would be gathered to his ancestors in peace and not see the coming disaster. Her prophecy triggered Josiah's sweeping religious reforms. The fact that the king's officials chose a female prophet over Jeremiah and Zephaniah shows her recognised authority.

intermediate.question: In the book of Judges, Deborah composed a victory song (Judges 5) after Israel's triumph over Sisera. This song is considered one of the oldest pieces of Hebrew poetry in the Bible. In the song, Deborah describes herself using a specific maternal title. What did she call herself?
options: 'A warrior of Israel'
'A mother in Israel'
'A queen of the people'
'A prophet of the LORD'
intermediate.explanation: Deborah called herself 'a mother in Israel' (Judges 5:7), a title that speaks to her protective, nurturing leadership over the nation. The title suggests not just biological motherhood but national maternal care — she was a guardian and provider for the whole people. The Song of Deborah (Judges 5) is regarded by scholars as one of the oldest compositions in the Bible, possibly dating to the events themselves (c. 1200 BC), making it an extraordinarily early witness to a woman's leadership.

intermediate.question: When Ruth went to the threshing floor at night and lay at Boaz's feet as Naomi had instructed, she asked Boaz to 'spread the corner of your garment over me, since you are a guardian-redeemer of our family.' What did this symbolic request mean in that cultural context?
options: She was asking for a blanket because she was cold

It was a marriage proposal — spreading one's garment over a woman was a symbolic act of claiming her as one's bride and offering protection, echoing Ezekiel 16:8 where God says He spread His garment over Israel
She was asking for clothing as a gift
It was a request for financial help
intermediate.explanation: Ruth's request 'Spread the corner of your garment over me' was a culturally understood marriage proposal. The Hebrew word for 'corner' (kanaph) is the same word used in Ezekiel 16:8 where God says 'I spread the corner of my garment over you... I gave you my solemn oath and entered into a covenant with you.' Ruth was asking Boaz to exercise his right as a kinsman-redeemer and marry her. Boaz was deeply honoured: 'This kindness is greater than that which you showed earlier.'

intermediate.question: In the New Testament, Paul commended a woman named Phoebe as a 'deacon' (or 'servant') of the church in Cenchreae and asked the Roman church to receive her properly. Paul also described Phoebe with the Greek word 'prostatis.' What does this term mean?
options: 'Prayer warrior'
'Patron' or 'benefactor' — indicating she was a woman of means who used her resources to support Paul and many others in their ministry
'Preacher'
'Prophet'
intermediate.explanation: Paul wrote 'I commend to you our sister Phoebe, a deacon of the church in Cenchreae... she has been the benefactor (prostatis) of many people, including me' (Romans 16:1-2). Prostatis denotes a patron or protector — someone who used their social and financial resources to support others. Phoebe was also likely the one who carried Paul's letter to the Romans, making her the first person to read aloud what became arguably the most important theological document in Christian history.

intermediate.question: Tamar was the daughter-in-law of Judah (one of Jacob's twelve sons). After being twice widowed and denied her rightful marriage to Judah's third son, Tamar took a drastic and controversial action to ensure the family line continued. What did she do?
options: She ran away to another country
She disguised herself as a prostitute, sat by the road, and conceived twins by Judah himself — when Judah discovered the truth, he declared 'She is more righteous than I'
She married a man from another tribe
She appealed to the tribal elders for justice
intermediate.explanation: Tamar's actions were shocking but the text presents them as a desperate response to injustice. Judah had failed his legal obligation to provide his third son, Shelah, as a husband for Tamar. When Judah discovered Tamar was pregnant and wanted to have her burned, she produced his personal items (his seal, cord, and staff) as proof he was the father. Judah acknowledged: 'She is more righteous than I, since I wouldn't give her to my son Shelah.' Tamar is listed in Jesus' genealogy in Matthew 1.

intermediate.question: Bathsheba's story began tragically when King David saw her bathing, committed adultery with her, and then arranged the death of her husband Uriah. Despite this dark beginning, Bathsheba later played a crucial political role in Israel's history. What did she do?
options: She led a rebellion against David
She successfully advocated for her son Solomon to become king instead of David's older son Adonijah, securing the Davidic succession that led to Jesus
She became a prophetess
She left David and returned to her family
intermediate.explanation: When David was old and Adonijah tried to seize the throne, the prophet Nathan and Bathsheba worked together to remind David of his promise that Solomon would succeed him. Bathsheba went to David's bedside and secured his oath to make Solomon king (1 Kings 1:11-31). Her political astuteness preserved the succession that God had ordained. Bathsheba is listed in Jesus' genealogy (Matthew 1:6) — though notably referred to as 'Uriah's wife,' preserving the memory of the injustice done to Uriah.

intermediate.question: The 'Proverbs 31 woman' is a famous biblical portrait of an ideal wife and mother. However, the Hebrew text reveals something about this passage that is often missed in English translations. What is the literary structure of Proverbs 31:10-31?
options: It's a simple list of qualities
It's an acrostic poem — each verse begins with successive letters of the Hebrew alphabet, making it a carefully crafted literary masterpiece from A to Z (Aleph to Tav)
It's a song meant to be sung at weddings
It's a legal document listing a wife's duties
intermediate.explanation: Proverbs 31:10-31 is an alphabetic acrostic poem: the first word of each verse begins with the next letter of the 22-letter Hebrew alphabet. This literary structure is deliberate — it suggests completeness, perfection, and comprehensive praise from A to Z. The poem celebrates a woman of strength (the Hebrew word is 'chayil,' meaning 'valor, strength, ability'), not domesticity. She is an entrepreneur, real estate investor, manufacturer, and philanthropist, as well as a mother and wife.

intermediate.question: In Romans 16:7, Paul mentions 'Andronicus and Junia, my fellow Jews who have been in prison with me. They are outstanding among the apostles, and they were in Christ before I was.' The identity and role of Junia has been debated. What is the scholarly consensus about Junia?
options: Junia was a man whose name was later changed by scribes
Junia was a woman — the name is a well-attested Latin feminine name, and she was recognised as 'outstanding among the apostles,' making her a female apostle in the early church
Junia was Paul's sister
Junia was a title, not a personal name
intermediate.explanation: Early church fathers unanimously identified Junia as a woman. John Chrysostom (4th century) wrote: 'How great the wisdom of this woman must have been that she was even deemed worthy of the title of apostle!' The name 'Junias' (a hypothetical male form) does not appear in any ancient Greek or Latin text. The masculine reading was introduced in the 13th century. Modern scholarship has overwhelmingly restored the feminine identification. Junia was a Jewish Christian woman who was 'outstanding among the apostles.'

intermediate.question: Queen Jezebel, the wife of King Ahab of Israel, is one of the most notorious women in the Bible. She promoted the worship of the Canaanite god Baal and persecuted the prophets of the LORD. How did she die, as prophesied by Elijah?
options: She was struck by lightning
She was thrown from a window by her own servants, trampled by horses, and eaten by dogs — fulfilling Elijah's prophecy that dogs would devour her
She died of a plague
She was captured and executed by a foreign army
intermediate.explanation: When Jehu came to Jezreel, Jezebel painted her eyes and arranged her hair (defiant to the end), then looked out from an upper window. Jehu called out 'Who is on my side?' Two or three eunuchs threw her down. Her blood splattered the wall and the horses trampled her. When they went to bury her, they found nothing except her skull, feet, and palms — dogs had eaten the rest, exactly as Elijah had prophesied: 'Dogs will devour Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel.'

intermediate.question: When Mary visited Elizabeth and greeted her, something extraordinary happened. Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit and exclaimed words that have been repeated in Christian prayer for two thousand years. What did Elizabeth say?
options: 'My soul magnifies the Lord'
'Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the child you will bear! But why am I so favoured, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?'
'Glory to God in the highest'
'Hosanna in the highest'
intermediate.explanation: Elizabeth's greeting — 'Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the child you will bear!' — has been incorporated into the 'Hail Mary' prayer in Catholic tradition. Remarkably, Elizabeth called Mary 'the mother of my Lord,' recognising the unborn Jesus' divine identity while he was still in Mary's womb. Elizabeth also noted that 'the baby in my womb leaped for joy' at Mary's greeting — the unborn John the Baptist responding to the presence of the unborn Jesus.

intermediate.question: Michal, King Saul's daughter and David's first wife, loved David deeply and even helped him escape from her father when Saul tried to kill him. But years later, when David danced before the Ark of the Covenant as it entered Jerusalem, Michal despised him. What happened as a result?
options: David divorced her
Michal had no children to the day of her death — interpreted as either divine judgment or personal estrangement from David
Michal left David and returned to Saul's family
David apologised and Michal forgave him
intermediate.explanation: 2 Samuel 6:23 records: 'And Michal daughter of Saul had no children to the day of her death.' When Michal criticised David for dancing 'half-naked' before the Ark, David replied that he was celebrating before the LORD who chose him over her father Saul. The childlessness may have been divine judgment, David's withdrawal from the relationship, or simply a natural consequence of their broken relationship. For a royal wife, childlessness meant the end of her family line.

intermediate.question: The 'woman who anointed Jesus' appears in all four Gospels, though with different details. In John's account, it was Mary of Bethany (sister of Martha and Lazarus) who anointed Jesus with expensive perfume. Judas objected to the 'waste.' Jesus defended her with words that connected the anointing to something specific. What did Jesus say the anointing was for?
options: 'She has done it to honour me as king'
'She has done this to prepare my body for burial' — connecting her act to his imminent death
'She has done this to cleanse me from sin'
'She has wasted nothing; this perfume was for everyday use'
intermediate.explanation: Jesus said 'It was intended that she should save this perfume for the day of my burial' (John 12:7) or 'She did it to prepare me for burial' (Matthew 26:12). Mary may have understood, better than the disciples, that Jesus was about to die. The perfume (nard) was worth a year's wages — an extravagant act of love. Jesus said 'Wherever this gospel is preached throughout the world, what she has done will also be told, in memory of her.'

intermediate.question: In the book of Exodus, two Hebrew midwives named Shiphrah and Puah were ordered by Pharaoh to kill all Hebrew baby boys at birth. These women defied the most powerful ruler on earth. What excuse did they give Pharaoh for not obeying his order?
options: 'We did not hear your command'
'The Hebrew women are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive' — and God blessed the midwives for their courage
'We tried but failed'
'The babies were all girls'
intermediate.explanation: Shiphrah and Puah told Pharaoh 'Hebrew women are not like Egyptian women; they are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive.' Whether this was entirely true or a clever excuse, the text says they 'feared God and did not do what the king of Egypt had told them to do.' Their civil disobedience saved countless lives. 'God was kind to the midwives and the people increased and became even more numerous. And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families of their own.'

intermediate.question: When the wise woman of Abel Beth Maakah's city was besieged by Joab's army because a rebel named Sheba was hiding there, she called out from the wall and negotiated with Joab. Her solution saved the entire city. What did she do?
options: She opened the city gates and surrendered
She persuaded the people of the city to cut off Sheba's head and throw it over the wall to Joab, ending the siege and saving the city from destruction
She bribed Joab with gold
She challenged Joab to single combat
intermediate.explanation: The wise woman called out to Joab: 'We are the peaceful and faithful in Israel. You are trying to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you want to swallow up the LORD's inheritance?' When Joab explained he only wanted Sheba, the woman told the people, and they cut off Sheba's head and threw it to Joab. The army withdrew, and the city was saved. She is described as 'a wise woman' — her diplomatic skill and decisive action preserved her entire community.

intermediate.question: Martha of Bethany is often remembered for being 'distracted by all the preparations' while Mary sat at Jesus' feet. But in John 11, after her brother Lazarus died, Martha made one of the most significant theological confessions in the entire Bible — a statement that matches Peter's famous confession. What did Martha say to Jesus?
options: 'If you had been here, my brother would not have died'
'I believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God, who is to come into the world'
'Lord, show me a sign so I can believe'
'Raise my brother from the dead'
intermediate.explanation: Martha's confession — 'I believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God, who is to come into the world' (John 11:27) — is the Johannine equivalent of Peter's confession at Caesarea Philippi. It is a full, three-fold christological statement: Messiah (God's anointed king), Son of God (divine identity), the Coming One (prophesied deliverer). Martha made this declaration in the midst of grief, before seeing Lazarus raised — making it a statement of pure faith, not a response to a miracle.

intermediate.question: The book of Esther is unique in the Bible for a specific literary feature that has puzzled scholars and readers for centuries. What is missing from the entire book of Esther?
options: Any mention of prayer
Any direct mention of God — God's name never appears in the entire book, yet His providential hand is visible throughout the story
Any mention of Jerusalem
Any mention of the Law of Moses
intermediate.explanation: The book of Esther never mentions God, prayer, the Temple, the Law, or any explicitly religious activity. Yet the entire narrative is driven by divine providence — 'coincidences' that are too perfect to be accidental: Esther becoming queen, Mordecai overhearing a plot, the king's insomnia on the crucial night, Haman building gallows he would hang on himself. The book teaches that God's guidance is sometimes hidden but always active, even when His name is unspoken.

intermediate.question: Rahab, the prostitute from Jericho who hid the Israelite spies, is mentioned in the New Testament in three separate books. What remarkable claim does the book of Hebrews make about Rahab?
options: That she was the greatest woman in the Old Testament
She is listed in the 'Hall of Faith' (Hebrews 11) alongside Abraham, Moses, and David — 'By faith the prostitute Rahab, because she welcomed the spies, was not killed with those who were disobedient'
That she became a priestess in Israel
That she performed miracles
intermediate.explanation: Rahab appears in Hebrews 11:31 (Hall of Faith), James 2:25 (as an example of faith expressed through works), and Matthew 1:5 (in Jesus' genealogy). She is the only woman specifically named in the Hebrews 11 faith chapter. Her inclusion is remarkable: a Canaanite, a prostitute, and a liar — yet commended for faith. She believed in God's power based on what she had heard (Hebrews 11 faith), and she acted on that faith by welcoming the spies (James 2 works).

intermediate.question: When Potiphar's wife repeatedly tried to seduce Joseph (the son of Jacob who had been sold into slavery in Egypt), Joseph refused her advances. When she grabbed his cloak and he fled, she used the cloak as false evidence. What did she accuse Joseph of?
options: Stealing from Potiphar
Attempting to assault her — she used his abandoned cloak as 'proof,' and Potiphar had Joseph thrown into prison
Planning to run away
Insulting the Egyptian gods
intermediate.explanation: Potiphar's wife falsely accused Joseph of attempting to assault her, using his abandoned garment as evidence. Joseph was thrown into prison despite his innocence. But 'the LORD was with Joseph' even in prison, and this unjust imprisonment eventually led to Joseph interpreting dreams for Pharaoh's officials, which led to his interpreting Pharaoh's dream, which led to his becoming second-in-command of all Egypt. The injustice of one woman's lie became the pathway to Joseph's divine destiny.

intermediate.question: The witch (or medium) of Endor was visited by King Saul the night before his final battle. Saul, desperate because God was no longer answering him, asked her to summon someone from the dead. Who did Saul want to speak to, and what happened?
options: He asked to speak to Moses, who encouraged him
He asked to summon the dead prophet Samuel — when Samuel appeared, both the medium and Saul were terrified, and Samuel told Saul he would die in battle the next day
He asked to speak to his father, who gave him battle strategy
He asked to summon an angel for guidance
intermediate.explanation: When Samuel appeared, the medium screamed — suggesting something genuinely supernatural happened that even she didn't expect. Samuel's message was devastating: 'The LORD has departed from you and become your enemy... Tomorrow you and your sons will be with me.' The passage raises profound theological questions about the afterlife, necromancy, and divine sovereignty. Saul died in battle the next day, exactly as Samuel had said.

intermediate.question: Zipporah, the wife of Moses, performed an emergency circumcision on their son during a dangerous encounter on the journey to Egypt. The text says 'the LORD met Moses and was about to kill him.' Zipporah's quick action saved Moses' life. What did she do with the foreskin?
options: She buried it in the ground
She touched it to Moses' feet (a Hebrew euphemism), saying 'Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me'
She threw it into the fire
She kept it as a memorial
intermediate.explanation: This is one of the most mysterious passages in the Bible. Zipporah took a flint knife, circumcised her son, and touched the foreskin to Moses' feet, saying 'Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me.' The passage is deeply enigmatic, but Zipporah's decisive action apparently saved Moses' life. She understood the importance of circumcision (the sign of God's covenant with Abraham) even though she was a Midianite, not an Israelite.

intermediate.question: Lois and Eunice are mentioned together in 2 Timothy as the grandmother and mother of Timothy (Paul's protégé). Paul commended them for a specific spiritual quality that had been passed down through three generations. What was it?
options: Their wealth and generosity
Their 'sincere faith' — a genuine, unhypocritical faith that first lived in grandmother Lois, then in mother Eunice, and now in Timothy
Their knowledge of Greek philosophy
Their ability to perform miracles
intermediate.explanation: Paul wrote 'I am reminded of your sincere faith, which first lived in your grandmother Lois and in your mother Eunice and, I am persuaded, now lives in you also' (2 Timothy 1:5). The word 'sincere' (Greek: anupokritos) means 'without hypocrisy' — genuine, real faith. Paul also noted that 'from infancy you have known the Holy Scriptures' (3:15), crediting Lois and Eunice with Timothy's early spiritual education. They demonstrate the power of multigenerational faith formation.

intermediate.question: Lot's wife is one of the most briefly mentioned women in the Bible, yet Jesus specifically referenced her as a warning. When the family was fleeing the destruction of Sodom, the angels told them not to look back. Lot's wife looked back and was turned into a pillar of salt. What did Jesus say about her?
options: 'Blessed are those who do not look back'
'Remember Lot's wife!' — a warning against attachment to the old life when God calls for decisive forward movement
'Lot's wife was punished unfairly'
'Do not judge Lot's wife'
intermediate.explanation: Jesus' warning 'Remember Lot's wife!' (Luke 17:32) comes in the context of his teaching about the coming of the Son of Man. He warned that people should not turn back to save possessions or cling to their former way of life. Lot's wife physically left Sodom but her heart remained there — she 'looked back,' suggesting longing for what she was leaving behind. Her fate symbolises the danger of half-hearted commitment: going through the motions of following God while your heart remains attached to the old life.

intermediate.question: The Shunammite woman in 2 Kings 4 built a room on her roof for the prophet Elisha to use whenever he visited. When her son died suddenly, she rode urgently to find Elisha. When Elisha's servant Gehazi asked 'Is everything all right?', she gave a remarkable response despite her devastating grief. What did she say?
options: 'My son is dead, please help!'
'Everything is all right' — she refused to share the news with anyone except Elisha himself, showing extraordinary composure and faith
'Send Elisha immediately'
'Nothing is all right, my world has ended'
intermediate.explanation: The Shunammite woman said 'Everything is all right' (Hebrew: shalom) despite her son being dead at home. She pressed past Gehazi to reach Elisha directly. When she reached him, she fell at his feet and expressed her pain: 'Did I ask you for a son, my lord? Didn't I tell you, "Don't raise my hopes"?' Her faith was directed specifically at Elisha — she refused to accept anyone less. Elisha went and raised her son from the dead.

intermediate.question: The book of Song of Solomon (Song of Songs) features a woman as its primary speaker — she speaks more than the man and initiates much of the relationship. The woman describes herself in a way that addresses racial or ethnic difference. What does she say?
options: 'I am the fairest of all women'
'Dark am I, yet lovely, daughters of Jerusalem. Dark like the tents of Kedar, like the tent curtains of Solomon. Do not stare at me because I am dark'
'I am a lily among thorns'
'I am a garden locked up'
intermediate.explanation: The woman says 'Dark am I, yet lovely' (Song 1:5-6), noting that her dark skin came from working in the sun ('My mother's sons were angry with me and made me take care of the vineyards'). She addresses potential prejudice directly: 'Do not stare at me because I am dark.' The Song of Solomon presents her dark beauty as positive and desirable. The woman is confident, articulate, and sexually expressive — initiating desire and pursuing her beloved with equal agency.

intermediate.question: In the story of the Exodus, Pharaoh's daughter played a crucial role by rescuing baby Moses from the Nile. She adopted him as her own son and gave him his name. What does the name 'Moses' mean, and why did she choose it?
options: 'Son of God' — because she thought he was divine
'Drawn out' — because she said 'I drew him out of the water'
'Gift of the Nile' — because the Nile was sacred in Egypt
'Little one' — because he was a small baby
intermediate.explanation: Pharaoh's daughter named him Moses (Hebrew: Mosheh), saying 'I drew him out (mashah) of the water.' The name captures both the physical rescue from the Nile and prophetically foreshadows Moses' future role of 'drawing out' Israel from Egypt through the waters of the Red Sea. Pharaoh's daughter's compassion — defying her own father's death decree to save a Hebrew baby — made her an unwitting instrument of God's plan to deliver an entire nation.

intermediate.question: Athaliah was the only woman to rule as queen regnant (sole ruler) of Judah. When her son King Ahaziah was killed, she seized power by doing something horrific. What did she do, and who stopped her?
options: She declared war on Israel

She massacred the entire royal family to eliminate all rivals — but the baby Joash was secretly hidden in the Temple by his aunt Jehosheba for six years until the priest Jehoiada led a coup to restore him to the throne
She imprisoned all the nobles
She burned the Temple
intermediate.explanation: Athaliah 'proceeded to destroy the whole royal family' to secure her grip on power. But Jehosheba (Ahaziah's sister) stole the baby Joash from among the royal princes about to be murdered and hid him with his nurse in the Temple for six years. In the seventh year, Jehoiada the priest revealed Joash to the people, crowned him king, and had Athaliah executed. Jehosheba's courageous act preserved the Davidic line from which the Messiah would come.

intermediate.question: Jesus healed a woman who had been 'bent over and could not straighten up at all' for eighteen years. He healed her on the Sabbath in a synagogue, which outraged the synagogue leader. Jesus called the woman something specific that honoured her identity. What did he call her?
options: 'Poor woman'
'A daughter of Abraham' — a title that affirmed her full membership in God's covenant people and her right to be healed
'My child'
'A woman of great faith'
intermediate.explanation: Jesus called her 'a daughter of Abraham' — a remarkable title that parallels 'son of Abraham' (used for Zacchaeus). The term affirmed her full covenant identity and dignity. Jesus then shamed the synagogue leader: 'Doesn't each of you on the Sabbath untie your ox or donkey and lead it to water? Then should not this woman, a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has kept bound for eighteen long years, be set free on the Sabbath day?' He elevated her status while exposing the hypocrisy of caring more about animals than a suffering woman.

intermediate.question: Paul's letter to the Romans ends with an extensive list of greetings (Romans 16) that mentions several women by name with specific commendations. How many women does Paul greet or commend in Romans 16?
options: Two or three
About ten women — including Phoebe (deacon), Priscilla (co-worker), Mary, Junia (apostle), Tryphena, Tryphosa, Persis, Julia, and Rufus' mother
Only one — Phoebe
None — Paul only greeted men
intermediate.explanation: Romans 16 mentions approximately ten women: Phoebe (deacon/patron), Prisca/Priscilla (co-worker), Mary (hard worker), Junia (outstanding among the apostles), Tryphena and Tryphosa (workers in the Lord), Persis (dear friend who worked very hard), Julia, Rufus' mother (who has been 'a mother to me too'), and Nereus' sister. Several receive higher commendation than the men listed. This passage reveals that women played crucial leadership roles in the Pauline churches.

intermediate.question: Leah, who was unloved by her husband Jacob compared to her sister Rachel, named her sons with names that expressed her emotional pain and her hope that Jacob would love her. Her fourth son received a name that finally showed a shift in Leah's focus — from seeking Jacob's love to praising God. What was this son's name?
options: Reuben ('See, a son')
Simeon ('One who hears')
Levi ('Attached')
Judah ('Praise') — she said 'This time I will praise the LORD'
intermediate.explanation: Leah's first three sons' names reflected her longing for Jacob's love: Reuben ('See, a son — surely my husband will love me now'), Simeon ('God heard that I am unloved'), Levi ('Now my husband will become attached to me'). But with Judah, something shifted: she said simply 'This time I will praise the LORD.' She stopped seeking validation from Jacob and turned to God. Ironically, Judah — the son born from praise rather than desperation — became the ancestor of King David and Jesus.

intermediate.question: The 'woman clothed with the sun, with the moon under her feet and a crown of twelve stars on her head' appears in Revelation 12. This mysterious figure gives birth to 'a male child, who will rule all the nations with an iron sceptre.' Who does this woman most likely represent?
options: Eve specifically
Mary the mother of Jesus only
Israel (the people of God) who gave birth to the Messiah — the twelve stars representing the twelve tribes, with the imagery drawn from Joseph's dream in Genesis 37:9
The church in the first century
intermediate.explanation: The imagery directly echoes Joseph's dream (Genesis 37:9) where the sun, moon, and eleven stars (representing his family/Israel) bow before him. The twelve stars represent the twelve tribes. The woman (Israel/the people of God) gives birth to the Messiah, who is 'caught up to God and to his throne.' The dragon (Satan) pursues the woman. While some see a dual reference to both Israel and Mary, the primary identification is with the covenant community that produced the Messiah.

intermediate.question: Rizpah was a concubine of King Saul whose two sons were executed as part of a blood-debt to the Gibeonites. After their deaths, Rizpah performed an extraordinary act of maternal devotion that lasted for months and eventually moved King David to action. What did she do?
options: She pleaded with David to avenge her sons
She guarded her sons' exposed bodies day and night for months — keeping birds away by day and wild animals by night — until David was shamed into giving the bodies a proper burial
She cursed David publicly
She fasted for forty days
intermediate.explanation: Rizpah spread sackcloth on a rock and guarded the exposed bodies 'from the beginning of harvest until the rain poured down from the heavens' — approximately five to six months. She kept the birds of the air from the bodies by day and the wild animals by night. When David heard about Rizpah's vigil, he was moved to gather not only the bones of the executed men but also the bones of Saul and Jonathan and give them all a proper burial. Rizpah's devotion achieved through love what could not be achieved through power.

intermediate.question: In Acts 16, a slave girl in Philippi had a spirit of divination that earned her owners a great deal of money through fortune-telling. She followed Paul and Silas, shouting 'These men are servants of the Most High God, who are telling you the way to be saved.' Paul eventually turned and commanded the spirit to leave her. What happened as a result of the exorcism?
options: The girl's owners thanked Paul
Her owners were furious because their source of income was gone — they dragged Paul and Silas before the magistrates, who had them stripped, beaten, and thrown into prison
The girl became a believer and joined Paul's team
Nothing happened to Paul
intermediate.explanation: When the spirit left the girl, her owners realised their hope of making money was gone. They seized Paul and Silas, dragged them to the marketplace, and brought charges before the magistrates. Paul and Silas were stripped, severely beaten with rods, and thrown into the inner prison with their feet in stocks. This incident led to the midnight earthquake and the conversion of the Philippian jailer. The slave girl's liberation from spiritual bondage led to Paul's imprisonment — liberation often comes at a cost.

intermediate.question: Miriam, Moses' sister, was a prophetess who led the women of Israel in celebration after the Red Sea crossing. But later, Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses for a specific reason. God punished Miriam with leprosy for seven days. What was Miriam's complaint against Moses?
options: That Moses was a poor leader
She criticised Moses for marrying a Cushite (Ethiopian/African) woman — and she and Aaron questioned whether God spoke only through Moses: 'Hasn't he also spoken through us?'
That Moses was too strict
That Moses favoured Joshua over Aaron
intermediate.explanation: Miriam and Aaron 'began to talk against Moses because of his Cushite wife.' The Cushite wife may have been Zipporah (a Midianite) or a second wife from Cush (modern-day Ethiopia/Sudan). They also challenged Moses' unique prophetic authority: 'Has the LORD spoken only through Moses? Hasn't he also spoken through us?' God appeared in a pillar of cloud and affirmed Moses' unique status. When the cloud lifted, Miriam had leprosy. Moses interceded for her and she was healed after seven days outside the camp.

intermediate.question: The Syrophoenician (Canaanite) woman approached Jesus begging him to cast a demon out of her daughter. Jesus initially seemed to rebuff her, saying 'It is not right to take the children's bread and toss it to the dogs.' Her response demonstrated remarkable wit and faith. What did she say?
options: 'But I am also one of God's children'
'Yes, Lord, but even the dogs under the table eat the children's crumbs' — and Jesus, impressed by her faith, healed her daughter immediately
'Please, have mercy on a poor mother'
'I will not leave until you help me'
intermediate.explanation: The woman's response was brilliant — she didn't argue with Jesus' framework but worked within it. If the children (Israel) have a full meal, surely even the dogs (Gentiles) can have the crumbs that fall from the table. Even the 'crumbs' of Jesus' power would be more than enough for her daughter. Jesus was amazed: 'Woman, you have great faith! Your request is granted.' Her daughter was healed at that very hour. This Gentile woman demonstrated greater faith than many in Israel.

intermediate.question: Sapphira, together with her husband Ananias, sold a piece of property and gave part of the proceeds to the apostles but claimed they were giving the full amount. When Peter confronted them separately about lying to the Holy Spirit, what happened to both of them?
options: They were expelled from the church
They both fell down dead — Ananias first, then Sapphira three hours later when she repeated the lie — and 'great fear seized the whole church'
They repented and were forgiven
They were imprisoned by the apostles
intermediate.explanation: When Peter confronted Ananias — 'You have not lied just to human beings but to God' — Ananias fell down dead. Three hours later, Sapphira arrived not knowing what had happened. Peter gave her a chance to tell the truth: 'Tell me, is this the price you and Ananias got for the land?' She maintained the lie. Peter said 'The feet of the men who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out also.' She fell down dead at Peter's feet. The sin was not keeping money but lying about it.

advanced.question: Matthew's genealogy of Jesus (Matthew 1:1-17) is remarkable for including four women — Tamar, Rahab, Ruth, and Bathsheba (referred to as 'Uriah's wife'). What common characteristic unites these four women and explains their deliberate inclusion?
options: They were all wealthy and powerful

All four were foreigners and/or involved in sexually irregular circumstances — their inclusion demonstrates that God's plan of salvation works through unexpected, unconventional, and even scandalous situations, preparing the reader for the most irregular birth of all: the virgin conception
They were all prophetesses
They all lived in Jerusalem
advanced.explanation: Tamar was a Canaanite who conceived through deception with Judah. Rahab was a Canaanite prostitute. Ruth was a Moabite (forbidden ancestry per Deuteronomy 23:3). Bathsheba (identified as 'Uriah's wife' — a Hittite) entered David's line through adultery. All four were Gentiles or involved in irregular unions. Matthew includes them to show that God's messianic plan has always involved the unexpected — outsiders, scandal, and grace. This prepares the reader for the most 'irregular' birth: Jesus born of a virgin.

advanced.question: The debate over the identity of 'Junia' in Romans 16:7 — whether the name is feminine (Junia) or masculine (Junias) — has significant implications for the role of women in the early church. What is the current scholarly consensus?
options: The name is masculine and refers to a man

The name is feminine (Junia) — there is no evidence for a masculine name 'Junias' in any ancient Greek or Latin text, and all patristic commentators before the 13th century identified Junia as a woman who was 'outstanding among the apostles'
The name could be either gender and the question is unresolvable
The name is a title, not a personal name
advanced.explanation: The feminine identification is overwhelming: (1) 'Junia' is a well-attested Latin feminine name appearing over 250 times in ancient inscriptions; (2) 'Junias' (masculine) appears nowhere in ancient literature; (3) every church father who discussed the passage (Origen, Chrysostom, Jerome, etc.) identified Junia as a woman; (4) the masculine reading only appeared in the 13th century. Chrysostom wrote: 'How great the wisdom of this woman that she was even deemed worthy of the title of apostle.' The NA28 Greek text now reads the feminine 'Junia.'

advanced.question: The Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55) — Mary's song of praise — has been analysed by liberation theologians as one of the most politically revolutionary texts in the Bible. What specific social reversals does Mary celebrate in this song?
options: She celebrates military victory over Rome

She celebrates God scattering the proud, bringing down rulers from thrones while lifting up the humble, filling the hungry with good things while sending the rich away empty — a comprehensive reversal of social, political, and economic power structures
She celebrates personal blessings only
She celebrates the beauty of nature
advanced.explanation: Mary's Magnificat celebrates five specific reversals: (1) God has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts; (2) He has brought down rulers from their thrones; (3) He has lifted up the humble; (4) He has filled the hungry with good things; (5) He has sent the rich away empty. These reversals are not future hopes but are stated in the past tense (prophetic aorist) — as though already accomplished through the incarnation. Liberation theologians highlight that the mother of God sang a song about the overthrow of unjust power structures.

advanced.question: The 'woman at the well' narrative in John 4 breaks multiple social conventions of Jesus' time. Scholars have identified at least three barriers that Jesus crossed in this encounter. Which of the following is NOT one of those barriers?
options: Gender barrier — a Jewish man speaking alone with a woman in public
Ethnic/religious barrier — a Jew interacting with a Samaritan
Economic barrier — Jesus refused to speak to her because she was poor
Moral barrier — engaging respectfully with a woman of questionable reputation
advanced.explanation: Jesus crossed gender barriers (the disciples 'were surprised to find him talking with a woman' — John 4:27), ethnic/religious barriers ('Jews do not associate with Samaritans' — 4:9), and moral/social barriers (engaging respectfully with a woman who had five husbands). Poverty was not a barrier in this text. Jesus' willingness to cross all these boundaries was intentional — he chose a Samaritan, a woman, and one with a complicated past to receive some of his deepest theological teaching about worship 'in spirit and truth.'

advanced.question: The Hebrew word used for Eve's role in Genesis 2:18 is 'ezer kenegdo,' often translated 'helper suitable for him.' The word 'ezer' has been debated extensively. How is 'ezer' used elsewhere in the Old Testament, and what does this reveal about its meaning?
options: It always refers to subordinate assistants

Of its 21 other Old Testament uses, 16 refer to God Himself as Israel's 'ezer' (helper/rescuer) — indicating strength and rescue, not subordination. 'Ezer' denotes a powerful ally, not a domestic servant
It refers exclusively to women
It means 'lesser companion'
advanced.explanation: The word 'ezer' appears 21 times in the Old Testament outside Genesis 2. In 16 of those instances, it refers to God as Israel's helper/deliverer (e.g., Psalm 121:1-2 'My help [ezer] comes from the LORD'). In the remaining cases, it refers to military allies. The word denotes strength, rescue, and powerful assistance — never subordination. 'Kenegdo' means 'corresponding to' or 'equal and opposite.' Together, 'ezer kenegdo' means 'a powerful ally corresponding to him' — an equal partner, not a subordinate assistant.

advanced.question: The role of women as the first witnesses of the resurrection is considered by many historians to be one of the strongest arguments for the historicity of the empty tomb. What is the scholarly name for the principle that supports this argument?
options: The criterion of multiple attestation

The criterion of embarrassment — the early Christians would not have invented women as primary witnesses because female testimony was not accepted in Jewish or Roman courts, meaning this 'embarrassing' detail was preserved because it was true
The criterion of dissimilarity
The criterion of coherence
advanced.explanation: The criterion of embarrassment states that material the early church would not have invented (because it was inconvenient or embarrassing) is more likely to be historically authentic. In first-century Jewish law, women's testimony was generally inadmissible. Josephus wrote that women should not be witnesses 'on account of the levity and boldness of their sex.' If Christians invented the resurrection story, they would have made Peter or John the first witnesses. Women were named first because that's actually what happened — the historical truth overrode cultural conventions.

advanced.question: The concept of the 'kinsman-redeemer' (Hebrew: go'el) is central to the book of Ruth. The go'el had specific legal obligations in ancient Israel. Which of the following was NOT a function of the kinsman-redeemer?
options: Buying back family property that had been sold due to poverty
Marrying a deceased relative's widow to continue the family line (levirate marriage)
Serving as the family's priest and offering sacrifices
Avenging the blood of a murdered relative
advanced.explanation: The go'el (kinsman-redeemer) had three main functions: (1) redeeming (buying back) family land sold due to poverty (Leviticus 25:25); (2) marrying a deceased relative's childless widow to continue the family name (related to levirate marriage — Deuteronomy 25:5-10); (3) avenging the blood of a murdered relative (Numbers 35:19). Acting as a priest was NOT a go'el function — that belonged to the Levitical priesthood. Boaz fulfilled the go'el role by redeeming Naomi's land and marrying Ruth.

advanced.question: The 'Proverbs 31 woman' is introduced with the Hebrew phrase 'eshet chayil,' traditionally translated 'virtuous woman' or 'wife of noble character.' However, the Hebrew word 'chayil' has a primary meaning that is often lost in translation. What does 'chayil' most commonly mean in the Old Testament?
options: 'Beautiful' or 'graceful'
'Valor,' 'strength,' 'military might,' or 'capability' — the same word used for warriors and armies. 'Eshet chayil' is better translated 'woman of valor' or 'woman of strength'
'Quiet' or 'submissive'
'Wise' or 'educated'
advanced.explanation: 'Chayil' appears over 240 times in the Old Testament and primarily refers to military strength, valor, and capability. It describes armies (Exodus 14:4), warriors (Judges 6:12 — Gideon is called 'mighty warrior/gibbor chayil'), and capable people (Exodus 18:21). When applied to a woman, it means 'woman of strength/valor/capability.' Boaz uses this exact phrase for Ruth (Ruth 3:11). The Proverbs 31 woman is not a domesticated ideal but a formidable, capable, entrepreneurial woman of power and influence.

advanced.question: The role of Deborah as judge and military leader of Israel (Judges 4-5) has been used in theological debates about women in leadership. Some argue she was an exception due to the failure of male leadership. What evidence from the text itself challenges this 'exception' interpretation?
options: The text doesn't describe her leadership at all

The text presents Deborah's authority as normative and God-given — she is called 'prophetess,' she 'was leading Israel at that time,' people came to her for judgment, and God directly commissioned her to deploy the army. No hint of apology or exceptionalism appears in the narrative
The text explicitly says God only chose her because no men were available
The text says she only led temporarily
advanced.explanation: Judges 4-5 presents Deborah's leadership without any qualification or apology. She holds multiple roles simultaneously: prophetess, judge, military strategist, and poet. The text says she 'was leading (shophetah) Israel at that time' — the same verb used for all other judges. People came to her for decisions. She speaks with divine authority ('The LORD, the God of Israel, commands you'). The Song of Deborah (Judges 5) celebrates her leadership unreservedly. The 'exception' argument is imported into the text, not derived from it.

advanced.question: The encounter between Jesus and the woman caught in adultery (John 7:53-8:11) is one of the most famous biblical narratives, yet it has a unique textual history. What do scholars know about this passage's place in the Gospel of John?
options: It was always part of John's Gospel from the beginning

The passage is absent from the earliest and most reliable Greek manuscripts of John, appears in different locations in different manuscripts (some place it after Luke 21:38), and was likely not part of the original Gospel — but most scholars believe it preserves an authentic tradition about Jesus
The passage was invented in the Middle Ages
All scholars agree it is exactly where John placed it
advanced.explanation: The 'Pericope Adulterae' (John 7:53-8:11) is absent from the earliest Greek manuscripts (P66, P75, Sinaiticus, Vaticanus), is marked with asterisks or obeli in manuscripts that include it, and appears in different locations (after John 7:52, after John 21:25, after Luke 21:38). Most scholars conclude it was not part of the original Fourth Gospel. However, most also believe it preserves a genuine early tradition about Jesus — its style fits Luke better than John, and Augustine suggested it was removed by some because they feared it might encourage sexual permissiveness.

advanced.question: The concept of 'levirate marriage' (from Latin 'levir,' brother-in-law) is important for understanding several biblical women's stories (Tamar, Ruth, the Sadducees' question to Jesus). What was the primary purpose of levirate marriage in ancient Israel?
options: To provide financial support for widows
To raise up offspring 'in the name of the dead brother' so that his name and inheritance would not be lost in Israel — preserving the deceased man's family line and property rights
To punish the surviving brother
To increase the population of Israel
advanced.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:5-10 mandates that if a man dies without children, his brother should marry the widow and 'the first son she bears shall carry on the name of the dead brother so that his name will not be blotted out from Israel.' This was about preserving the dead man's name, lineage, and land inheritance. Tamar's story (Genesis 38) shows a woman fighting for this right. Ruth's story shows a kinsman-redeemer (similar principle) fulfilling this obligation. The Sadducees used this law to construct their hypothetical question to Jesus about the resurrection.

advanced.question: Mary Magdalene has been mistakenly identified with the 'sinful woman' who anointed Jesus' feet (Luke 7:36-50) for centuries. This conflation was popularised by a specific historical figure in AD 591. Who merged these two separate women into one, and what was the impact?
options: The apostle Paul in his letters

Pope Gregory I (Gregory the Great), who declared in a homily that Mary Magdalene, the sinful woman of Luke 7, and Mary of Bethany were the same person — a conflation that persisted in Western Christianity for over 1,400 years until the Catholic Church officially separated them in 1969
Emperor Constantine at the Council of Nicaea
Martin Luther during the Reformation
advanced.explanation: In AD 591, Pope Gregory I preached a homily identifying Mary Magdalene as the sinful woman of Luke 7 and Mary of Bethany — combining three separate women into one. This had the effect of sexualising Mary Magdalene's identity, reducing her from 'apostle to the apostles' (first resurrection witness) to 'repentant prostitute.' The Eastern Orthodox Church never accepted this conflation. In 1969, the Roman Catholic Church officially separated the three figures. In 2016, Pope Francis elevated Mary Magdalene's feast day to the rank of the apostles.

advanced.question: The Hebrew midwives Shiphrah and Puah (Exodus 1:15-21) committed civil disobedience by refusing to obey Pharaoh's order to kill Hebrew baby boys. Their story raises a theological question that ethicists have debated for centuries. What is the core ethical question their story raises?
options: Whether midwives should be paid more

Whether it is morally justified to disobey human authority — even a king — when that authority commands something that violates God's law, and whether deception (their excuse to Pharaoh) can be morally acceptable when used to protect innocent life
Whether women should work outside the home
Whether Pharaoh was punished enough
advanced.explanation: Shiphrah and Puah's civil disobedience raises the question of when obedience to God supersedes obedience to human government. The text says they 'feared God' more than they feared Pharaoh, and 'God was kind to the midwives.' Their deception (the excuse about vigorous Hebrew women) is not condemned in the text — in fact, God rewards them with families of their own. This passage, alongside Rahab's lie and the Hebrew midwives' deception, is used in discussions about whether lying to protect innocent life is morally justified.

advanced.question: The portrayal of women in Luke's Gospel is distinctive compared to the other Synoptics. Luke includes more stories about women, more named women, and more positive portrayals of women. What literary technique does Luke consistently employ when presenting women's stories?
options: He always places women's stories at the end of chapters

He frequently pairs male and female characters in parallel episodes — Zechariah/Mary, Simeon/Anna, the widow of Zarephath/Naaman, the man with the lost sheep/the woman with the lost coin — creating gender-balanced teaching
He always quotes women's exact words
He only includes unnamed women
advanced.explanation: Luke's 'pairing technique' is a distinctive literary strategy: the annunciation to Zechariah is paralleled by the annunciation to Mary (Luke 1); Simeon's prophecy is paralleled by Anna's (Luke 2); the man with a hundred sheep parallels the woman with ten coins (Luke 15); the man healed on the Sabbath parallels the woman healed on the Sabbath (Luke 13-14). This deliberate gender pairing ensures women receive equal narrative space and theological significance. Luke presents the gospel as equally relevant to both men and women.

advanced.question: The story of Hannah (1 Samuel 1-2) contains her prayer of thanksgiving after Samuel's birth, known as the 'Song of Hannah.' This song has been identified as the literary model for a famous New Testament passage. Which New Testament text was directly influenced by Hannah's song?
options: The Lord's Prayer
Mary's Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55) — which shares Hannah's themes of divine reversal, the proud humbled, the humble exalted, the hungry filled, and the rich sent empty
The Beatitudes
Paul's hymn in Philippians 2
advanced.explanation: The parallels between Hannah's Song (1 Samuel 2:1-10) and Mary's Magnificat (Luke 1:46-55) are extensive. Both celebrate: God's care for the lowly, the reversal of social status ('He raises the poor from the dust'), the humbling of the proud, the filling of the hungry. Both women were in unexpected situations of divine favour. Luke deliberately models Mary's song on Hannah's, connecting the two mothers whose miraculous sons would change Israel's history — Samuel who anointed Israel's kings, and Jesus who IS the ultimate King.

advanced.question: Priscilla (Prisca) is mentioned six times in the New Testament, and in four of those six mentions, her name appears before her husband Aquila's. In ancient naming conventions, this order is significant. What does Priscilla being named first likely indicate?
options: That she was taller than Aquila
That she was the more prominent, influential, or theologically active partner in the marriage — ancient naming conventions placed the more notable person first
That her name was alphabetically first
That she was older than Aquila
advanced.explanation: In Greco-Roman convention, naming order reflected social prominence or significance. Priscilla is named first in Acts 18:18, 18:26, Romans 16:3, and 2 Timothy 4:19. This is remarkable in a patriarchal culture where husbands were normally named first. The consistent reversal suggests Priscilla was the more prominent Christian leader — she is the one who primarily taught Apollos 'the way of God more adequately' (Acts 18:26). Some scholars have even suggested Priscilla as the author of the epistle to the Hebrews.

advanced.question: The concept of 'wisdom' (Hebrew: chokmah) in the Old Testament is personified as a woman in Proverbs 1-9. 'Lady Wisdom' is portrayed calling out in the streets, inviting people to her feast, and claiming to have been present at creation. What theological significance does the feminine personification of wisdom carry?
options: It was an arbitrary literary choice with no deeper meaning

It associates the divine attribute of wisdom with feminine imagery — Lady Wisdom is an extension of God's own character, challenging interpretations that associate the divine exclusively with masculine attributes and providing a biblical basis for feminine language about God
It was borrowed entirely from Greek mythology
It only applies to human wisdom, not divine
advanced.explanation: The personification of wisdom as female (Proverbs 1-9, Job 28, Sirach 24, Wisdom of Solomon 7-9) is theologically significant. Lady Wisdom speaks with divine authority, was present at creation (Proverbs 8:22-31), mediates between God and humanity, and offers life to those who follow her. Early Christians identified Jesus with Wisdom (1 Corinthians 1:24, Colossians 1:15-17 — paralleling Proverbs 8). The feminine personification provides canonical precedent for using feminine language and imagery when speaking about divine attributes.

advanced.question: The Samaritan woman at the well (John 4) receives the longest recorded private conversation between Jesus and any individual in the Gospels. During this conversation, Jesus reveals his messianic identity to her directly — something he rarely did with Jewish audiences. What specific claim did Jesus make to her?
options: 'I am the Son of God'

When the woman said 'I know that Messiah is coming,' Jesus replied 'I, the one speaking to you — I am he' ('ego eimi') — the only instance in John's Gospel where Jesus explicitly declares his messiahship to a non-disciple before his trial
'I am a prophet like Moses'
'I am greater than Jacob'
advanced.explanation: The woman said 'I know that Messiah is coming. When he comes, he will explain everything to us.' Jesus responded 'I, the one speaking to you — I am he' (ego eimi — John 4:26). This is remarkable: Jesus, who often veiled his messianic identity in Galilee and Judea (the 'Messianic Secret'), explicitly declared himself to a Samaritan woman — a triple outsider (Samaritan, female, morally questionable). Jesus chose to make his most direct self-revelation to the most unexpected recipient.

advanced.question: The story of Vashti in Esther 1 has been reinterpreted by feminist scholars as an act of courageous resistance rather than mere disobedience. Queen Vashti refused King Xerxes' command to display her beauty before his drunken guests. What was the consequence, and why do feminist scholars view her positively?
options: She was executed immediately

She was deposed as queen — but feminist scholars note she refused to be objectified before drunken men, valuing her dignity over her crown, and her removal created the vacancy that allowed Esther to become queen and save the Jewish people
She was imprisoned for life
She was exiled to a foreign country
advanced.explanation: Vashti was deposed because her refusal was seen as a threat to male authority throughout the empire — the king's advisors feared 'all the women will despise their husbands' if Vashti went unpunished. Feminist scholars celebrate Vashti as a woman who refused to be exhibited as a trophy before drunken men, choosing dignity over power. The irony is that Vashti's courageous act of self-respect created the circumstances for Esther's rise — one woman's defiance led to another woman's deliverance of an entire people.

advanced.question: The phrase 'he shall rule over you' in Genesis 3:16 (part of the consequences of the Fall) has been interpreted in two fundamentally different ways. What are the two main scholarly interpretations of this phrase?
options: That it describes God's original design for marriage vs. that it's a curse on women only

That it is prescriptive (this is how marriage should be — male authority is God's will) vs. descriptive (this is what will happen as a result of sin — male domination is a consequence of the Fall to be redeemed, not a divine ideal to be maintained)
That it applies to all relationships vs. only to marriage
That it was spoken to Eve vs. spoken to the serpent
advanced.explanation: The prescriptive view reads 'he shall rule over you' as God's ordained order — male authority is permanent and divinely mandated. The descriptive view reads it as a consequence of sin — like pain in childbirth and toil in work, male domination is a distortion that entered through the Fall, not part of God's original 'very good' creation (Genesis 1:31). Egalitarian scholars note that in Genesis 1-2, the man and woman are equal partners; hierarchy only appears after the Fall (Genesis 3). If male domination is a result of sin, then redemption in Christ should progressively restore the original equality.

advanced.question: The designation of Mary Magdalene as 'apostle to the apostles' (apostola apostolorum) has a long history in Christian tradition. Who was the first church father to use this title for her, and what does it mean?
options: Augustine in the 4th century

Hippolytus of Rome (3rd century) first applied this title — it means that Mary Magdalene was 'sent' (apostello) by the risen Jesus to announce the resurrection to the Twelve, making her the apostle who commissioned the apostles
Martin Luther in the 16th century
Pope Francis in the 21st century
advanced.explanation: Hippolytus of Rome (c. 170-235 AD) first called Mary Magdalene and the women at the tomb 'apostles to the apostles.' The title reflects the literal meaning of 'apostle' (Greek: apostolos — 'one who is sent'). Jesus sent Mary Magdalene to tell the disciples about the resurrection: 'Go to my brothers and tell them' (John 20:17). She was commissioned by the risen Christ to deliver the foundational message of Christianity to the male apostles. In 2016, Pope Francis elevated her liturgical feast day to the same rank as the twelve apostles.

advanced.question: The 'woman clothed with the sun' in Revelation 12 has been interpreted in multiple ways throughout church history. What are the three main interpretations, and which has the strongest textual support?
options: Eve, Mary, and the church — all three are equally supported

Israel (the people of God who produced the Messiah), Mary (the mother of Jesus), and the church (the community of believers) — with Israel having the strongest textual support due to the twelve stars echoing the twelve tribes (Genesis 37:9) and the Old Testament tradition of personifying Israel as a woman
Three different angels in heaven
Three stages of church history
advanced.explanation: The three main interpretations are: (1) Israel — supported by the twelve stars (twelve tribes, echoing Joseph's dream in Genesis 37:9), the sun and moon (patriarchs), and the Old Testament tradition of Israel as God's bride (Hosea, Ezekiel 16); (2) Mary — she literally gave birth to the Messiah; (3) The Church — the community persecuted by the dragon. Most scholars see a primarily Israel interpretation (giving birth to the Messiah) with secondary Marian and ecclesial applications. The Old Testament imagery favours Israel as the primary referent.

advanced.question: The story of Tamar (Genesis 38) is inserted into the middle of the Joseph narrative, seemingly interrupting the plot. Scholars have identified a specific literary and theological reason for its placement. What is it?
options: It was accidentally misplaced by a later editor

The Tamar story is deliberately placed to contrast Judah's moral failure (sleeping with his daughter-in-law) with Joseph's moral triumph (refusing Potiphar's wife) in the very next chapter (Genesis 39) — creating a literary juxtaposition of two sons of Jacob facing sexual temptation
It provides chronological information about Judah's family
It was inserted to fill a gap in the narrative
advanced.explanation: Genesis 38 (Judah and Tamar) is deliberately positioned between Genesis 37 (Joseph sold into slavery) and Genesis 39 (Joseph and Potiphar's wife). The juxtaposition creates a powerful contrast: Judah succumbs to sexual temptation while Joseph resists it. Both stories involve deception using garments (Tamar's veil, Joseph's cloak). The placement also explains the transition of leadership from Judah (who will become the messianic tribe despite this failure) to Joseph (who maintains integrity in exile). The interruption is intentional, not accidental.

advanced.question: The role of women in Jesus' ministry is sometimes characterised as merely receiving help or healing. However, Luke 8:1-3 reveals that women played a specific practical role that made Jesus' ministry possible. What does this passage reveal?
options: Women cooked meals for the disciples

Several named women — Mary Magdalene, Joanna (wife of Chuza, Herod's household manager), Susanna, and 'many others' — were financially supporting Jesus' ministry 'out of their own means,' serving as patrons who funded the movement
Women only came to listen to Jesus teach
Women were not involved in Jesus' ministry at all
advanced.explanation: Luke 8:1-3 reveals that women served as financial patrons of Jesus' itinerant ministry. Mary Magdalene, Joanna (whose husband managed Herod's household — indicating she was wealthy and politically connected), Susanna, and 'many others' supported Jesus 'out of their own means.' This means Jesus' ministry was partly funded by wealthy women who had independent resources. The role of 'patron' (prostatis) was a position of significant social status in the ancient world. Without these women's financial support, Jesus' travelling ministry could not have functioned.

advanced.question: The relationship between Sarah and Hagar has been used as an allegory by the apostle Paul in Galatians 4:21-31, where Sarah represents the 'free woman' and Hagar represents the 'slave woman.' This allegory has been critiqued by some scholars. What is the main critique?
options: That Paul misquotes Genesis

That Paul's allegory, while making a valid theological point about law vs. grace, risks dehumanising Hagar — a vulnerable, enslaved, sexually exploited woman — by making her a negative symbol, when the Genesis narrative itself portrays God showing compassion to Hagar and making promises to her
That Paul didn't understand the original story
That the allegory contradicts the rest of Galatians
advanced.explanation: While Paul's theological point (the new covenant of grace vs. the old covenant of law) is coherent, scholars like Phyllis Trible and Delores Williams have noted the tension: in Genesis, God shows remarkable compassion to Hagar — appearing to her in the wilderness, promising to multiply her descendants, calling her son 'God hears' (Ishmael). Hagar is the only person who gives God a name (El Roi, 'the God who sees me'). Paul's allegorical use, while not negating these narrative details, shifts Hagar from sympathetic victim to negative theological symbol — a move that requires careful handling.

advanced.question: Deborah's song (Judges 5) — one of the oldest texts in the Hebrew Bible — ends with a striking and disturbing scene: Sisera's mother looking through the window, waiting for her son to return from battle, imagining the spoils he would bring. What makes this scene theologically and literarily significant?
